name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament interrupted on 16 February 2017. (The sitting opened at 15)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda, set by the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149, at its meeting on Thursday 16 February 2017, was distributed.The following proposals for amendments were presented: Wednesday: I report that I have received a request from Mr Terry Reintke.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, I would like to bring to your attention the recent case of Deniz Yücel, a German-Turkish journalist, who has been detained in a Turkish prison for more than two weeks now. He, together with 150 Turkish journalists, deserves our solidarity. This House should not only demand a strong and decisive reaction from the Commission and the Member States, especially the German Government, but we should also request a debate on the situation of journalists imprisoned in Turkish prisons, for the upcoming Strasbourg session. Let us demand the release of journalists detained in Turkey. Journalism is not a crime: it is the basis of democracy. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Reintke, I too am concerned about freedom of expression throughout the world - wait a moment, I am responding to Mr Reintke - if your parliamentary group intends to ask for a debate on this issue, we will discuss this at the next Conference of Presidents.I await the proposal from your parliamentary group.Mr Spinelli asked to speak.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I appeal to Article 22 of the regulation - and I turn to you, President - because I am amazed by what you said yesterday to the press about the repatriation agreements in Libya.Without the Parliament having discussed it yet, and knowing the objections of many deputies, he declared himself in favor of detention camps in Libya, where migrants and refugees could be locked up - I quote - even for years.My group, but not only, is opposed to the agreement, even the UN considers Libya an unsafe state.In the interview, you say that they should not be concentration camps - and God forbid - but I don't know how the Union can guarantee this, since Libya is not a protectorate.I am amazed because, in your time, you promised to be a President respectful of the diversity of this House, I fear it is a promise not kept.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr Spinelli, I have never talked about concentration camps, this word does not belong to my language, and I am against any concentration camp, be it Nazi or communist.So I am also against concentration camps anywhere in the world.I only said that refugees, immigrants who must remain in Libya and who remain in Libya must be welcomed in camps where there are doctors, medicines and must be treated with total respect for the dignity of the person.I have said only this, and I have never talked about camps or detention or concentration, this is not part of my political culture, Mr Spinelli.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, let me point out that we should abide by the Rules of Procedure, and if anyone wants to raise any objection, they should initially, under Rule 184 (a),(a) of the Rules of Procedure, to indicate under which article he raises this objection.Otherwise, this is not Parliament, but it is a cabaret, everyone can perform here and they can attack you here as they please.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, on behalf of the Group of Friends of European Ukraine, I would like to draw your attention to the third anniversary of the victory of Euromaidan. The Maidan Revolution of Dignity was a game-changing event not only for Ukraine: its significance is huge for today’s Europe and the whole free world. The Ukrainian nation chose to be European, free and democratic. During the struggle, Putin disclosed his true face by occupying Ukraine and launching a war in eastern Ukraine. Despite the huge human and financial losses, Ukraine remains a solid member of our European family and is showing a true example of real change. The EU must respond adequately, inter alia by finalising visa-free travel for Ukraine as soon as possible. Colleagues, to all of us in Europe the Maidan revolution is a reminder of freedom and of the price paid for it. That should not be underestimated in these turbulent times. Glory to the heroes of Maidan.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I appreciate all the interventions, but I remind you that we were discussing the approval of the agenda. It is legitimate to criticize the President, it is legitimate to say everything you want in this House, but please respect the rules and respect the other colleagues, otherwise it really becomes a great confusion. We were saying, on Wednesday there is a statement by the President of the Commission on the White Paper on the future of the Union, it will be added as the first item on the agenda. Secondly, the report by Mr Jáuregui Atondo on "e-democracy in the European Union: potential and challenges" was postponed to the March II part-session. Third point: the session will continue until midnight. Are there any objections? The agenda was thus amended. On Thursday the Committee on Legal Affairs approved the following report by Mr Ferrara on parliamentary immunity, in accordance with Rule 9 (8) of the Parliament's Rules of Procedure, this report will be added to the votes on Thursday. The agenda was thus amended. The order of business was thus established.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission President's statement on the White Paper on the future of the EU [2017/2559 (RSP)]. I want to thank the President of the Commission and the entire Commission for deciding to present this debate text to Parliament on the same day as the White Paper on the future of Europe is approved. It is important that this institution, which is the only one directly elected by the Europeans, plays a central role in the debate for a more effective Europe and closer to our citizens. As you all know and as the Commission knows, three reports by Mr Verhofstadt, Mr Böge-Berès and Mr Bresso-Brok were adopted in the last plenary session, which opened the debate in Parliament. I believe that this debate should also continue in the next plenary and in view of the joint declaration for the celebration of the sixtieth anniversary of the signing of the Rome Treaties on 25 March. In my opinion, this anniversary must not only exist as a moment of celebration, but must represent an opportunity for the European institutions to listen even more to citizens, working together to respond to their concerns.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, honorable Members of this House, ladies and gentlemen, later this month in Rome, 27 of our Member States will stand shoulder to shoulder in peace, solidarity and friendship to mark the 60th anniversary of the Treaties of Rome, and I would like to see the President of Parliament associated with these ceremonies. However, this will not simply be a birthday celebration. It should also be the birth moment of the European Union of 27, and as we turn the page and commence a new chapter in our history, it is time we sought new answers to a question as old as our Union is young: quo vadis Europa at 27? Europe’s founding fathers were visionaries. Altiero Spinelli and Ernesto Rossi, imprisoned by a fascist regime, dared to dream of a place where allies and adversaries would unite. Unable to speak freely, they penned the manifesto for a free and united Europe, which had to be circulated secretly in Rome among the Italian resistance movement in 1943. In writing this manifesto, this new chapter, Spinelli and Rossi decided not to cling to the darkness surrounding them in their Ventotene prison cells. They stretched out their arms to the light instead. They dreamed of a better future and paved the way towards it. Sixty years later, this should be an inspiration for us. With nothing to dim our voices, would we be forgiven for not speaking up? In 60 years’ time, what will our grandchildren say of our legacy? I want them to be proud, as Spinelli and Rossi would probably have been today. Now is our time to be pioneers and to carve out a vision so that we may work hand in hand, united at 27, towards our future. Dear Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! The world around us changes every day. The changes and changes are rapid. Globalization, terrorism, migration, the effects of new technologies on society and jobs are profoundly changing everyday life for Europeans. Circumstances, Relationships and relationships do not change annually, monthly or weekly, they change daily - so much and so quickly that we sometimes get out of breath. There are great challenges and high hurdles ahead of us. They are tall and tall, but by no means insurmountable. Either we are overtaken or rolled over by such developments, or we get involved in them, shape them and seize the new opportunities that they bring with them. Europe must not get tired. Europe must be wide awake and actively, sometimes proactively, use opportunities and opportunities. As my friend Frank-Walter Steinmeier said: If we want to encourage others, we need some ourselves. The future of Europe must not be held hostage by election periods, party politics or short-term reports of success in domestic politics. Brexit, as regrettable and painful as it may be, will not be able to stop the European Union on its march into the future - we will continue, we must continue! Where are you going europe Quo vadis, Europe? Where is the Europe of 27 headed? There is really no better time or time than now to have this admittedly difficult debate. All deliberations and debates about which path to take must have an essential task in mind, and the solution to this task must determine the actions of all of us. Let's be honest: for far too long what people expected from Europe was too far removed from what Europe could offer and achieve. Our task will be to make it clear what Europe can and what Europe cannot. Take, for example, the fight against unemployment and, in particular, youth unemployment. We meet summit after summit and promise to lower the number of unemployed, especially youth unemployment. However, this is far beyond what Europe can do alone. On European level we cannot work miracles if national measures fall short. We can finance training programs, stimulate investments - the latter not without success, incidentally - but that does not automatically and per se lead to a systematic decline in unemployment. The EU budget only contributes 0.3% to European social budgets - 0.3%! The Member States contribute 99.7%. To say that Europe has sole responsibility when it comes to combating unemployment is simply wrong. Then we shouldn't pretend that Europe alone can solve the problem. We and the member states should finally admit this. We shouldn't make people believe that we can conjure up the sun and moon if at most we can provide a telescope. We should stop announcing intentions and instead focus more on the areas where we can deliver tangible results. The starting point for the Commission's White Paper that I am putting to you today is this: it is time - I repeat myself - that we clarify what Europe can and cannot do. Far too often the debate about Europe's future is reduced to more or less Europe. But this approach is misleading, just as all over-simplification is misleading. In the White Paper we present different paths for the future of the EU-27: five scenarios for the European Union of 27, although in reality there may be more possibilities. Not all scenarios find the spontaneous approval of the Commission, but all five scenarios are under discussion, so we have to deal with them. We need to explain what consequences each of these scenarios can lead to. Let's look at a first scenario that is based on a continuation of the previous policy. When this commission took office, I promised this House that things would be different to regain people's trust, and to a large extent, hopefully, we will. The Commission has already made great strides in breaking the long-standing reflex of regulating every aspect of people's daily lives and getting involved in everything. People don't want us to regulate toilet flushing or the height of children's swings. We have withdrawn hundreds of proposals and are proposing only 23 new initiatives per year instead of 130 initiatives per year, as was the case in previous years. We focus on the big things that are really important to people. And yet the Commission is accused of over-regulation in all capitals, in almost all national parliaments, sometimes here too, in almost all of the press. This permanent Brussels bashing makes no sense because this Brussels bashing has had no basis since this Commission took office. Incidentally, it would do us all good if we stopped bashing this Brussels, this European Union bashing. This is very often a substitute for national failures. We can go on and on, putting all our energies into achieving results in key areas and moving forward on our positive agenda, which this House has approved. Completing the Single Market, the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union, the Capital Markets Union and the Defense Union. We do that too. And we will do that. But the question must be allowed whether that is sufficient. We could also take the opposite path and, as the European Union of 27, limit ourselves exclusively to the internal market: Scenario 2. If the member states cannot agree on a common position in more and more political areas, if more and more governments degrade the Commission to a simple internal market administrator would like, this might be the only one viable solution. It's not our solution, my solution. The European Union is more than a more or less sophisticated free trade area. Europe is more than a market, goods and money. The single market and the euro are not goals in themselves. You have to serve man and man. Nevertheless, there are governments who want to reduce the role of the European Union and therefore of the Commission to internal market administration. I am strictly against it! Then there is a third option, a third scenario. Do all member states of the European Union always have to move forward at the same pace? If we cannot reach agreement among the 27 on goals or pathways, then those who want to move forward in different areas should be allowed to make further progress where they feel necessary. At the same time, the others who cannot be at the start or who do not want to be at the start must have the opportunity to join the intentions and deeds of the first-time starters later. But how would such a system work? For a small number of countries, this approach could bring great advances. This would undoubtedly be a viable option for countries that wish to exchange, for example, all information on the fight against terrorism, to set up a real European asylum system and to pool defense capacities. However, it could also create a complex system of concentric circles in which many countries would orbit outside the orbit of central political strategies. That would make Europe even more difficult to understand than it already is. How do you explain to people, for example, that Europe is responsible for harmonizing frequencies on which autonomous vehicles can call the emergency services in the event of an accident, but only in countries X, Y and Z, and therefore they would not get any Help when you are in country A. We are already seeing the difficulties of this approach when we try to explain that Europe is partly responsible for monitoring the Schengen external borders, but only partly. And yet: The idea that some Member States are making progress in some areas and breaking the path for those who want to join later cannot simply be put aside. This form of the avant-garde does not aim at exclusion, but at later inclusion. To be honest, I can get a lot from this approach. The goal must remain to march forward to 27. If this turns out to be impossible, the coalition of those willing to integrate must be given permission to continue. European successes were almost always the work of leading pioneers. See Schengen, see Euro. (Applause) But there is a fourth possibility: the EU-27 could jointly decide to do more in a slightly smaller number of areas. In other words, in areas where our European measures would add real added value and where people rightly expect more from us: scenario number 4. Ultimately, this would mean that we are operating on the principle of “less is more”. Examples of areas in which citizens expect more from us are security policy and the so-called diesel gate. A real European Counter-Terrorism Agency, exchanging information across borders and systematically monitoring suspects, could - I am convinced - offer tangible added value for the security of all of us. In the same way, European consumers who are misled by the technical manipulation of car manufacturers must be able to rely on an EU agency that can enforce sanctions against companies who are deceiving and ensure that they also have to pay compensation - everywhere. Instead of the To disappoint people by sending out sharply worded letters calling on Member States to act, we have to make sure that those calls are met. Finally - Scenario 5 - Member States could also choose to share more powers and resources and make more decisions together. In this way you could give full throttle, shape the newly organized common ground into the future and ensure the leadership of the European Union. Climate protection: Europe must continue to play a pioneering role here, regardless of what is on the other side of the Atlantic. Sustainable development: a permanent European task. Defense: Here, further independent contributions from Europe must be listed. Toutes ces perspectives, toutes ces esquisses, tous ces projets théoriquement possibles sont des choix qui s’offrent à nous. Tout en ayant récusé l'idée qu'il faudrait réduire l'Union européenne à l'état de zone de libre-échange, ce qui n'est pas mon concept et qui ne correspond pas aux ambitions de l'Europe, je ne vais pas vous dire ma préférence absolue aujourd'hui parce que, en fin de compte, ce n'est pas à moi seul - et je le regrette - ni à la Commission de faire ces choix «in splendid isolation». Je n’ai pas voulu présenter les vues définitives de la Commission. Je ne procède pas, alors que c’est devenu la mode, par “executive audace”. La parole sera à votre Parlement, aux parlements nationaux, aux gouvernements, à la société civile, bref, aux citoyens. Contrairement à ce qui, jadis, fut la règle, la Commission ne prescrit pas, ne dicte pas, n’instruit pas. Elle veut être à l’écoute avant de se prononcer définitivement. Pas de dictat - cela ne correspond pas à mon tempérament - mais de l’écoute. Je ne suis pas un dictateur, mais j’aime dire les choses comme je les vois. J’aimerais annoncer la couleur, ma conception de l’Union européenne dès aujourd’hui, et je mesure la déception de ceux qui auraient voulu que je le fasse. Mais nous préférons écouter avant de dire. À ceux qui voudraient qu’avant le débat, la Commission dise ce qu’elle voudrait être, je dirai qu’il ne faut pas confondre leadership et diktat. Contrairement à ce qui a été fait jusqu’à présent, nous voulons d’abord écouter avant de nous prononcer. Cela peut conduire - je l’ai lu - à des déceptions majeures, mais c’est une méthode qui fait honneur à la démocratie non seulement representative mais aussi entière. Parler d'institutions, de révision des traités, de procédures institutionalnelles - débat qui agite ceux qui sont installés dans le confort de la bulle bruxelloise, qu'il faudra, à tout prix, que nous quittions tous ensemble - ne m'intéresse pas pour l'instant. D’ailleurs, un tel discours n’intéresserait pas les citoyens. Vous, qui faites des réunions dans tous vos pays, vous a-t-on jamais posé une question sur l’équilibre des pouvoirs entre le Conseil, la Commission et le Parlement? Jamais! Jamais je n’ai eu à répondre à une telle question! C’est donc un débat typiquement bruxellois qui, mis à part ceux qui sont installés dans le confort de la bulle bruxelloise, n’intéresse personne. Il ne faudrait donc pas conduire ce débat. Viendra, j’en suis certain, le jour où les traités devront être adaptés à une volonté collective, mais à une volonté collective à naître. Car elle n’existe pas aujourd’hui. Pour pouvoir donner corps à cette volonté collective, il nous faut un véritable débat, un débat honnête sur l’Europe et sur ce que les citoyens attendent de l’Union européenne. Cette conversation vertueuse ne doit pas avoir lieu seulement à Rome or encore à l’occasion de nos nombreux sommets or de nos nombreux débats ici même. Elle doit avoir lieu dans les villes et les régions, partout en Europe. C’est avec vous, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, et avec les États membres que nous tiendrons une série de débats sur l’avenir de l’Europe. Chaque voix, même minuscule, à peine audible même, doit être entendue. Les citoyens nous diront ce qu’ils attendent de l’Union européenne. Ils exprimeront vraisemblablement leurs doutes, leurs interrogations, mais aussi leurs espoirs. À nous d’y répondre. Le Livre blanc, que je vous invite à lire, y comprised son introduction et l’échange des arguments pour et contre, nous aidera à formuler les bonnes réponses. Au cours des prochains mois, la Commission apportera de nouvelles contributions à ce large débat avec une série de documents de réflexion et de propositions plus précises portant sur les grands enjeux dont demain sera fait. Nous présenterons nos idées sur le renforcement de la dimension sociale, débat à mes yeux essentiel et auquel j’apporte toute mon attention. Ceux qui applaudissent, lorsqu’on parle d’Europe sociale, ne font pas la majorité dans cette salle. Honte à vous! Parce que l’Europe sociale est un enjeu principal pour les décennies à venir. Nous présenterons nos vues sur l’approfondissement de l’Union économique et monétaire et, notamment, sur les mécanismes qui amélioreront la très nécessaire coordination des politiques économiques. Nous présenterons nos vues sur la maîtrise de la mondialisation et nos réflexions sur l’avenir de la défense de l’Europe et l’avenir des finances de l’Union européenne. En matière de défense, il est évident que les États européens devront augmenter leur budget militaire, mais la stabilité planétaire n’est pas seulement fonction de l’ampleur des budget militaires. La stabilité internationale, mondiale, planétaire est aussi fonction de la dimension des budget d’aide au développement et du financement de la lutte contre le changement climatique. Réduire les budgets de l’aide au développement, remettre en cause les engagements qui furent les nôtres et ceux des autres en matière de changement climatique - je parle de la COP 21 - nuira gravement à la stabilité intégrale. L’Union européenne doit porter et continuer à porter ces messages. La stabilité, ce n’est pas seulement l’affaire des armées, c’est also l’affaire de ceux qui veulent aider ceux qui sont en retard à rejoindre ceux qui sont en avance. La stabilité, ce sont les dépenses militaires, mais pas exclusivement; c’est also l’aide au développement et la lutte contre le changement climatique. Mesdames et Messieurs, vous vous êtes déjà penchés sur toutes ces questions et nous nous réjouissons à l’idée de continuer à travailler avec vous et notamment avec les rapporteurs qui ont vu leurs rapports adoptés récemment. Je prends rendez-vous avec vous en septembre, lors du discours sur l’état de l’Union, où je développerai davantage ces idées, pas avant, mais après avoir écouté les uns et les autres. J’aimerais que le Conseil européen donne en décembre ses orientations pour un processus qui atteindra son apogée lors des élections européennes en 2019. In 2019, nous avons rendez-vous avec le suffrage universel européen. Ce sera d’abord un rendez-vous d’explications. Explications entre les forces politiques, c’est-à-dire entre les familles politiques, qui devront dire comment elles voient l’Europe de 2025 et au-delà. Je voudrais que le processus démocratique engagé en 2014 connaisse son prolongement, c'est-à-dire qu'en 2019, les partis européens présentent au choix de l'électeur des têtes de liste, exigence qu'il faudra que nous respections pour que la démocratie européenne fonctionne et reste crédible. En 2019, nous ne pourrons pas renoncer à l’acquis que nous avons réalisé en 2014, ensemble. Je salue d’ailleurs amicalement les candidats qui n’ont pas eu la chance que j’ai pu avoir. (Jean-Claude Juncker replied to M. Verhofstadt qui disait hors micro: “La prochaine fois”.) Les citoyens européens doivent pouvoir décider qui sera le prochain président de la Commission européenne. Les citoyens doivent pouvoir faire leur choix, pas les officines gouvernementales. Je ne serai pas candidat à un deuxième mandat, comme je l’ai dit dès le premier jour. (Applaudissements venant de la droite de l’hémicycle.) (En réaction à ces applaudissements) J’avais pour intention de ne jamais décevoir l’extrême-droite, j’ai réussi. Je ne serai pas candidat à un deuxième mandat, mais, croyez-moi, je ne suis ni fatigué ni à court d’idées, au contraire, et vous allez le voir. Monsieur le Président, l'Europe s'est relevée des cendres de la Seconde guerre mondiale pour réaliser l'impossible: mettre fin à cette éternelle tragédie européenne qui, en fait, nous obligeait - les peuples, leurs dirigeants - à choisir entre la guerre et la paix. Dans le monde d’aujourd’hui, plus de quarante guerres et conflits militaires font rage, mais pas un seul ne se déroule sur le sol européen proprement dit. Vu de plus loin et à partir d'autres continents, l'Europe continue à rester une chose magnifique: avoir réuni tout un continent, avoir mis un terme à ce funeste décret d'après-guerre qui voulait que l'Europe, à tout jamais, soit scindée en deux blocs, y avoir créé un espace de stabilité, de prospérité et d'égalité nous vaut l'admiration du monde entier. Très souvent, j’ai l’impression que les autres nous admirent et que nous-mêmes, il nous arrive de nous détester. Mais cette Europe, celle que je décris, n’est pas un acquis, ni une évidence. L’Europe a toujours été et reste aujourd’hui et pour toujours un choix délibéré, qu’il faut défendre contre vents et marées, contre l’assaut de ceux qui ne veulent pas comprendre le cours de l’histoire. Les choix que nous faisons maintenant, aujourd’hui, demain, dans deux ans et d’ici 2025 doivent tenir compte de leurs implications, non seulement pour nous, mais surtout pour les générations à venir. Parce que nous serons jugés, non pas sur ce qui nous a été légué, mais sur ce que nous laisserons en héritage. Nos citoyens nous disent souvent que nous devons faire les choses différemment. Oui, nous y sommes prêts, mais il ne faut pas vouloir tout changer. Nous devrions essayer de mieux comprendre les contraintes et les chances d’une application correcte du principe de subsidiarité, qui ne doit pas devenir un ersatz pour la solidarité, laquelle doit, elle, rester le principe directeur de toutes nos actions européennes et nationales. Très souvent, en écoutant ceux qui se font l’avocat du principe de subsidiarité, j’ai l’impression que, comme ils ne veulent pas parler de solidarité, ils préfèrent parler de subsidiarité. Il s’agit de bien comprendre la signification exacte du concept de subsidiarité. Monsieur le Président, nous n’avons pas le droit d’être - comment dire - patriotes contre les autres. Le patriotisme du XXIe siècle se décline en deux dimensions: un patriotisme heureux, accepté et acceptable vers l’intérieur, et la solidarité, qui est le prolongement du patriotisme heureux vers l’extérieur. Il ya des valeurs qui doivent continuer de nous unir: la paix, la démocratie, la solidarité, l'état de droit - qui doit être la règle qui sous-tend notre vivre-ensemble très souvent menacé -, la dignité et l'égalité de tous les êtres humains, ainsi que la liberté de la presse. Regardez ce qui se passe en Turquie où l’on emprisonne, sans raison aucune, of the journalist allemands parce qu’ils ont osé dire ce qu’il fallait dire! Les valeurs, oui, ce qui inclut le refus du rejet de l’autre, de celui qui est différent de nous, mais qui n’est pas moins noble que nous-mêmes. Nous ne pouvons pas accepter que les voix de ceux qui défendent ces valeurs, dont je voudrais qu’elles soient universelles, soient noyées dans le vacarme des slogans nationalistes qui font du patriotisme une poor contre les autres. Le patriotisme n’est plus un patriotisme lorsqu’il se dirige contre les autres. L’Europe, elle, doit rester une force mondiale positive. Nos sociétés européennes sont bâties sur l’ouverture et nous devrions en être plus fiers. D’autres préfèrent se refermer sur eux-mêmes et tourner leur regard vers l’intérieur. Le nombrilisme fait des progrès angoissants à travers la planète. Mais une telle attitude n’est ni dans notre nature, ni d’ailleurs dans notre intérêt. La démocratie - la démocratie entière - est un produit européen et nous la défendrons partout et de toutes nos forces. Alors, ayons le courage, la patience et la détermination qui sont nécessaires aux longs trajets et aux grandes ambitions. L’Europe continues à être une grande ambition. Une ambition qui a derrière elle et devant elle un long trajet. Nous avons aujourd’hui le choix entre plusieurs chemins, certains plus pernicieux que d’autres, d’autres plus porteurs d’avenir que d’autres. Monsieur le Président, quel que soit le choix que nous ferons, la destinée de l’Europe à Vingt-sept est entre nos mains. Entre nos mains, oui, mais elle est d’abord et avant tout une affaire de cœur et une affaire de valeurs, de valeurs qui donnent sa véritable dimension à la raison d’État européenne. Je ne suis pas en train de citer un poème européen, je décris une nécessité continentale. (Applaudissements)

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank President Juncker for having chosen the European Parliament as the first place to present this White Paper. The anniversary of the Treaties of Rome will be something other than a celebration: it will be a farewell to the United Kingdom and it will be the birth of the Union with 27 Member States. We have done many things wrong before arriving at this point. Brexit is not the cause. Brexit is the last consequence and we must be sure it remains the last consequence. If Brexit is a divorce, the anniversary of the Treaties of Rome should be a time to renew the commitments between us and the Union. We are all facing serious challenges: globalisation, terrorism, migration and the refugee crisis, climate change and so on. The question is simple: how do we want to deal with those challenges? How do we move forward? But also, do we want to move forward? This is a legitimate question too because I know that I want to move forward, but we cannot simply blame those who do not want to go further than we are now, by calling them anti—European. We are all Europeans. Europe belongs to all Europeans, no matter whether they come from the north, the south, the east or the west. Europe belongs to all of us. That is why I thank the Commission for having presented five different scenarios, even knowing that none of them will be fully accepted. For my Group, for example, a sixth scenario could also be possible: merging the other five because they are not mutually exclusive. I agree with President Juncker that the time has come to align expectation with reality. It is time to say what you can do, and not promise what you cannot do. It is time to defend Europe because it is the best bastion against nationalism and populism. What Member States must do is to stop blaming Europe for what Europe cannot do because it does not have the tools. This is a wrong and dangerous game and Brexit is one of the consequences. Whatever road we take, we must take it in unity and with consensus because these two words have given us 60 years of peace. We may have forgotten where we come from. We come from war, death, poverty and hunger. We come from lack of freedom. We may have forgotten why unity is so important. We may have forgotten to explain that there is no alternative to the Union – not in the past, not now, and not in the future. The Union was – and will be – the best instrument for peace. So, when a country as important as the United Kingdom leaves us, we have to ask ourselves the question: are they leaving us because peace is already consolidated or because peace is no longer important? I cannot understand it. To conclude, this debate is necessary: a debate about the future that we want for ourselves and for our children. This debate starts today, right here, right now, in the European Parliament. This Parliament must be fully involved from now on. Every single Member, every single Committee and every single body of this House must be involved. Europeans must be the owners of their own future, and this Parliament is the way forward for them. This debate means that the Council, the Commission and the Parliament have realised one thing: that the Union is built from its citizens and not from the institutions. As Manfred Weber said today, it is now or never. Well done, Mr Juncker. (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I know you, President Juncker, as a devoted pro-European, a man who all his life has fought to make Europe better and stronger. But the White Paper the Commission is now presenting has disappointed us now that Europe is faced with unprecedented challenges: a protectionist US President, Russia and China on the rise, and the bloody war on our doorstep from which millions of people are running for their lives; now that populists show their ugly face in every corner of Europe; now that hardworking families all over Europe are struggling to make ends meet and are worried about their children’s future; now that our common European House, which has sheltered us for decades, has to weather the toughest storm ever. Now you are presenting us with a reflection paper and scenarios instead of a clear plan to fortify our House to weather this storm. You are right, President Juncker, in showing all the political difficulties, because the difficulties are real; but it is necessary, it is essential, to indicate one political priority, one political option, because the European Commission is not a bureaucratic body but a political body, and you know very well that we support you for this reason. I can only see one option, the fifth option, because it is the only viable option: to work together as Europeans and to do much more together, because together we are stronger.  There is so much left to do. Our House needs a strong Social Pillar to protect our citizens. And it needs European fiscal capacity. We must complete the European monetary union and build a sustainable Europe capable of fighting climate change and creating jobs and growth. We must combat tax fraud, and the project of a common European army is now more important than ever. We have to defend our inclusiveness without leaving aside the eastern countries. We can only achieve this if we stay united as Europeans. President Juncker, I call on you and on your Commission to take on your responsibility. You are the guardians of the Treaties, the guardians of the common European good and our common European future at this time. We ask you to show leadership and urge the Council to take on their historic duty.  In a couple of weeks, we will celebrate the anniversary of the Rome Treaties. Only some years after a terrible world war in Europe, political leaders had the courage to commit to European unity and explained to their citizens why we Europeans are stronger together. After decades in which Europe has brought us peace and prosperity, is it really too much to ask of this generation of leaders to commit to Europe and make it stronger for the future? Let us not give up. Let us show political leadership in the fight together for a Europe that is better and stronger, so that our children and their children will have a good future. (Applause)

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Thank you, Mr. Chairman! “Quo vadis, Europe?” You ask, Mr Juncker, and that is a good and right question at the right time. The EU and the euro area face challenges that they cannot master. Particularly noteworthy are the repercussions of the common currency, the euro, which has inflicted epochal damage on Europe's citizens. The crisis continues to swell and the previous policy - namely to buy time - does not work. Yes, the EU made peace, but now only peace is conjured up in connection with the EU. Let us remember: one day the EU and especially the euro zone should also ensure prosperity and growth - these hopes have failed. This is not an industrial accident, but the result of centralism and megalomania. The failed concepts of social and economic centralization belong in the moth box. Unfortunately, such ideas can still be found in your paper, Mr Juncker. For example in scenario 5, where politics is to be moved into the innovation cluster modeled on Silicon Valley. Mr. Juncker, you are already a little way on the right track to say goodbye to outdated ideas. You have to go a little further. Innovation and change work by themselves if politics creates good framework conditions. If states want industrial policy, then they should do so at their own risk and expense. Your scenario 2 of restricting the EU to the common market is therefore not unreasonable! The peace effect of economic integration would thus be preserved. But I admit that there are other concerns for the EU to play a functional role - for example counter-terrorism and border protection. Your concept 4 is under the heading “do less and do it more efficiently”! This idea is fundamental, the EU towards some areas restrict, well and the right approach. At this point we should move on. We can see from the rapid succession and change of the crisis scenarios in recent years that we can hardly tie down policy areas forever. Flexibility is necessary. It must be clear that the cooperation mentioned in Scenario 4 means voluntary participation in individual programs and that the nation states are given the opportunity to withdraw from programs or to insert new cooperations as required. Times are changing and the EU needs institutional rules that allow it to adapt to new challenges. Nobody here in the company can foresee where cooperation will make sense 10 or 20 years from now, and we should - as you rightly mentioned - give future generations this freedom. Mr Juncker, you are perhaps one step further than our colleague Verhofstadt, who has not yet learned his Brexit lesson and would like to continue to impose a centralized feel-good happiness on European citizens. Please communicate that! It is high time this Parliament abandoned wishful thinking. And finally: Your five scenarios suggest a certain flexibility. What a shame, Mr Juncker, that you did not express this flexibility to David Cameron in this way, because then the British would certainly still be a member of this European Union. Many Thanks.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I find it a crazy idea that it is now Mr Juncker’s fault that there is a Brexit. I thought it was more or less an internal catfight within the Conservative Party that was the reason for Brexit. It is crazy how some people then blame this House here and say that it is the cause. But that said, I welcome the contribution from the Commission and I certainly welcome your introduction, Mr Juncker, because you made mention of the founding fathers: Altiero Spinelli, and I could add Paul-Henri Spaak, I could add Heinrich von Brentano, founding father of the German Grundgesetz, and I could add Jean Monnet and Robert Schuman. I could even add Winston Churchill, because from 1946 to 1951 – a part that was forgotten by Mr Boris Johnson in this biography of Winston Churchill – he was the leader of European integration and of the future European Union. That said, it is important to recognise one thing here, which is that, before we go to Rome for the festivities, what we want today is something different from the Treaty of Rome, because the Treaty of Rome was a customs union. It was maybe the right answer in 1957 but, let us be honest, it is not the answer to the challenges we are facing today. I think it is very important to talk about the founding fathers because they had more ambition than just the Treaty of Rome. The Treaty of Rome was a fall-back option, a fall-back solution, because they were not able – because of the ‘no’ vote in the French National Assembly – to make a defence union, to make a political union, and to make an economic union. It is wise to remember what they wanted after the Second World War, which was to create a Union that was capable and decisive. But what is our problem today? You will find it in your five scenarios. You have given us five scenarios but what I remember from your introduction is that we can forget the first three. Let us talk about scenarios four and five, and I think that is the right decision to make, but, let us be honest: what is lacking in the European Union of today? Why are we not capable of stabilising our neighbourhood? It is because we do not have the capabilities to do so. Why are we not capable of finding a solution to the migration crisis and the refugee crisis? Because we have no capabilities to do so at European level. Why are we not capable of cleaning up our banks, eight years after Lehman brothers? Eight years after, we are still facing problems with an unrealised banking union, with no recovery fund and so on. Why? Because we have no European capacities and capabilities. And finally, why do we not have big European internet companies? If we talk about Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Samsung, they are all American or Asian. And why? Because we do not have a completed digital market in the European Union: no European capacities, for example for a European telecom authority or a digital authority, as you propose in your fourth scenario. That is the lesson. We are still a loose confederation of nation states based on the unanimity rule, and if there is one country blocking – and you know this better than I do, Mr Juncker, having been a Member for a long time of the European Council – if only one member says ‘no’, then we apply the unanimity rule and we do not go forward. Too little, too late – that is the consequence of the absence of the European capacities and European capabilities that we desperately need.  So we do not need to start asking whether it is four, five, or three, because we are already familiar with the different circles in the European Union. We have 50 exceptions in the European budget. There are 50 different circles in the European Union. The question now is how can we overcome that? How, for one, do we convince European leaders at national level to make the jump forward that we desperately need? That is the question, and therefore our proposal from Parliament, in our papers and in the reports that have been discussed and approved two weeks ago, is to start an interinstitutional reflection. We alone cannot decide this. You alone, Mr Juncker, cannot decide from your side in the Commission. Even the Council cannot do that – and maybe they do not have the inspiration to do it. So our plea, Mr President of the Commission, is that you back our proposal for an interinstitutional reflection from day one, from now on, so that we are not only talking about Brexit here in this House, but we also open an offensive – a positive, optimistic reform of the Union in parallel with Brexit. And it is not only a negative story of one country leaving us, but also a story of 27 who know that their destiny in the future will be in unity, together, in the European Union.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, let us take note of your profession of faith that your Commission, Mr President, does not impose, does not prescribe. If this is true, then you will need to build on what citizens are living and saying - workers, peasants, unemployed, young people - and organize a major European citizens' debate; kinds of states-general for a refoundation of the European Union. The challenges are too great, too worrying not to change course. The challenge is not to simply groom the facade: we have to rethink, we have to redesign ourselves and we will have to take stock of the application of the treaties. As long as the European Union is not the concern of the peoples themselves, as long as it does not take into account their aspirations to live better, as long as it is not a project for justice, equality, solidarity, democracy, human and environmental well-being, it will continue to be rejected. As long as it is seen only as a strangulation system for Greece or a sort of public expenditure police, as long as it is a fortress for migrants, but a paradise for the free movement of capital, it will continue to grow. to be rejected. As long as it carpools with business circles and financial funds to the detriment of workers, it will be rejected. That is why, Mr President Juncker, we can imagine another scenario, a scenario that starts with the people themselves, the employees, the creators, the youth. Launch a major European popular public debate preparing a European conference on democratic, social, ecological, feminist overhaul, with a view to building a new European project. Failure to do so will condemn the European idea itself. Besides, between us, start by consulting the people on the free trade project with Canada: this would be an act showing that Europe is an asset for transforming globalization. Replace the concept of generalized competition with that of cooperation, austerity by a new distribution of wealth and a new way of producing it, unemployment and precariousness by professional social security, the current common agricultural policy by a new agricultural policy and food which would take into account employment and health. Imagine a new policy for tomorrow's industry and digital technology, a major cooperation project with the countries of the South. Action can be taken to ensure that the billions of cash provided by the European Central Bank are used for employment projects and new public services. Let’s launch a big plan against tax evasion and a tax and social harmonization project aimed at justice. The European project could be relaunched by amending the fund that you created to make it a fund for social, human and environmental development which, at the same time, could refinance the over-indebted states. Mr. Speaker, we must not miss this historic moment. Listen to the peoples, involve them in a new project.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is an understatement to say that the European Union is not at its best, and I thank you therefore, Mr President Juncker, for coming up with proposals. You try in your document to answer the question of "how". We believe that before answering this question, we should ask ourselves the "why", and in particular why an increasing number of our fellow citizens have become defiant, even openly hostile to the very idea of ​​European construction. It is clear that in their eyes, the European Union has lost its legitimacy. There is obviously the question of institutional legitimacy: the Union would be too distant, too opaque; decisions would be taken there too concealed by policies that do not sufficiently assume their responsibilities. If this were the diagnosis, one would expect ambitious proposals in terms of transparency and democratic control, and all of this is necessary. But I think that mistrust has deeper roots, because if it is legitimacy that it is, it is legitimacy by the result. Indeed, what can a large single market and currency, combined with fiscal and social competition, lead to? What can free trade treaties and regulatory standards lead to that set the right to profit as an absolute and superior standard, if not to the enrichment of the owners of capital to the detriment of all others? It is this, I think, which is at the source of the big battalions of our fellow citizens who join the Eurosceptics, even the Europhobes. If the European Union were a vehicle, today it would be less a question of discussing its shape, the number of seats or even the speed of this vehicle than its engine and, above all, its direction. Mr. Juncker, if I may, you suggest that we stand still, reverse, move before together or in differentiated groups, but always in one direction, as if the idea of ​​a change of course was just unthinkable. You had the courage, Mr Juncker, to give us the correct diagnosis when we were faced with the challenge of asylum and immigration. You told us - and you were right - that, if we want to keep this area of ​​free movement that we value so much - and we do want it - we cannot fail to have a common asylum and immigration policy and common management of our borders. You had this courage. Strangely enough, in the face of exploding inequalities and a rocking single currency - and that's saying something - you don't have the courage to tell the historical truth. There is no - I mean no - monetary union in the history of mankind that has held without fiscal union, without social union, and therefore without political and democratic union. It is this contradiction that we must resolve today if we are to maintain the single market and the single currency, and we do so. If we want to win back, Mr President, the hearts and minds of our fellow citizens, we believe it is urgent to reconnect European construction to what was its initial ambition, that is to say to ensure peace. on this continent - and this remains relevant today - by the extension of democracy and by shared prosperity. If we want to reconnect Europe to this objective, we must abandon this idea of ​​fiscal and social competition in order to move towards convergence, in other words put the dignity of all, and not the prosperity of a few, at the heart of the European project.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the White Paper on the future of the European Union follows the usual format that we are used to. It recognises the problems facing it, but fails to understand that many of these were created by the EU in the first place. The solution is always the same, namely for the EU to have yet more power in order to solve the problems that it created, and that always means yet more integration – political, fiscal and economic. The Paper acknowledges that the current economic crisis particularly affects the younger generation. It quite rightly wants to ensure that every generation is better off than the previous one. It acknowledges that the effect on the young is particularly felt within the euro area and, in the same paragraph, it goes on to say ‘this highlights the need to complete economic and monetary union’. It defies belief that Mr Juncker, or anybody else, can fail to understand that the European single currency is the single biggest reason for the catastrophic levels of youth unemployment in countries like Portugal, Spain and Greece. The austerity measures designed to keep the euro alive just make things worse.  The Paper does not once mention the British referendum. If Mr Juncker tried to understand the reasons why the British voted to leave, it might help him understand what is needed to reform the European Union. Sadly, I do not think he is going to do that but,  happily, Britain will not be part of it.  (Applause)

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - The European Union is in decline and support for your European project is crumbling. The Dutch, among others, have already said no to the European constitution and the association agreement with Ukraine. And now the first member state is leaving, because the British said no to the EU. I am happy for them. But at a time when the population yearns for freedom, all you are doing here is keeping the Brussels dream alive. Because Juncker's future plans for the European Union are more of the same: more, more, more European Union. The President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, even wants the Member States to swear allegiance once again to the European project. Who makes such a thing up? How unworldly are you really? You are playing with the future of millions of citizens you do not represent and whom you have asked nothing at all. Mr Juncker now says that he wants to hear every citizen, every voice. But may I remind you of a few quotes from the same man? On the French referendum in connection with the European constitution, he sees: “If it is a yes, we will say: on we go. If it is a no, we will say: we continue. ” And about Greece: “When it becomes serious, you have to lie”. Madam President, that is democracy in the European Union, that is what Brussels stands for here. Proposals of this kind from unelected EU bosses will only reaffirm the feeling in the Dutch that we have to get rid of the stifling EU, on the road to sovereignty, on the road to freedom.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Juncker very much indeed for coming to the Chamber this afternoon and for outlining his White Paper. Mr Juncker, it was very nice to see you and I will regret losing you in two-and-a-half years’ time when you go into retirement. But the legacy you will leave, sir, in terms of the White Paper that you have outlined this afternoon is really quite dangerous and a real delusion in terms of denial of what has happened. Everything that has happened in the European Union in the last few days – and last few years for that matter – has been because of lack of action: the lack of sensible action, or the lack of action full-stop. And so what you see across the European continent is the emergence of all the threats and all the issues that you have highlighted in your White Paper, but there is nothing in the White Paper that gives citizens across Europe the opportunity to voice their discontent – via referenda, for instance – and actually highlight to you what is wrong. We all wish the European Union project a future. There are 27 Member States that want that to happen. There is one Member State that has made the right decision to walk away. But, sir, can I just implore you to look at that White Paper? You have signalled with your fifth option what your preference is, but I ask you again, for the sake of 440 million citizens, please go back to a blueprint and come up with something new, something that does not just paper over the cracks and look backwards for solutions, rather than looking forward for what is actually required.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Let us now turn to the other speakers.We are very late, I have been flexible with the group presidents, now I ask you to strictly respect the time allotted to you, I will not even be able to grant the "blue card" because, I repeat, the delay is very strong.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate President Juncker on the decision to present the White Paper to the Parliament and to present it to the press in the presence of the Parliament. This is a good sign as it shows what you think about the future of Europe, namely that it has to be a democratic construction, a democratic building. I would also like to congratulate you – and to disagree with the Socialists – because I think it is a good idea to present five scenarios and not only one solution. The problem of the future of Europe is not the Commission and its view, it is not the European Parliament and its view, but is really the responsibility of the Member States and now the Member States, within their national parliaments and their national public opinion, will have to say what they want. They have to be confronted with their own responsibilities. I think that this is a very important step to bring transparency, democracy and legitimacy to this process of reforming the European Union in the near future. Finally, I would like to say that the EPP Group has approved its own strategy. We are totally committed to the idea of a social market economy, to innovation, development, growth, the creation of jobs and prosperity, and to moving forward in defence and security reforms that lead towards a kind of European defence union.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, I would say that the problem is not that the Commission is coming forward with scenarios, because that is interesting. Nevertheless, the expectation will be of the Commission saying that we can consider these scenarios but that there is a choice, which is the choice the Commission is proposing. Why is that so? Because we are in such a situation, with these overlapping crises and these so—called existential crises, that the key question in the current situation is not whether we need to have better European solutions or to go backwards. This is not the central question. The central question is about how we can deliver better European solutions, because we have a majority in favour of better European solutions. I am sure that majority exists here in this House; I am sure, of course, it exists in the Commission; and I am sure that majority exists among European citizens. Why? Because it is evident that, in order to deliver better labour conditions and better large—scale investment, we need better European solutions. The same goes for trade, defence, security and migration. So let us focus the discussion on how to deliver these better European solutions. I hope this will be the central question for the period to come.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! If we are to choose the right future for the European Union, it is important that we start by stating one thing completely: Brexit was not the disease, it was the symptom of the disease. The disease is an EU that for far too many years has moved far further in integration and in a federal direction than member states and not least the peoples of the EU have wanted. That is why it is absolutely central now that the Commission has played out to the Member States and said: should we go in a direction that means smaller EU, a more reformed EU, back to the idea of ​​the internal market as the focal point and not the federal union? If we do, I believe we have a future as a European community based on common values. If, on the other hand, one moves in the federal direction towards a European superstate, I am sure that Brexit is only the first in a number of countries that would rather seek their happiness outside the community than inside. That should be the concern, both of the Commission and of the EU federalists in this House. I hope we choose the sensible path. I hope we choose the path that means a collaboration we can be together on, and not a federal union that we all want to get out of.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Mr President, Monsieur Juncker, I speak on behalf of the European Free Alliance in this Parliament. With Brexit we know that the future of Europe will necessarily be different in a few months. To prepare for this, we must take seriously our own slogan: "Unity in Diversity." Until now it has been possible for each Member State to go practically on its own, and thus there is no Union. In the future, the Union will only be possible if two conditions are met: first, that the European Union recognizes the value of medium-sized nations and welcomes former nations, declared explicitly pro-European, such as Scotland and Catalonia; second, that all the States, the current ones and those that are added, accept that respect for diversity is only achieved if, at the same time, common ties and commitments are accepted that oblige them and make them stronger. In other words, for the Europe of the future, greater diversity, with a more effective unity. Only then will the values ​​of the European Union be credible.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - The path to federalism we are discussing today will, in my view, be the most direct path to the collapse of Europe. Aren’t we ready to go that route? I would see another way. Not two speeds, not European federalization, but Europe's path to unity and freedom. A Europe of free, equal nations is the only way that can bring us together for a common pursuit of Europe and its future. I would see a path to a Europe without fictional fears, to a Europe without distorted liberalism, without blind capitalism, not one in which apologists no longer see an exploited person, where most politicians no longer have responsibility and most officials no longer have conscience. Is we not determined to strengthen such a European Union? Are we not determined to solve the problems of the big states at the expense of the small ones? Today, I see a desire to push to the margins those states that are really in favor of a commonwealth of states, for a real reform of the European Union, and not for its transformation into a United States of Europe.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: -  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! If you listen to the statements made by the President of the Commission, but also to those of the heads of the pro-EU parliamentary groups here, you get a bit of the impression that the captain's bridge of the Titanic has just stepped up and you turn a blind eye to the fact that in water has long since penetrated this European concept. I do not understand why one does not understand here that it is precisely the undesirable developments in centralization in recent years that are the problem here and that we want to continue in the wrong direction. There are enough concept proposals to change this European Union, to redimension it and thus lead it into a good future. For example, the proposal is on the table to cut the European Commission in half, to redimension the European Parliament and thus to give the member states more decision-making space again. But all of this is obviously of too little interest to you, because you want to take this step further and further, to centralize Europe, while on the other hand the citizens of Europe are running away from you and you are actually doing Europe a very, very disservice if you to develop precisely these failed concepts instead of handing over more possibilities to the nation states.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, the debate that opens, and with the White Paper, aims to make the European Union more effective in its attack on the people, amid growing popular discontent. It shows the struggle with its competitors internationally, the fierce competition within the European Union, on the ground of anisometry, between Member States and portions of capital, as well as the need for the European Union to gain time. None of the five versions proposed has anything to do with popular interests. Whatever scenario is followed by the European Union and its governments, the workers will be the multiple losers and the monopolies the benefactors and multiple winners who will hoard. Workers, from their own experience, can conclude that the European Union is a union of capital and that the goals it has been serving all these years are deeply unpopular. The European Union is neither changing nor improving. An urgent need and way out is to intensify the popular struggle against the European Union and the capitalist system, for workers' power, with liberation from the European Union.

name: Herbert REUL
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Commission! We all agree: Europe has achieved great things. Nobody actually denies that. And that's why it's important. But it is also undisputed that Europe has obviously lost approval in the approval of the people and even of a state. It doesn't help to pray that well, or to swear how great this project is. It also doesn't help to break down what's good from morning to evening and only talk about the bad. And that is why, Mr President of the Commission, I am extremely grateful to you for the type of approach that you have now chosen: at last, not just a proposal from the Commission that says: 'This is how it is done', but a thoughtful paper with alternatives. This gives you the chance to take people and all of us back with you on a future project, to bring people together, to think about what is the advantage of path A, path B, path C or D, just weigh what you want then in the end you want what you can still manage, where the common denominator is. That's what it's about at the moment. And if only another piece of paper is presented and everyone prays down their things that are important to them, we will race in front of the wall again. I find it extremely intelligent and super helpful that this path is chosen. I think that's right, because of course you have to answer a few questions about what Europe can and cannot do - you can't avoid the question. The subject of youth unemployment is constantly being talked about here - and rightly so. And President Juncker has described precisely that precisely this example is suitable for explaining why we hit the wall: Because we are overwhelmed, because we cannot do what we are supposed to do, because we are not responsible are. It is much smarter to say: What are we doing? We do what all states consider feel wise what Europe can do together because one state can no longer do it alone.And everyone at home has to take care of the other things a bit.With that in mind: Mr President Juncker, I am extremely grateful to you that this attempt is being made.Of course, that only makes sense if we all embark on this path now.If everyone downgrades their programs again, it hits the wall.And if at the next piece of advice everyone just tells what they want and what they don't want, it's over.Thank you very much, this is a huge opportunity!

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – Mr President, President Juncker, today in Belgium it is Complimentendag. Do you know what that means? It means giving compliments to each other, it is a very special day, so let me start with a compliment. You have written a very comprehensible White Paper, something one can easily understand: I can give it to my mother who is 68 years old, or to my daughter who is nine years of age, and they will understand it. It is a good start to a discussion. But having said that, our Group is also disappointed because, here in Parliament, all of us are elected to prepare the future of Europe, and that means getting into the concerns of Europe, and you know very well what they are. If you look at the great challenges of Europe, they are migration and security, solidarity – or the lack of solidarity – and growing inequalities. You mentioned the social pillar, and, of course, climate change. If you want to address those things – and we need to do that, it is our mutual responsibility – then you need a Union in which we work much more closely together. So you do not need all these scenarios. We know which scenario we need to prepare the future of Europe.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: - Mr President, Mr Juncker, I would like so much to believe you when you say that you have social Europe at heart and that you indeed want it to become a priority. We all agree here - you said moreover when you took office that it was perhaps the Commission of the last chance - we are all aware that there is a major problem with the European Union currently. Without making any trial of intentions, how can you expect us to be able to study solution scenarios when we have not shared a common diagnosis on the reasons why the European Union is in crisis and in difficulty? I won't go into the detail of your last scenario - which obviously is your preference. It's just the same as the first, except you take off the slippers to put on sneakers, but you always go to the same place and always on the same path. Mr Juncker, we must - as Mr Verhofstadt clearly said - ask ourselves the question of blockages in this Europe and ask ourselves, in order to be able to actually move forward, what reforms we must implement in order to be able to transform this Union European?

name: Marco VALLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker, you said in your speech that the single currency, the single market, are at the service of citizens today. I can show you exactly the opposite and that is why citizens are becoming disaffected with the project, precisely because there is this conflict of interest, on which the European Union is founded, and the fact that you present these proposals, after being being the President of a tax haven - in fact, Luxembourg - for twenty years, further increases this citizens' disaffection with the European Union and the proposals you can bring in this area. Do you really want people to get attached to the European project? So, let's start from three fundamental points: first, let's get rid of those who have obvious conflicts of interest like you; second, we discuss alternatives to the single currency and this single market, truly putting them at the service of the people - not just the big stakeholders; third, we involve citizens in this process. We want referendums and direct democracy which must be the pillars of the new Europe otherwise citizens will always ask themselves: who is in charge of Europe, us or the lobbies?

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! The nearest future, i.e. 2017, will determine the fate of the European Union, ie it will answer the question "Quo vadis, Europe?" These will be national events with Europe in the background, because in addition to starting the Brexit procedure, the Dutch are going to the elections in two weeks, then there will be presidential rounds in France, and then the German elections. These national elections and decisions will have a greater impact on the future of Europe than even the best-designed white paper and the best-organized celebration of the 60th anniversary of the Treaties of Rome - may it be as well organized as possible, but the celebration of the 50th anniversary is rather a celebration of elites than of Europeans themselves. Although these decisions will be national in nature, the agenda for these elections will be fully European. Migration, refugees, terrorism, the future of the euro area, common defense - this is a risk and an opportunity. The risk is because there have been and there are populist and xenophobic forces in the attack in this area, but there is also a chance in this area because they live off real and real fears, but they do not give any real answer. We expect this response from the Commission - so far we have scenarios, it is not a plan yet. But next week, without this plan yet, we can make an act of the desired continuity amidst many uncertainties, that is, extend the mandate of Donald Tusk as head of the European Council. Let it be.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Juncker, thank you for choosing the European Parliament to present your White Paper - European Parliament which, as you know, has just adopted three reports which could make a strong contribution to the cycle of debates that you just opened. With regard to this White Paper, I can see that you were obliged to put several scenarios on the table. It seems to me that there is only one that is really viable. He needs to be fed; it must be the basis from which we convince our constituents - the citizens of Europe - that this is the way forward. The year 2017 is a year that you defined in all its amplitude until its conclusion at the European Council in December, and it is this path that we must accompany. However, on this path, there are electoral meetings, and I see your White Paper - which you are presenting to us here, in the European Parliament, while we ourselves have already made our contributions to nourish this reflection - as an interpellation capitals. The questions and scenarios that you present must be seen as alternatives in each of the capitals when the Member States decide to say what they want for themselves, but also where they choose to say what they want for themselves. they want for Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker, today you are presenting us with a White Paper on the future of the Union. If you had the courage to scrutinize your conscience, you should also present us with another one: the Black Book of the recent past, of inequalities, poverty and social exclusion. The starting point is what Europe can do? I tell him what he has to do: change policies and purposes in all your scenarios. Do you want an example? In your single response to migration, erase the already scarce flexibility of the current Dublin, there is no mandatory and permanent preventive redeployment mechanism. Your solidarity exists only in words, because the rules will say more. Your common defense does not aim at reducing costs and duplication to reinvest savings in the social sector, but is based instead on increasing spending to build a military superpower that for now is without even a truly common interest and when it criticizes Turkey - President - remember that you and your Commission wanted that illegal agreement with Ankara, without even a vote from this Parliament. As always, ask only for more tools to better impose the wrong policies and mistakes of recent years. To your lack of self-criticism, to your carts in front of the horse, we say no. Because without a true social Europe, there is no Europe, but there is still no social Europe here.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Mr President, there are those who assert themselves and those who resign themselves, there are the realists and those who play on fears, there are those who work for the future with pragmatism and those who isolate themselves . Believing in Europe is not an option, it is a necessity. But believing is not enough: we must act, because the current geopolitical instability pushes us to reinvent our project. The European Commission is now sketching out different scenarios for the future of Europe. We will take this reflection by your side, with pragmatism and without dogmatism. Dream sellers need to understand this. Here in Parliament, we are working to build a Europe that acts and wins. Brexit will raise awareness. Yes, the negotiations will be difficult, but they must be, because Europe à la carte is not a solution. I have confidence in Michel Barnier to carry out this process, and the British and all Europeans will realize what the UK loses by leaving the European Union. Sixty years after the signing of the Treaty of Rome, a single question must guide our action: what Europe do we really want? Preparing the future of Europe means acting on priorities without naivety for strengthening security and the fight against terrorism, for increased control of our borders, to seek growth where it is found. , abroad, by promoting intelligent trade defense, and for a relaunch of industrial policy. It will take courage to face the lies of all those who dream of the end of Europe. They propose the weakening of our continent and our states, but we are working to strengthen a community of destinies that protects and, above all, is respected in the world.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr President, Mr Juncker, you are right, in the governments of the Member States there is no collective will and it must be pointed out.You are also right when you say that the European Union is not obvious, and you are right to launch a call to rebuild the European consensus.But you are wrong not to show the way, because the enemies of Europe, those who attack our values, are not going to stop, they are not going to wait until the end of our deliberations.Mr Juncker, I therefore suggest that you take action, show the way, have the courage to stamp with the European seal the solutions that citizens expect from us.We need courage.You know, Mr Juncker, melancholy never succeeded in changing things.I found you a little sad.We need courage, you and us, because outside, the citizens are waiting for a reaction.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: - Mr President!Once again I have listened to Mr Juncker's speech;again and again I have been struck by how tiring and repetitive it is with the same old faulty solutions.It is just as if you are unable to put your ear to the ground and listen to what the people of Europe are saying.Half of Europe's population no longer has faith in the EU.You see it in the turnout: 42% of Europe's population last voted.And what is your solution to that?Well, the solution is more EU, more of the same policy, more of the same failure that has taken you here where you are today, when half of Europe's population no longer has faith in the EU.It must be obvious that it no longer works.It must be obvious that new steps are needed.If we continue in this direction, the EU is doomed to fail, in the form we see today.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Juncker. You are right, Mr Juncker, that we are standing at a crossroads, not because of Brexit – which I am very sorry about – but because of a lack of agreement between Union members and because of the unwillingness or inability of many politicians to explain the importance of the Union for the future. So we are in a situation where every kind of future is possible. It will depend on our decision and on the decision of every European. We need to understand the achievements we have made in recent decades. We should also understand the weaknesses that we are now facing and we must be fully aware of the consequences of each decision. By presenting the White Paper, Mr Juncker, you are forcing us to understand what the options at this crossroads are. I believe that this White Paper will help us to decide, correctly and wisely, about our future in developing the joint project of a joint Europe for the good of us all and of our people.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank President Juncker for this White Paper. We need a strong Europe and we need leadership on the challenges of globalisation that no country can deal with by itself. That is clear. We need to harvest the good side of globalisation but we also need to deal with the negative side. We need a solidarity pact between the European Member States and the EU as such, to stop the race to the bottom, for example on tax and corporate taxation. We can see that there is a race to the bottom on tax payment, we can see the EUR 1 trillion cost every year of tax evasion and tax avoidance in Europe: EUR 2000 per citizen per year, money that could be spent to protect our welfare state. We also need to stop the race to the bottom on workers’ rights, decent salaries and decent working conditions. So we need a solidarity pact that can protect the worker in the age of globalisation, and we need leadership on the migration crisis, not only patrolling our EU external borders but also fighting the root causes of migration and the refugee crisis, which is the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, in the times we are living in we need a strong Europe, but we also need to understand that visions are more than institutions. Visions are never about institutions.
