Sometimes I feel that we underestimate how much we have achieved in recent decades: reunification, the single market, what could be the most competitive global economy if we take the right decisions, the fact that we can create financial stability and ensure we have the scientific research that can make us leaders, and the fact we have such a strong political identity that other parts of the world and our neighbours lean towards our values. That is what we are capable of. We have achieved not just unification: we have achieved the opportunities to take decisions. Sometimes I feel that we lack the real political will to take these decisions because we fall into the trap of ever-ongoing discussions about institutions to replace the old institutions. We do, of course, need to discuss the balance of powers, but we can do that only if we put unity before uniformity and accept that Europe’s strength is plurality, openness, the safeguarding of our values and the eagerness and willingness to take political decisions to make the visions come true. That is more important than these discussions about institutions. They are very important, but the vision of a strong Europe is stronger.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President, I have really tried to understand President Juncker’s approach today, but I have to say that I have difficulties. I am not sure if it is the right one. You have spoken about five scenarios, Mr Juncker, and you are actually referring the decision to the national capitals. I know that the Commission does not have the power to discuss levels of integration but I think that, more than ever, we need clear leadership, with vision and concrete proposals. I agree with you that we need a sincere, open dialogue with our citizens and collective motivation but, again, I hope that the way you choose today is the right one. My strong vision is like yours: to have a Europe that is not divided; to have an open and modern Europe, peaceful and with real security and wellbeing for everyone. One thing I would like to say is that the biggest priority for Socialists and Democrats is the asylum system, with genuine reform of the Dublin arrangements, and I do not see that as an absolute priority of this Commission. Also, when we speak about immigration, we need a system truly based on solidarity. We have to go back to a fully restored Schengen and not have border controls: there are no grounds for having them introduced.

name: Viviane REDING
text: - Mr President, I believe that we must choose our path, and as soon as possible. I agree with those who say that arguing, arguing, arguing ... leads nowhere. We must act, and then Europe à la carte, that's enough! The leap that Europe needs can only come from a nucleus of European countries ready to move forward towards a Europe of security, but with common instruments, towards a Europe of peace, with the capacities of common defense and a true Minister of Foreign Affairs, towards a Europe of prosperity, with a budget worthy of the name to invest in youth, in social progress and in digital and energy infrastructures, towards a Europe of freedom, with the conditionality of European funds on respect for Union law and values, and towards a Europe of democracy, with a directly elected president and a Council of Ministers acting by simple majority. To meet these challenges, we must reform Europe around those who have ambition for our Union. So, let's reform Europe with common and concrete actions. The sovereignty of future generations, their ability to decide their own rules and to control their own destiny depends on it.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, each of the first four scenarios you have indicated - Mr President - contains elements of truth. The incremental dynamic triggered by the Lisbon Treaty should not be underestimated, the internal market remains our most powerful lever, differentiated integration is a fundamental tool that already exists, and subsidiarity and proportionality are principles that can and must be implemented better. However, it is clear that only by doing more and together in some key areas will we be able to address the challenges that lie ahead. In particular, it is clear that Economic and Monetary Union must be completed if we are to make it sustainable and a growth factor. For those who share the same currency, reducing unemployment is not an option but a necessity, otherwise those who think that monetary sovereignty must be recovered and devalued will win. Parliament has shown that it can be done on the basis of existing treaties and by maintaining the unity of the Union legal framework and has proposed to trade between enhanced convergence of economic policies and building a fiscal capacity to support investment and shock. We understand that the political moment has advised us to postpone this debate, but it cannot be dropped and the European Parliament will make its voice heard.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: - Mr President, I am speaking on behalf of the social democratic delegations of the already old 'new members' of the European Union. The Commission's assessment, even if it may be technically correct, worries me. The Commission's primary responsibility is to ensure the leadership and direction of the European Union, not to be a think tank. At one of the most dramatic moments in the European Union, reaffirming solidarity between all Member States is imperative. Yes, solidarity, including by preserving a sound cohesion policy. We oppose the idea of ​​a Europe with two or more speeds, which is dangerous, and the time chosen for its presentation is the most inappropriate possible. This proposal can only generate new divisions, concern, frustration and even humiliation, including in companies deeply convinced of the importance of the European project and willing to cooperate loyally and in all forms to strengthen the European Union, such as my country. So, Mr President, do not take this course of action. It can only create new dissensions and tensions between Member States and will certainly have a negative impact on the 2019 European elections which could become a threat to the European project.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, this White Paper, as an analysis of possible scenarios, is certainly better than the report on institutional reform that we recently adopted. Finally, it offers scenarios that are realistic. Let us not lie to citizens that we will provide what we cannot provide, because the European Union does not have the competence to do certain things. After all, the European Union alone cannot provide jobs for all, it cannot provide housing for all, it can guarantee housing for all children and young people. The European Union cannot accept all refugees who want a safe life. The citizens of the European Union understand very well that the European Union simply cannot ensure all this. But they expect the European Union, through its institutions and through the governments of the nation-states, to do what it must do and what it follows from the commitments made by each state. This means that the European Union must ensure the free movement of people, services, goods and, in the event of a threat, protect the security of its citizens and respond to the preparedness of its external borders.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you President Juncker for having wished to present the White Paper on the future of Europe here in the European Parliament. I think this White Paper can help ensure that the Rome Summit is not only an occasion to celebrate 60 years, but also a meeting in which we really talk about the relaunch of Europe. President Juncker said well, the constant criticism of the European Union must be stopped. It is time to relaunch Europe united at 27, do more and do it all together, pursuing the idea of ​​a Europe of great speed and not two speeds. This is the only possible scenario for a possible Union, the best scenario for the future of Europe. This White Paper on the future of the Union will be followed by reports on individual issues: the euro area, the social pillar, the Community budget, the fight against climate change, the stability and growth pact, foreign and security policy, reports from adapt to the type of integration which should then be adopted by the Member States. In short, I really hope - President Juncker - that the White Paper you have presented on the future of the Union can represent the birth certificate of Europe at 27.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, after the old political world of Europe has failed, after it has filled Europe with millions of poor people, after it has filled Europe with armies of the unemployed, after it has turned them into the sea, it is now throwing in the towel, abandoning, and not only that, to the European peoples themselves. Now Mr Juncker has remembered the peoples of Europe and is asking for their views, the peoples of Europe who are constantly insisting that austerity must end, there must be a fair distribution of the wealth produced in Europe, the peoples of Europe demanding debt relief because the Europe has become a Europe of creditors, a Europe where some countries are debtors and some other countries are supposedly creditors, the European peoples who demand respect for democracy, which the troika does not respect in Greece and in other countries. They demand respect for national sovereignty, they demand respect for many things, they demand respect for human rights. So that's what Mr Juncker forgot to tell us. So that is his answer? The people are demanding change in Europe.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Mr President, this White Paper on the future of the European Union starts from wrong premises, starts from a wrong diagnosis of the current situation, which ignores the roots of the crisis and the progressive removal of the people from this integration process. Today, increasingly broad sections of the population and workers in the European Union see a problem and a threat to their income and rights. And this thought does not stem from any subjective assessment - it results from the concrete application of European Union policies, which imposed wage cuts, tax increases, privatizations and the degradation of the social functions of the State on the peoples of Europe. At the same time, this same Europe favors large economic groups, with policies tailored to their interests. Here lies the cause of Euroscepticism, but also the reasons for economic stagnation and the growth of social inequalities. Without recognizing this reality, there will be no White Paper that can solve Europe's problems.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Thank you very much, Mr Tajani. I hope that Mr Juncker also read it, because he lives and dies to get to know the thoughts and attitudes of the people of Europe, so now he can get to know him about migration, because Mr Tajani conveyed exactly what humane Europeans think about refugees and immigration. . There are two pillars, one is that the problem must be tackled at the root, so in, say, Africa, and in the poor poor countries, economic stabilization must be achieved. The other is that those who flee, from war or other imminent danger, should be placed as safe as possible on their own continent, as close as possible to their place of residence, under normal human conditions, with medical care, access to medicines, and so on. I knew right away that some of my fellow Members would be preparing for this. I ask you, why do you react so hysterically, why are you talking about a concentration camp here, why do you want to force multimillion-dollar immigration into Europe at all costs? If they really want security for these wretched people, why don’t they believe this is the good solution that Tajani said?

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, I must say that the debates follow and resemble each other. The debates in the European Parliament are special in that we do not listen to those who have spoken, but read the text that we had prepared. Is this a debate? It's the contrary. So I am not going to repeat myself, because I will not be listened to a second time. You will read, maybe it is easier than listening. To those who think that the Commission has chosen the wrong topic, I will simply answer that in Europe, you should never try to innovate. Too many are the classics, the traditionalists, the reactionaries and the conservatives who do not accept a change of method. We criticized the method that was, that which consisted of proposals from the Commission sometimes considered but never discussed with the general public. Now the Commission is proposing something else: we are submitting to everyone's meditation, including this assembly, various scenarios, which do not all find my approval - you have clearly felt that, among the options we are presenting, there are some one that I like a lot more than the other four. But if we only presented one, we would kill the debate. We are shouting from all the rooftops of Europe that we have to debate, that we have to find our way back to our fellow citizens, our voters - who are citizens and not just voters - and when we do, we do. critical. But "shit!" I would say if we weren't in the European Parliament. What do you want us to do? The Socialist Group - and my friend Gianni, who is no longer there when he is normally present - criticizes the Commission for not saying which option it would prefer. So, I would like all the same, in all friendship, that the Socialist Group, within a fortnight, by identifying those who are for option 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5, send me its opinion on the question. . Don't forget to talk to the prime ministers socialists, don't forget that.You are not Prime Ministers, unfortunately for your countries, but they are and think the opposite of what you say.

name: Antonio TAJANI

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - The lack of momentum for the European project that we perceive in the Commission and especially in the Council is worrying. We come to the anniversary of the Treaty of Rome with a notable lack of ambition and perspective and, above all, of solutions to the real problems of European citizens. At the head of the Union we must work with ambition, precision and determination. The governments of the Member States do not demonstrate the collective will to rebuild consensus, the Union's main engine. It is especially important to consolidate this European political consensus in order to keep the European project viable, after Brexit and the tension with the nationalists / populists. The Commission must continue to lead the way in the process. The white paper on the future of the EU is an insufficient foresight exercise to clearly see what future Europe has and whether it is worth continuing to trust in it. Citizens expect solutions that require action and courage. The white paper does not necessarily collect them, it is a map of theoretical options. In our opinion, the Commission should have established a diagnosis on what is not working in the EU and the Member States show a clear political will to move towards a stronger Europe.

text: in writing.- The European Commission, guardian of the Treaties, presents us with a scenario with five possible hypotheses for the future of Europe.It is now up to the European Parliament, as an expression of the citizens' will, to open a discussion on the basis of these hypotheses, in order to find an answer to the challenges that our Union faces.From our discussions, the Europe we want will have to emerge.The most desirable direction to take by now is that of a multi-speed Europe, a differentiated Europe that advances rapidly and effectively, involving the states that ask for greater integration.This solution has its own logic, the challenges are many and a united Europe, as the first economic power in the world, has an international responsibility that it cannot ignore.However, we must avoid leaving anyone behind, remembering our values: Europe primarily means solidarity.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I support the approach taken by the Commission President and his chosen approach.The White Paper provides the right basis for a broad debate that we must have in the coming months - with the involvement of all parties involved: the European institutions, the national parliaments, the regions and municipalities and civil society as a whole.The five possible scenarios outline different options for where the Union could be in the future.It is clear to me: Europe must be aware that only as a united Europe will it not sink into insignificance;but this cannot mean that all national and cultural differences must be leveled out.In this respect, Juncker's motto remains unchanged: Europe must be strong in big things and take a back seat in small things.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - Today, Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker presented a White Paper with five scenarios for the future of the European Union on how to preserve the unity of the EU-27. Three of the paths or scenarios described would hardly withstand a reality test under the current political framework, while two of them require a closer look: The first scenario, called “Those who want more do more”, outlines a Europe of the willing, which work more closely together in certain policy areas in order to move faster together. A procedure that is already possible today through the instrument of "permanent structured cooperation" provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon. In the second scenario, called “Doing less more efficiently”, the European Union focuses its resources on a selected number of “large”, i.e. H. important topics and leaves others to the member states. One of these topics could, for example, be a common foreign and security policy. In conclusion, it can be said that this White Paper and the debate on the future of the European Union are important and, due to the open-ended approach, encouraging, but that they are coming very late. Tactical considerations in relation to the upcoming election year 2017 are likely to be a major reason for this debate.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written.- In my view, we have exactly one sensible option: strengthening the EU and cooperation.World politics is in a state of instability, and it is certainly not worth Europe now to start weakening itself.European populists have spoken about the possibility of narrowing European cooperation so that only the internal market is left out and political cooperation is curtailed.Under no circumstances should this be done - no, even if one fears populists will succeed in national elections.If politics is stripped of the EU, only the benefit of money will remain.Then, for example, the well-being of people and the environment, consumer protection, the protection of workers, the fight against tax evasion and other very important issues would be left out.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: signed up. - The European Commission's proposals for the future of the EU, contained in a document called the "White Paper", will be decided by the end of the year on the future direction of the Union. The five working scenarios are neither exhaustive nor mutually exclusive, and I believe that the document does not propose a two-speed Europe, as each Member State has the opportunity to integrate or not. This future White Paper will try to introduce some new rules that the Member State may or may not adhere to, thus falling into one category or another. For example, with regard to the security fund set up after the crisis, each Member State had the opportunity to join, which is also the case in Romania. I believe that this White Paper will propose a similar accession mechanism. Last but not least, the European Union is operating with a new qualified majority voting procedure, and around 80% of all EU legislation is adopted through this procedure. This limits the possibility of forming a net division into two categories of Member States.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - The euro area has been in the grip of various economic crises for almost half the time the euro has been in use. The current kind of compromise euro has proved to be an unsustainable experiment. This was already made clear in the report of the five presidents. The changes recommended in it were far-reaching and radical compared to the EU treaties in force so far. The premise that if the euro cannot adapt to the needs of different euro countries, Member States must adapt to the conditions of the euro represents a policy of dictation at the expense of the well-being of the citizens of the euro countries. Recently, Parliament has only been faced with options to advance the federal government. The take-it-or-leave-it situation leads to scenario 1. It has not strengthened Europe, as has been said. Unfortunately, deepening integration has not made Europe stronger either, but deepening integration at the expense of the economy has from time to time reminded me of the Soviet Union. Europe will only be strong if its economy is strong. It may be necessary for some Member States to strengthen their economies themselves through the euro gap. In order to ensure the smooth functioning of the market, economic growth and employment, it is important to create formal channels for those who end up opting out of the euro. This is the only way to guarantee the rapid stabilization of the market and the well-being of Europeans.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – It might make sense to open the discussion about the future of Europe with a discussion about its past, its history. Frequently I get the feeling, in this Parliament and elsewhere, that such discussions too often take exclusively an ideological perspective – that of pilgrims intent on reaching the new Jerusalem. Moreover they get bound to technocratic approaches that are grounded in neo-liberalism. Even the social dimension, when it is included, gets relegated to a policy chapter, calibrated in positivist terms.  Perhaps what we need is a self-critical, historical review of what the European project has been, set in a framework of the realities of European history since the French Revolution. Perhaps what we need is an acknowledgement and examination of the failures as well as the achievements of the European project over the last sixty years – seen not in contingent terms but as strategic responses undertaken in historical time. These need to be reinforced if their outcome was good for the European peoples, and reversed where they have been mistaken. Decisions about the future of Europe must be built on an honest, critical assessment of our recent past. Unfortunately, this terrain has been abandoned to populists and demagogues.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. - The European Union stands after the so-called brexite at the crossroads and we have to decide which way to go. From the point of view of Slovakia's interests, any variant that counts on a two-speed Europe, but also one that presupposes the federalization of the European Union, is inadmissible for us. None of the presented variants is final. In the future, the European Union should focus on a positive agenda that brings concrete results to citizens and businesses. Examples are the Energy Union and the Digital Single Market. The integration of the common market should also be deepened and the compliance mechanism within the euro area strengthened. Europe also needs to face together the current challenges, such as mass migration, the security risks posed by terrorism and Russia's expansion, and the threat of global trade wars. To do this, we need effective and efficient tools in the form of authorities, such as the European Border and Coast Guard and, of course, a consensus on foreign and trade policy issues. On the contrary, both the European Commission and Parliament should completely abandon the field of cultural and ethical issues and unresolved statements and resolutions on various secondary issues. Personally, I am in favor of the combination of variants number one and four. It opens up the possibility for the wide-ranging society-wide discussion that we urgently need. Proper setting of priorities and strict adherence to them can kick-start the European Union and reduce internal friction between Member States.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up. - "Quo vadis Europe of the 27?", Is the question launched today by the President of the Commission in the plenary meeting in Brussels. Presenting the White Paper on the future of the EU, President Juncker reviewed five possible scenarios proposed for public debate: from a deeply politically integrated Union to a two-speed Europe, the nightmare of the eastern states, and to a minimal, reduced Union to the status of free trade area. The expected debate is more than necessary. I believe that the most important stake is to mobilize citizens, to motivate them to take part in consolidating the new EU, which, for the first time in its history, will see one of its members leave. In order to have a future, the EU must regain the trust of its citizens, the European project must become a generator of adhesion, hope and even love. Of the five scenarios, I believe in the materialization of the sixth: the European Union of its citizens. This is a union of regions and communities. Rebuilt in its regions, the EU will become more efficient and able to enhance local economies. By sincerely valuing all its national, ethnic and linguistic communities, the Europe of Communities will truly place the citizen at the center of its reconstruction.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on preparation of the European Council meeting of 9 and 10 March 2017 (2016/3019(RSP)).

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, the 28 Heads of State or Government will be meeting in Brussels next Thursday, 9 March. On Friday, 27 leaders will discuss their own preparations. I know you had intensive discussions last month on the future of Europe, and I am aware of your contributions. Today, however, I will concentrate on what is expected to happen next week. The discussions will focus on citizens’ main concerns, namely growth, external security and migration. Let me take these subjects one by one. The emphasis will be, first and foremost, on economic issues with a number of important subjects featuring under the title Jobs, Growth and Competitiveness. Against the backdrop of the latest forecasts, leaders will have a political discussion on the economic situation in Europe. The outlook overall is positive. The European Council debate will certainly look at how best to use this positive momentum.  The leaders will also touch upon trade. This subject has come to the forefront lately, not least because of recent declarations on the subject by one of our transatlantic partners. It is therefore a good time for Europe to send a clear signal and reaffirm its belief in free and fair trade and the greater good that comes from sharing its benefits. I will take this occasion to thank you for giving your consent to the deal on the EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). It was an important step forward for all of us, and it is crucial for the credibility of the Union. The last element under this economic chapter is the single market. The leaders will look at efforts to deepen the single market in all its dimensions. Together, Parliament and Council have made good headway – most recently concerning the digital single market, with breakthrough agreements on roaming and portability. But a lot remains to be done and, if we are to meet the deadline we have set for ourselves of completing the single market by 2018, there is no time to lose. The second item on the agenda will be external security and defence. This topic was already discussed last December, as leaders are determined that Europe needs to do more for its own security. A new momentum has developed: in March they will want to reinforce that message and ensure that the whole agenda moves forward as quickly as possible. Another topic that leaders are following closely is migration. It was added to the agenda after discussions at the last informal meeting in Malta. The leaders want to review what has been done to implement the decisions taken in February and to keep the pressure high, so that efforts are pooled to tackle the Central Mediterranean route. With the start of spring around the corner, leaders want to avoid any repetition of the tragedies of last year. Of course, in parallel, work continues on all elements of the EU’s comprehensive approach and we will maintain vigilance on other migratory routes. There was also another outcome of the Malta summit. The leaders decided to have a political discussion in March on the Western Balkans. Signs coming from that region in recent months are increasingly worrying. Leaders want to dedicate time to discussing the situation in detail and to send a strong signal of EU commitment to the region. Lastly, the European Council is expected to note the absence of consensus on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office proposal, paving the way for reinforced cooperation on the issue. Thank you very much for your attention. I am looking forward to this debate.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, if you will allow, we would like to share this introduction from our side. Commissioner Avramopoulos will go deeper into the migration issue. But first, we had a very interesting discussion just a little while ago about the future of Europe. It was quite a visionary discussion and next week’s Council will not, hopefully, be as visionary because the purpose of next week’s Council meeting is rather to concentrate on short—term delivery, which is very important from the point of view of our citizens. The first priority for the Commission next week will be to see the meeting of the leaders in the European Council take concrete steps forward to deliver on jobs, growth and competitiveness. Unemployment is still too high across Europe, but it is now at its lowest level since 2009. We are moving in the right direction, but risk persists and we are not yet where we want to be. To continue our good progress, the Commission would like to see the European Council give its support next week to the swift extension of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). This will allow us to keep investing across Europe in projects which stimulate economic growth and create jobs for Europeans. In one and a half years EFSI has already financed projects worth EUR 30 billion, and this is expected to trigger around EUR 170 billion in additional investments throughout Europe.  The European Council will also talk about trade policy, which is another important policy area from the point of view of job creation. We need more rule—based trade. We hope that the European Council will acknowledge the important vote in Parliament on the approval of our progressive trade agreement with Canada and I take this opportunity to praise you for this important decision. Even those in this House who voted against the Agreement with Mr Trudeau’s Canada were quite impressed by his presence. So let me remind you of his words on this issue: ‘We must choose to lead the international economy, not simply be subject to its whims’. You know by now that this Commission does not believe naively in trade. This is why we want the European Council to give political impetus next week to our efforts to equip the Union with modernised tools to tackle unfair trade. When others step back from rule—based trade, the European Union must step forward and we have others, such as Japan, Mexico, Mercosur and India, willing to do likewise and make sure that the rules of the game are the rules which best serve and protect our citizens and our societies. Rule—based trade is the way to govern globalisation and that is why Europe must move on with this agenda.  I would now like to ask Commissioner Avramopoulos to continue on the other subject.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the other topic which Heads of State and Government will need to discuss next week, as Mr Katainen said, is migration. Even if we make progress in the management of the migratory flows, the situation is still very fragile. We all need to be committed to implementing the agreed – I repeat, the agreed – measures and finding a way forward to complete the structural reforms. The credibility of our actions inside the Union, at our borders and in our migration management, is central to building mutual trust and to enabling us to act in a collective way. Our comprehensive European agenda on migration contains elements of solidarity and responsibility. It demands that we take forward each element in parallel with the others. The success of one reinforces the others. In all areas we must both show solidarity and assume responsibility. Now is the moment to prove what we really mean whenever we make reference to this basic principle upon which Europe is built. And the more effectively we work with third-country partners on tackling the root causes of migration, the greater our capacity to ensure a fair and effective system of asylum and migration management here in the European Union. March 2017 will be a month when many people look to Europe’s past, and many people look to Europe’s future. In the Commission, we will make sure that we also shape Europe’s present.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Commissioner, this debate is truly a continuation of the debate we had previously on the future of Europe. In addition, it comes at a crucial and highly symbolic moment since, in this month of March, we are going to celebrate the sixty years of the Treaty of Rome and we should also open the Brexit negotiations, symbol of the crises facing the EU. European Union. Tensions with Russia, terrorism, the war in Syria, the economic crisis, the migration crisis, the new policy of the United States ... The world lives on a volcano which, far from being extinct, can at any time to wake up. In the face of these threats, Europe is a last island of stability which must be preserved. For that, we need to implement a common defense policy, an essential prerequisite for protecting our borders and defending our values ​​in the world. Yet the European Union appears to our fellow citizens less and less as a community, but more and more as a collection of national egoisms. It is high time that the heads of state or government face up to their responsibilities: do we want to continue building Europe or unravel it? This was the subject of the previous debate. In this regard, I congratulate the Maltese Presidency for working hard to push for an ambitious agenda. This is the case, for example, with regard to investments: Mr Vice-President, you spoke of the efforts of the EFSI, the Capital Markets Union, all these investments which should enable us to support the industry and innovation and to create the jobs our citizens demand. I am also pleased that an agreement has been reached on the structural reform support program 2017-2020. This program must now be implemented as quickly as possible because, make no mistake about it, the convergence of our economic, social and fiscal policies is essential for strengthening the euro zone. To this end, it is urgent that fundamental reforms be carried out in many Member States, particularly in France. The euro must be an instrument of European power, but we will not be able to build anything without confidence and without solid economic and social foundations, at the risk of seeing our common home collapse on its foundations. While withdrawal into oneself and protectionism seem to have become the rule since the election of Donald Trump, in particular, Europe must continue to carry, without naivety, a message of openness. Our continent can make the development of trade a formidable economic asset. Europe must be there, the world is watching us. The European Parliament, on behalf of the citizens, must continue to be the driving force to initiate a European leap forward. Do not be fooled, history will show we were right.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I know that there are indicators for blue cards, but I am following the advice of President Tajani and I will not accept blue cards because of time constraints.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, this debate shows that there is a connection between preparing for the European Council and the previous debate on scenarios for Europe. I can see that this European Council is trying to put into practice Scenario 5, namely working together to come up with better European solutions.  This is the case with regard to investment and to completing the single market with the digital and the energy union. This is also the case regarding the need to manage migration and to build up a real European asylum system. This is also the case regarding the trade agreement which was completed with Canada and which paves the way for a new generation of trade agreements, if some new concerns are introduced. This is also the case with regard to defence.  So on this European Council agenda you have many critical issues where we need to deliver better European solutions. Nevertheless, let me underline that when it comes to growth, we really want more of it because the current European Semester clearly shows that there is a limit to the growth strategy we are following in Europe. Up to now we been driven by exports. We have nothing against this, but we feel this is the right moment to bet on domestic demand, which means reducing social inequalities. This is the second source of growth in Europe which should be strengthened.  Then, if this is the case, all these outcomes of the European Council should pave the way for a good declaration at the Rome Summit. Let me underline this: we should not just commemorate the 60th anniversary. We need to use the opportunity to pave the way for the future, which means having a declaration that highlights the importance of the European social pillar and of a real reform of the euro area to deliver upward economic and social convergence, as well the need to come up with a European defence strategy and to make Europe a central entity for cooperation at the level of good trade agreements and good strategic partnerships and support for the multilateral system. So these are the expectations for the Rome Declaration.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, on economic issues businesses need regulatory certainty and economic stability if they are to grow. As the United Kingdom will undoubtedly be leaving the European Union in the next two years or so, and given the intensity and importance of the economic relationship between the UK and its continental neighbours, it is clearly in the interests of both the EU and the UK that the new strategic partnership, based on amicable and sensible arrangements, is agreed as quickly as possible. We start from a position of regulatory equivalence and mutual recognition of standards – maximum continuity and deep mutual market access will therefore be a great economic reassurance on both sides of the Channel. In terms of internal security, it is clearly in the interests of all our nations that the opportunities for cooperation between our police, security and intelligence agencies is maximised. Many of the problems that have been identified following terrorist attacks in recent years concern the workings of security agencies within States, rather than between them. Bilateral and multilateral cooperation between countries has generally been good, and Europol has often played a useful role in this. The United Kingdom has highly effective and internationally respected security and intelligence capabilities. They have proved their value across Europe and beyond, and it is very much in the interest of the EU in particular, as well as the UK, that arrangements are put in place to ensure that these operational relationships are maintained in the years ahead. On defence, while some transatlanticists here suggested EU defence ambitions are about reinforcing NATO, the reality is different. The ambition is for an autonomous military capability and just at the time when the democracies need to be standing together in solidarity, when that great transatlantic security bond of NATO should be revitalised, the EU is pursuing a separate agenda. This is dangerous. Some have suggested that the new US administration was anti-NATO and this underlined the need for some separate agenda. Nothing could be further from reality and the new American President has underlined yet again his strong support for NATO.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, in fact the three topics on the European Council’s agenda – economy, security and what we call the political model – have to be in balance and I think that these three topics have to be a clear priority. As far as the question of security is concerned, let us be honest. What has the European Union achieved in diplomatic terms in recent months and years? How strong and heavyweight a player have we been? I must say that it is not too optimistic and it is a matter of fact that you can hardly be a heavyweight diplomatic force without having defence and military capacity. That is the reality. That is also why we are not present in a number of important negotiations on critical conflict issues, which have had an impact on us, but which we have certain limits in influencing. So in this respect I do not agree with the previous speaker. It is a question of our credibility and I believe that a European defence is necessary to assert true security with goals, means and a strategy. It is crucial that together we pool our political will and capabilities. On the second issue, economics and especially on trade, I agree with Vice—President Katainen that CETA has to be ratified. I also believe that we need necessary and finely-tuned defence mechanisms. But what I believe even more is that we, as a heavyweight in economic terms well beyond our demography, should use that. It is not just a question of negotiating with Japan and other countries at a time when we are at, shall we say, a standstill with the US. Why do we not have our own agenda that we impose on the Americans? Our negotiating position is already influenced by that. There will of course be limits to it and we will have to see. Finally, on migration, this is not the end of it. The migration problem will still be with us for many years to come. I believe that we need a true migration policy that will provide all the incentives and the tools that we need, but at the same time will take into account our own interests and also the specifics of the individual Member States. So I expect that the European Council will deliver on this. To be honest, what the Presidency has told us today is not convincing. It is not an input into the political debate but has rather more technocratic elements.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the European Union and its integration process are in a deep crisis, but it is a crisis that is not cyclical - it takes place before its liberal and deeply anti-democratic matrix. In the face of this undisguised crisis, the next Council will naturally look at the usual solutions designed only to deceive public opinion. However, the peoples of Europe do not want more of the same, they do not want to further deepen the pillars of the militaristic, liberal and federalist European Union. They no longer want an escape to the front that completely ignores the real causes of the current crisis. The White Paper on the future of Europe proposes five scenarios. For us, a sixth is missing, a rupture with this process of neoliberal integration, a rupture that opens the door to the construction of another Europe, at the service of populations and workers, a Europe of cooperation, without CETA, where all peoples be respected in their sovereignty and in their right to decide on their own development model.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, I think we are aware of the very difficult year that the integration project is going to go through, in an already deep crisis, and I have to say that the impression is of a worrying paralysis of the institutions. And I also say this because of the White Paper that has been presented to us today, by the European Commission, which is more of a prospective exercise more worthy of a think tank than of an institution like the European Commission, from which we would have expected us to give some messages and a path and a clearer political bet. This White Paper seems to confirm, in some way, what Mr Juncker already hinted at in the last State of the Union debate: that the Commission is increasingly a secretariat of the Council and has less and less political role, which It is very worrying. Look, we need a clear direction and it is clear that, at the moment, we have a very clear block in the Council of certain directions that we need to take. But we do expect the Commission to give some clear directions: reform of the eurozone, social pillar, democratization. And since in the next Council they are going to talk a lot about immigration, reform in the asylum system and changes in our policies in relation to asylum and immigration that until now have been a real disaster.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, while our farmers are dying with their mouths open, the European Commission informs us that it is hijacking the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development in order to finance the settlement of illegal migrants. You should be ashamed of the 30% of French farmers who earn less than 350 euros per month. Already faced with the abolition of milk quotas as well as unfair international competition, they do not have the same opportunity to benefit from the Commission, from their leaders, who prefer to negotiate free-trade treaties behind their backs. exchange like CETA, which - I remind you - will sign the death warrant for our agriculture. This European Union was supposed to defend security, prosperity and purchasing power. However, this European Union is doing completely the opposite, because the European peoples quite simply want to leave this European Union which is imposing, in a shambles, austerity policies on the Member States. Spain, Portugal and now Italy: all are threatened with financial sanctions if they fail to reduce their debt. In the UK, they said 'yes' to Brexit and, contrary to what so-called experts say, the UK economy is doing much better than elsewhere in Europe, with higher exports and lower unemployment. . The year 2017 will be the final blow to this faltering European Union. In the Netherlands, in France and in Germany, the people will sweep you away for good to finally build a Europe of nations and freedoms.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, thank you very much, the European Council will return to the subject of jobs and employment next week, quoting from the document: 'so that the citizens of the European Union can enjoy economic prosperity and prosperity'. Well, I try to put it mildly, I would not recommend that a single person in the European Union go to, say, a village in eastern Hungary with this text, because we are quite a temperamental people, or at least take out some more serious insurance. So there is no prosperity please nicely, there is no flourishing, let us stop this daydreaming, and what we should finally be doing thirteen years ago, say for my country after joining the European Union, is to show numbers. During these thirteen years, and before that in the accession process, how much European Union money has been pumped into - now I say, regardless of party affiliation - the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, and let’s see if corruption was either the cause or and this money has migrated back to our dear Western friends and various multinational companies, or why has civilization left behind, why so many people live in misery, from public works or in assembly workshops, by tape, in complete uncertainty, for minimal, low, unimaginable wages in Western Europe working? You should finally look at this, not repeat the big texts year after year.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Please do not exceed the time limit, otherwise I will have to answer the floor.Following the example of my predecessors, I would like to inform you that I will not be giving the floor as part of the "blue card" as we have a long delay.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Mr President, it seems to me that major issues have been raised this afternoon and these issues are customarily described as ‘the future of Europe’, but even more significant is the question: what kind of Europe should we be discussing? To my mind, it should be a Europe that is not merely acceptable to the citizens, but responds to their concerns, and in this connection let me ask, as Parliament’s rapporteur: what exactly is happening to the European Citizens’ Initiative? It is after all in the Treaty, in Article 11, and has achieved no success at all. It is a prime instrument for connecting citizens and Europe. The President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, has rightly urged that we should stop Brussels-bashing; in exactly the same way we should stop Member State-bashing. We should be clear. A Europe based on mutual respect, on parity of esteem, is the Europe that works. It follows that the European political system has three components: Brussels, the citizens, and the Member States. They all have legitimate roles to play; they depend on each other. If these basic principles are not observed then the objectives of the March summit – growth, external security, migration – will be that much more difficult to attain.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - The summit conclusions contain two paragraphs on migration.I trust and support your efforts, Commissioner, and if I return to the agreement with Malta, it is urgent to implement it.In particular, we need to improve the humanitarian situation in Libya in close cooperation with the International Refugee Organization and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.Libya must not become a pocket.If war breaks out there, we will witness a new humanitarian catastrophe.And cooperation with Libya's southern neighbors is essential.In this context, let me mention the Western Balkans before the summit.We must not forget the countries along the Western Balkan migrant route.Capacity building needs to be continued, regional cooperation needs to be strengthened.The Union must play a key role in maintaining fragile political stability in the Western Balkans.This is our immediate neighborhood, with many challenges, and that is why the path of European Foreign Minister Federica Mogherini - soon - to the Western Balkans is all the more important.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, on energy union and Nord Stream II, I expect that, instead of meeting Gazprom envoys, the Commission will ensure EU jurisdiction over the project, publish analyses requested by the Council, including from DG Energy, and supports Ukraine and other CEE countries politically. By doing this, the Commission will bring credibility and solidarity back to the concept of energy union.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: - Mr. President, the next European Council delves into the original sins, despite seeing how this unsupportive project is deflated, that European Union of the center and periphery whose neoliberal dogma impoverishes and de-industrializes, creating a Europe of inequality and precariousness. They say they will focus on jobs, growth and competitiveness. We already know it. Job? Precarious, for working poor. And growth and competition from large companies and their income statements. I no longer remember the youth employment plan or those industrialization plans from the beginning of the legislature. They talk about European defense and they lie, because it is a defense subordinated to NATO, that is, to US geopolitical plans. And they speak as if the refugees were a natural catastrophe, preparing mass deportations and even arrests of minors. And then they talk about Trump. And, not content with outsourcing to the Erdogan dictatorship, they intend to outsource to a failed state destroyed by NATO, like Libya. They follow the path of their failure.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have heard a few general phrases from the Commission representative on the issue of immigration. I would like to know something specific about what we are doing with Libya, because the importance of the agreements with Libya was strongly emphasized, but then nothing more was known. In reality, we have, on the one hand, a Sarraj government which is in the hands of the Muslim Brotherhood, that is, the Islamist cartels and, on the other, poor Italy which is unable to do anything with a country of this kind. It is one thing to make pacts and advertise them, perhaps through the European media that are very complacent towards the Commission, but it is another thing to realize these pacts, to give substance to this action that should also protect on the humanitarian level. We do not know where these asylum seekers are, we do not know how they are treated, we do not know what the role of these militias is, we do not know what happens from the ports of Cyrenaica which are certainly not controlled by the Sarraj regime. This is an extremely confused, unclear situation on which the European Commission refuses to give clear answers and to tell the truth, we want to know the truth, what happens in Libya on immigration.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Thank you very much, Mr President, yes, I would like to make a point of order, I would like to raise an agenda item.I understand that, over time, Mr Tajani has banned the use of the blue card option, which is also being followed by the Vice-Presidents, but I understand that, but in this case I find it completely unacceptable that all speakers may exceed five, ten, twenty seconds and even thirty seconds.framework.I came here specifically to hear this debate, and I also wanted to ask people's MPs how they bear the word that they tolerate wordlessly, in addition to the word flowers, that Viktor Orbán will issue visas to thousands and tens of thousands of uncontrolled people in this European Union.But I would add that I do not have this opportunity now, but I would like to ask the President to either keep the times or not.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Mr Szanyi, the second part of your speech was not a point of order.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, on 7 February the European Council decided to extend for three more months the internal border controls of Germany, Austria, Denmark, Norway and Sweden to prevent the entry of illegal immigrants into these countries. With this decision, not only is the Schengen Agreement repealed in practice, but at the same time, injustice and differential treatment between the Member States of the European Union are formalized, I would say, institutionalized. By what logic are the five countries mentioned above more at risk of illegal immigrants than Italy and Greece, which are countries with external borders, are countries of entry into the European Union and where hundreds, if not millions, of illegal immigrants flock? immigrants, not to settle in them, but because they have been pushed to get there by the wrong open border policy implemented by all five countries I mentioned above. So, it is not possible to accept this policy. When the Council takes such decisions on these issues, imagine how it will take decisions on other serious issues, such as growth, defense and security, tackling unemployment and the future of the European Union in general.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The Council will also receive reports on reforms and reform efforts in the countries of the Western Balkans, and it will note that progress has been made and there is still much to be done. But that alone is no longer enough. We have to work very hard, because the road is long and rocky, to reach the people in the countries even during this phase of change. Russia is investing in the Western Balkans, China is doing that, Turkey is doing that, Saudi Arabia is doing that, and people see the mosques and see the services that are being delivered there. And we don't even manage to nail an enamel sign with the European flag on the projects we have created. Instead, we offer the simple baker in Belgrade that we now open Chapter 16. Nobody in Belgrade - except the politicians - knows what chapter 16 is. If we no longer care about the people in the Balkans, because of the long time we need, they will eventually lose a bit of the desire to follow along on the way.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Mister President! Ladies and gentlemen! Today we heard a great and important speech from the President of the Commission, who has finally opened a debate instead of setting a goal and pursuing it regardless of criticism. I believe it is important - an opportunity for the European Union - to make the course corrections that the European Union needs to make. And that's why the ball now rests with the Council. The Council should open exactly this debate at its next meeting, bring it into society, and the Council should draw attention to the fact that Europe has the most varied of opportunities to develop. It is quite remarkable, if you look at the individual options that the President of the Commission has put forward, that there is also the option of saying: in future we should do less, concentrate on what is important and do what is important better than before . After all, from the words of the Commission President that means nothing other than that the European Union has so far been bogged down. She's done way too much, she's done unimportant things, and she hasn't done important things well. We have never heard such a critical speech by the President of the Commission about his own work, about the work of this Commission and the work of this House. It is remarkable that he has kept it and it is up to the Council to speak to the citizens of Europe with the same honesty. Many Thanks.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: -  Mister President!It is unbelievable what we are hearing here today from both the Council and the Commission!Nothing has been achieved.The redistribution does not work.Dublin doesn't work.Schengen doesn't work.Instead, they would now like to present five paths to a new Europe, where we might be able to choose something new.Ladies and gentlemen, can you not imagine why the British left the EU?Because you didn't listen to the people.Because they are afraid of immigration, afraid of immigration.Before what is in store for Europe.Make a policy for the peoples of Europe at last!In the absence of a people in Europe, you speak of citizens and forget about popular sovereignty.Because we as MEPs are first of all obliged to our people, and then to Europe.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr President, gentlemen of the Council, gentlemen of the Commission, I believe that there is a great deal of agreement in this Chamber and throughout Europe on four major urgencies: immigration; in social pillar; in growth and employment; and in European defense, which has been talked about a lot lately. I want to focus on this idea to point out that we are probably facing one of the most critical moments for the defense and security of Europe, but also before an extraordinary opportunity to build this pillar of the European Union in which the founding fathers already thought . My question or my question is to tell you that ... pay attention to the financing of a new security effort, because very probably we are not in a position to tell citizens that it is necessary to cut the budget or social policy to spend on defense. And I think it is time to make a common defense, but it must be done with its own resources that the European Union itself builds at the service of this urgency and this objective. This is an idea that must be considered, because defense is necessary, but with sources and with the European Union's own resources, not with the budget of the Member States.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, the European Council will be held at a time when we do not know what the British have done. So, pending the tabling of the Article 50 instruments, this Spring European Council will, as you said, have to deal with the issue of investment. Beyond the EFSI, I believe that for the European Union, what we also need today is an investment that is maintained in the service of social investment and ecological transition in which the European Union must commit to. In addition, for the first time, this European Council will have to adopt a specific recommendation for the euro zone. In my opinion, this is an absolutely major step forward when looking to improve the coordination of economic policies within this zone. This must become a regular tool in order to be able to steer the economic policies of the Member States in an aggregate manner in the service of investment and employment, rather than an austerity cycle that has lasted too long within the European Union. . At this Council, you will talk about the internal market. On the Capital Markets Union, let's be careful that this project is refocused on the new situation linked to the Brexit debates.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, the topics in the Council next week are really important, from the election of the President for the second half of the term, economic issues, migration and the situation in the Western Balkans. It is good that the eurozone is growing fourteen quarters in a row, unemployment is falling, and GDP is strengthening in all member states, but good news should be accompanied by, say, an agreement on strengthening European security mechanisms. We need a serious integration of security and defense policy. The Union's inability to provide security for its citizens can permanently distance them from common ground and focus exclusively on national solutions. I welcome the Council's debate on escalating tensions in the Western Balkans. The stability of this region depends on the outcome of the confrontation of two processes: the progress of countries on the path to joining the European Union and the processes that threaten this due to interests contrary to the values ​​of European integration. Our support for the first process is crucial. However, what European perspective do we offer these countries? For example, the concept of a Europe of concentric circles would seriously jeopardize the European perspective not only in the candidate countries but also in the newer member states.

name: Seán KELLY
text: –  Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin agus tá áthas orm cúpla focal a rá ar an ábhar so. Looking at the discussion here this afternoon and the topics on the agenda, it is all very positive. We want to create trade, free and fair, complete the single market by 2018, further jobs and growth in the European Union, improve our competitiveness and extend the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which, as Mr Katainen, who has done so much work for it, pointed out, has spent EUR 30 billion generating EUR 170 billion in investment. That is a significant sum and obviously a very positive development. But I would ask the question: what credit does the European Union get for all this good work? I would say, very little. So I think from now on we need to have, alongside everything we do, a communication strategy for our citizens, and also, as President Juncker pointed out, it is time to stop Brussels-bashing. I would say it is time to lash back at the Brussels—bashers. Lash back at the Brussels—bashers. That is very important as well. Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the next Council will need to prioritize employment, growth and competitiveness policies, continuing on the path of progress made so far. We need to revive investment and continue structural reforms to modernize our economies. Within this framework, only responsible but clearly growth-oriented fiscal policies can help to put the current recovery on a more sustainable basis and to promote growth and employment. Equally urgent is a joint defense plan, along with strengthening ties with NATO. In this historical moment, with an America suddenly divided, a significant economic effort by the member states, but not only, towards a community defense would be the tangible sign that the ideals underlying the Union are still strong and shared. I hope that equal cohesion will be shown in the discussion on the route to the Mediterranean, a place where Italy uses energy and resources every day to deal with an emergency that affects all of Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, the meeting of the EU Council is an important occasion for EU leaders to address, firstly, the economic situation in Europe, trade policy, progress made on files related to the single market strategy, as well as the first phase of the 2017 European semester. On migration, leaders will have to review what has been done to implement the decisions taken at the informal summit in Malta on 3 February concerning the central Mediterranean route. Priorities include training, equipping and supporting the Libyan National Coastguard and making further efforts to disrupt the business model of smugglers through enhanced operational action by involving Libya and relevant international partners. Moreover, the Council should assess the implementation of its December 2016 conclusions on external security and defence. In this regard it is clear that something new is necessary. In a challenging geopolitical environment, EU cooperation on external security and defence has to be strengthened. We really need a future defence union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the European Council of 9 and 10 March should take the issue of immigration seriously. At the moment, based on the data provided by the Commission itself, only 9,566 refugees have been relocated from Greece. It is assumed that 66,400 relocations should have been made and completed by next September, ie so far only 1/6 of the relocations have been made. Germany had to take from Italy and Greece with a relocation of 25,094 people. He has received only 2,442, ie not even 10%. Therefore, there must be a decisive settlement on this issue, there must be measures against the states that do not carry out the relocations and at the same time, Mr Avramopoulos, measures must be taken to decongest the Aegean islands. There are 16,500 refugees and illegal immigrants located in Lesvos, Chios, Samos. Something must be done with the decongestion of the Aegean islands.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, we absolutely need to invest in the security and defense of our citizens, but that will only happen if we do so in coordination, within the framework of the common security and defense policy and an internal security strategy. But for that, we need more national resources and an adequate European budget. If the European Council is committed to combating the fiscal jungle and money laundering and terrorist financing by locking in tax havens, onshore and offshore, then Member States can recover substantial assets to invest in our security and defense. A tax on financial transactions would be a decisive step in this direction. As for the immoral attempt to externalize our responsibilities in managing migration and protecting refugees, through the creation of hotspots in Libya, which no one will be able to manage in a destroyed and ungoverned country, for lack of Europe, unless European governments have the courage to ask for an international mandate, invoking self-defense, and have the courage to put boots on the ground - many boots on the ground -, guaranteeing the security and defense of everyone in Libya and of all Libyan territory, and not only in maritime and coastal zone.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there has been plenty of discussion this afternoon about the future and the past. The Commission must also live in the present. Since the Bratislava summit in September we have been working hard to deliver on a unifying set of priority issues. Today President Juncker has again shown his commitment, and the commitment of the whole Commission, to delivery by presenting his White Paper in line with the promise made before this House in his State of the Union speech. Life goes on and our work goes on. The European Union is 60 years young. That means that we are old enough and wise enough not to get distracted from the task at hand today. We are also young enough, energetic enough and enthusiastic enough to make sure we deliver what we promise. Next week’s European Council must be about delivery. Delivery is the most important point on this issue. Europe needs to deliver on migration, deliver on jobs and prosperity, deliver on security, and deliver on all of its agreed priorities. The European Commission will continue to deliver.

name: Ana GOMES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for a useful exchange, which I will convey to the President of the European Council. Let me use these concluding remarks to underline the importance for the European Union, for all of us, of the two principles: responsibility and delivery. The European Council, as is its prerogative, draws the way forward and provides strategic guidance. This is reflected in its conclusions in the form of objectives and deadlines. It is then our responsibility – the responsibility of both the Council and the Parliament – to work together to deliver on this guidance. With your help, with your ideas and with your energy, the Presidency has already been able to deliver on important tasks set by the European Council. I hope there will be many, many more. In the end, this is what matters to citizens, not institutional wins, but responsibility and delivery from the lawmakers. Thank you for your help in achieving that ambition.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI

name: David McALLISTER
text: written. - The European Council will meet in Brussels on March 9th and 10th. The summit participants will deal, among other things, with the situation in the Western Balkans. In the Foreign Affairs Committee, we recently discussed the tense situation in the region intensively. The High Representative Federica Mogherini is traveling to all six countries of the Western Balkans these days. That is a correct sign. This week in the Foreign Affairs Committee we discussed and voted on the European Parliament's reports on Serbia, Macedonia, Montenegro and Kosovo. As different as the countries are, one message is the same in all reports: the Western Balkans must remain a priority of the European Union's foreign policy in the future. These countries are very close to us through many cultural, economic and political connections. Due to its geopolitical location - surrounded by member states of the European Union - we should have a very special interest in positive development in the region. The local people want a stable and peaceful future. This is possible with the European Union.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The European Union will be 60 this year. Brexit does not mean the EU will retire on its 60th birthday. On the contrary, Brexit is a chance for Europe to be renewed. Keep everything that is good and change everything that is bad. Democracy, the market economy The foundations of our modern society are in danger today. They are attacked by populists, nationalists, extremists who, with the ideology of the past, are trying to win votes to achieve their short-term goals. These leaders cut the tree under themselves. They can be winners for hours. But if it disintegrates, Europe cudar world will come, we will become a zone of Russian-Chinese influence. With extreme nationalist forces, we can only lose. Europe's 60th birthday is not the beginning of retirement, on the contrary: we need to issue a new birth certificate to Europe. We need to open a new chapter, where the solution to the problems, the troubles, is not to decide later or to set up another committee to look into the troubles. Europe's new chapter, which is now beginning, must focus exclusively on the well-being and security of the people. All our policies need to be guided by: people live better and are safer. Let us spend the British 'exit' money, EUR 60 billion, to overcome the by-product of globalization: social inequality. We are using it to make the market economy work for everyone, to start growth and to revive the sixty years of the European dream. The European dream that children live better than their parents.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- Europe needs to do much more and be more proactive to protect itself and increase its security.The Council's debate must clearly take forward the issue of defense cooperation, which has progressed well over the last year.Defense co-operation between European countries has so far been modest and hopes are mainly for NATO.Europe itself must make a much greater contribution and seize every opportunity to increase security and defense capabilities, also in the context of the European Union.EU countries, like NATO members, must set a target of 2% of GDP to protect spending.The EU can also support the creation of NATO infrastructure, such as barracks, roads, etc., defense industry cooperation and development, and the creation of Schengen Defense Forces.It is clear that now is the right time to build a well-functioning European defense cooperation.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - The last days preceding the next meeting of the European Council are an important moment for reflection and reflection on what issues should be prioritized and what should be discussed the most. At a time when Europe is facing numerous challenges and problems requiring it to take swift and decisive action, we must also not forget to carefully analyze the sources and causes of the current situation. Lessons should be learned from good decisions, and perhaps even more from less effective ones, and new sources of threats and opportunities should be identified. The approaching 60th anniversary of the Treaties of Rome will be a good occasion for this. In the context of the meeting of the European Council in March, an important topic should of course be the economy, including in particular its further digitization, enabling the improvement of production processes and trade. Care for the development and maintenance of the functioning of the EU single market remains a key issue. It is particularly important to ensure that there is free movement of goods, capital, people and services, not limited by unfair trade practices or non-tariff obstacles. We must also pay attention to the next steps to mitigate the consequences of the migration crisis and work on improving the functioning of the EU's external borders, which is a natural consequence of the abolition of borders between Member States - the EU's external border becomes its only border.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - Security and defense issues have permanently entered the agenda of the European Council summits. Considering today's international situation, that's good. At the moment, it is crucial that the decisions made at the previous summit, especially those concerning the implementation of the Global Strategy or the European Defense Action Plan, are implemented with the full involvement of the member states. It is also important that the EU and its member states function more efficiently within, but also cooperate with NATO. During the last Security Conference in Munich, Federica Mogherini said that 42 joint projects between NATO and the EU had already been undertaken in the last 7 months. This is a step in the right direction. The new American administration also requires Europe to become more involved in the North Atlantic Alliance, which must be accepted with understanding and awareness of the challenges. So you should roll up your sleeves. I also hope that Donald Tusk will be re-elected President of the European Council. Any changes in this position will not stabilize the situation in Europe. In addition, Donald Tusk has demonstrated the leadership that the EU badly needs in these difficult times during his two and a half years in office.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on combating the disappearance of migrant children in Europe (2017/2566 (RSP)).

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, protecting children, especially those in migration, is a top priority of our policies. By securing the future of children, Europe is securing its own future and not only that. Children in migration need to be protected, assisted and offered durable solutions at all stages of migration. We have to ensure that they are not exploited, abused or trafficked. This challenge is becoming even more pressing given that, in 2016, children represented 26% of the arrivals by sea. This is an almost tenfold increase since 2010. Many of them are unaccompanied minors. Moreover, shortly after their arrival in Europe, an increasing number of minors abscond or disappear. In spite of the efforts taken at European and national level, the situation of minors remains unsatisfactory and protection gaps must still be filled. Ensuring adequate assistance, in terms both of material supply, adequate reception and care and of legal information and psycho-social support, is key to building trust and avoiding absconding. The Commission is working on concrete and comprehensive actions to ensure the protection of children in migration. The European Agenda on Migration and the Action Plan on Unaccompanied Minors constitute our starting point. The Commission will also follow up on the conclusions of the 10th European Forum on the Rights of the Child, organised in November 2016, and on the outcome of the recent ‘Lost in Migration’ conference organised by Missing Children Europe in Malta in January. In Greece, the Commission is actively supporting the appointment of a child protection officer in each hotspot. Here, the availability of sufficient dedicated reception facilities remains a challenge both on the islands and on the mainland. Over 1 000 unaccompanied children are still awaiting a shelter placement. EU funding is available under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund to support capacity building, provide relevant infrastructure and develop operational actions in frontline Member States. Additional funding is also available under the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme to improve child protection in migration. In 2017, priorities on combating violence against children and women explicitly include children in migration.
