Funding under the Emergency Support Instrument has also been made available for child protection activities. The European Asylum Support Office (EASO), the European Border and Coast Guard and Europol are also supporting frontline Member States in identifying unaccompanied minors and providing information on relocation. They offer capacity-building activities and collaborate with public security departments for investigations on smuggling and trafficking. Ensuring legal means of transfer is another key aspect to prevent minors absconding and falling into smugglers’ traps. The Dublin system, including transfers and family reunification, and the relocation schemes must work efficiently and fast. All those involved need to collaborate better to implement these procedures smoothly. For the moment, only 205 unaccompanied minors have been relocated from Greece and Italy and, as we all understand, this is unsatisfactory. However, the Commission is working closely with Member States in this respect. It has deployed dedicated teams in frontline Member States to address this matter. Moreover, last year’s proposals to reform the Common European Asylum System aim at strengthening the guarantees available for vulnerable persons, including children. The proposals include provisions on safe accommodation in suitable reception facilities, and prompt and effective guardianship for unaccompanied minors who apply for asylum. In the absence of travel documents, fingerprinting is one of the very few options for identifying a person. For this reason, last year’s reform proposals also aim to lower the minimum age for fingerprinting from 14 to six years old, with a view to reducing the risk of minors going missing. Swift progress on all asylum proposals is now needed in the European Parliament and the Council. If children go missing, they have to be found, and they have to be found fast. Existing instruments to report and record child disappearances must be fully used. The Schengen Information System (SIS) constitutes the only Europe-wide information exchange on missing persons in general. For this system to be useful, missing children must be reported to the police and other relevant responsible authorities. They, in turn, should immediately record the disappearance in the Schengen Information System, attaching photographs and fingerprints and indicating that the child is unaccompanied. Currently the information system stores information on about 100 000 missing persons in 29 European countries, out of which about 65 000 are children. In 2016, 5 687 persons were found on the basis of SIS. In addition, the Commission has recently proposed to improve the information system. For instance, we suggest having a new type of preventive alert for missing unaccompanied children, to be issued in cases when a child is particularly at risk. Better use must also be made of the existing ‘Missing Children’ hotline (116 000). For instance, all reception centre managers should report all cases of children going missing via this hotline. As you can see, many actions are ongoing to protect children better in migration, and the European Union will step up its efforts. The migration crisis has been exploited by ruthless criminal networks, involved in trafficking in human beings, to target the most vulnerable, in particular women and children. It is our duty to protect children. We need to focus on prevention, the quality of care and protection. We must reinforce our fight against the criminals, mobilise and inform public opinion and put pressure on Member States to use all tools available to protect children in migration. Let us live up to the challenge and address it by using all resources in a united and coordinated manner.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his commitment. A real tragedy is unfolding in Europe, which needs urgent and concrete action. More than a year ago, Europol sounded the alarm when tens of thousands of migrant children went missing. They had been trafficked, abused, exploited and exposed. It is happening today in Europe. We are far away from a zero tolerance policy against traffickers and smugglers. With the Intergroup on Children’s Rights in this Parliament, together with Missing Children Europe, we have been at the forefront in putting this emergency at the top of the EU agenda. We call on the police to prioritise missing children, without double standards between European and migrant children. We need effective rules for cross-border cooperation and increased cooperation with Europol, filling the existing gaps. We need to allocate more resources to hotlines, to help report disappearances and build trust with migrant children to prevent them from running away, to make sure children remain in the protection system and to provide them with a safe environment and decent living standards. Children must be registered when entering the European Union and I support the Commissioner’s reform proposal for EURODAC, moving to take fingerprints from the age of six, to be able to protect them and to trace them. Member States need also to increase their interoperability between the Schengen and the Visa Information System and, as we revise the asylum package, we cannot sacrifice children. Europe should mean safety for them. What if it was our child missing?

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - The tens of thousands of lost migrant children we are talking about today are the fault of criminal gangs and not a functioning European Union asylum policy. We have strict and binding rules for members when dealing with asylum seekers, especially unaccompanied children. But this is true in theory. In practice, the system does not work. We have a very poor exchange of information, dissenting opinions on how to modernize the asylum system. The method of treating unaccompanied children is not uniform across countries. Some countries do not even have an institution responsible for these children. There is real confusion in all these areas. With the implementation of the Dublin Regulation, we are sending helpless children around Europe here and there as packages. Measures that should protect minors, provide them with security, which is why they came to our soil, actually drive them to flee. They force them to disappear, disappear. Open a newspaper or the internet. For the last two years, the same stories have been written about this issue. However, there is still no step forward at Union level. Why is there no action plan? Why are minors not a priority? And the oral question of my colleagues is precise enough. That is why I also expect more precise answers. Above all, I demand a plan to rescue these children and its consistent implementation.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Thanks.More than 10,000 children disappeared from reception centers after entering Europe with the influx of migrants, according to Europol data.In 2016, more than 13,000 unaccompanied minors arrived in Italy alone.Many have traveled a very dangerous road on the North Africa-Europe route.How do we protect these children?How do we prevent these children from becoming safe victims of trafficking, including organs, sexual exploitation, abuse?We can do this in several ways: through emergency numbers, through measures to reunite families, qualified staff in reception centers and also the collection of biometric data from the youngest age, starting at six years old, asalso proposes a Commissioner in the Europol Regulation.It is very important to find these children because this is the only way we can bring them back safely.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Commissioner, I welcome all the words you have spoken here. But I would like to see action. A year ago, Europol already issued the figure of 10,000 missing in Europe. Today Child Focus Belgium announces that 116 new files have been opened in Belgium. Last week I was visiting Dunkirk, a two-hour drive from Brussels. I would like to invite you to come and have a look at the French relief camp there. One hundred unaccompanied minor asylum seekers are in wooden shacks, without care, without education and without seeing anyone to submit an asylum application. That's the Europe of 2017! We must not tolerate that. I am officially asking you for a real action plan with good reception and short procedures. In doing so, a real effort must be made to combat human smugglers and to ensure the exchange of good practices. Where children sit, authorities must take photos so that they do not send an e-mail if a child is missing after 8 or 9 days. You know, Commissioner, if my dog ​​does not come home tonight, I will search harder for my dog ​​than Europe is looking for the 10 000 missing children. Come up with that action plan. I am happy to bring you the recommendations of the conference in Malta. I was there myself and I want to hand them over to you personally. It contains very concrete things!

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, excuse me, but I think everything I'm hearing here right now seems incredible. It seems that now you are very concerned about migrant minors, but you do not think of minors when they build fences, when they close borders, when they deny visas, when they open detention centers or when they sign agreements with Turkey, Afghanistan or Libya and feed the mafias . And everything that happens with minors is the result of those policies that you do not question. A good example of the consequences that these policies have for minors is the situation in Melilla. There are hundreds of minors trapped there - some in centers; others, many, in the street, without schooling — and the Government of Spain can think of nothing else to solve this situation than to negotiate an agreement with the Kingdom of Morocco to deport them, to deport the minors. This does not solve anything, what it does is send the problem away so that it does not bother us.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I think we are all agreed that we need a joined-up system that is going to protect children and ensure that their best interests are at the heart of what we do. We know that we need to develop a system that youngsters trust and will engage with, and that protects them, informs them properly, has effective legal guardians and will cooperate across borders where necessary. We know that we need governments to step up, and indeed to step in, to help those countries under particular pressure. As the Commissioner said, the offers are pretty poor at the moment and even those offers made are not always taken up. So I think we need to think seriously about how we improve that. But we do need, as others have said, a system that works in reality. It is no surprise that kids will believe smugglers’ promises to reunite them with family when we see the reality of what many of those minors currently face and the lack of information they get. We only have to look at the scandal of Calais in terms of child protection: children identified there by civil society organisations, not the authorities, a Supreme Court judgment to remind the British Government of their obligations, a totally inadequate system of cooperation and transfer between France and the UK, and still poor delivery even now. The French are closing the centres that they took unaccompanied minors to and the British Government thinks it has done its job, although there are still at least 1 000 who have, potentially, the legal right to be there under Dublin. So we really do need to make our system start working. I look forward to the infringement proceedings that I hope the Commission will bring against Member States. (Applause)

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the United Nations Refugee Agency estimates that 35% of migrants entering the European Union since January 2016 were children. In 2015, 85 482 unaccompanied minors applied for asylum in the EU, which was three times the 2014 figure. Now it seems that thousands of these children have gone missing, their fate unknown.  Are we to believe these children were sent abroad unaccompanied? Are we to believe that in a single year 85 000 minors made their own decision to make their way to Europe entirely on their own? Of course not. They were trafficked by criminal gangs, but someone had to pay the gang first and, presumably, that was their parents or families. The EU Schengen Area and open borders policy has helped to create an immigration and asylum racket: get the children in first and then the families can follow. The innocent victims of this racket are the children themselves.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe should help children fleeing war, but it does not and I wonder: it does not do so out of incapacity or complicity; is he incapable or accomplice of the delinquents, of the traffickers of human beings who organize death journeys? Why does the European Union let hundreds of children die in the Mediterranean every year? Because humanitarian corridors are not created to welcome real refugees to Europe in a legal and safe way, thus avoiding the arrival of many illegal immigrants who are exploited by the underworld for the drug trade, child prostitution and organ trafficking ? Every day in Italy 28 unaccompanied minors disappear. The Penelope association came here to Parliament to ask us to tackle the phenomenon of thousands of missing unaccompanied minors at European level. This association, which in Italy does an extraordinary job and helps families and missing persons, has also come to ask for help, our help, for the 1,600 minors, missing Italian citizens. Let us not forget these children - 1 600 - who are European citizens and who have disappeared into thin air.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: - Mr President, the situation is alarming. Unicef ​​has indicated that, in 2015, 96,000 unaccompanied minors applied for asylum - 20% of all children - and Europol estimates that 27% of the million migrants who arrived in Europe in 2015 were minors. We have to face this drama together: the Union and each of the Member States. First of all, we must search for the missing minors, since many are being exposed to all kinds of mistreatment by criminal gangs and are being victims of sexual exploitation. In addition, we must take responsibility, since many of them have disappeared while in European reception centers. Children, feeling unprotected and unsafe, decide to flee, and that is when they can easily fall into the hands of organized crime. To avoid these facts, the reform of the Reception Conditions Directive is necessary: ​​it is essential. In relocation, it is urgent that minors are cared for and relocated and resettled, and quickly, especially those from Greece and Italy. And I want to ask for special protection for children with babies, girls and boys who have been parents, and for those I ask for special protection. And also the assignment of the tutor is urgent: a non-deferred assignment, an immediate assignment.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank Commissioner Avramopoulos for his statements. The data cited by the Commissioner, such as the data published yesterday by UNICEF on missing children, demonstrate the gravity of the situation and highlight the need to implement an overall strategy at European level, based on the principle of the best interests of the child. The European institutions must therefore strive to ensure coherence between all the proposals that constitute the reform of the asylum system, and I am referring in particular to the proposal for the revision of the Dublin regulation which maintains, even for minors, the criterion of the responsibility of the country of first landing, with the risk of indirectly pushing minors to undertake secondary movements to clandestinely move to the member country in which they wish to apply for asylum. As was said at the "Lost in migration" conference held in Malta, in order to protect minors on European territory, we must ensure that they can apply for asylum in the State where, possibly, a person with family ties. And if, in order to protect minors, the proposal included in the Eurodac system to introduce biometric data for minors is appreciable, even from the age of six, it is however necessary that this happens in the presence of adequate guarantees, with specialized personnel and with all the necessary precautions to avoid trauma to children. And it is essential to transmit trust to migrant children, to ensure them dignified reception conditions, to assign each child an adequately trained guardian who evaluates what is best for him and to promote initiatives that favor their integration in the long term.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: -  Sir. Chairman! Unfortunately, it is as predictable as it is terrible that it is the weakest, namely the children, who are hardest hit when one sees the asylum chaos that has been created in these years in Europe. The solution is as logical as it has been difficult for the EU countries to come up with, namely that it is about tackling the root of the problem, ie that we are able to remedy the mechanisms that enable human traffickers to make a gold-rimmed business by abusing people's hopes of coming to Europe, including abusing children - some of the most horrible things imaginable. So it is not a question of everyone in this House thinking that it is horrible when children are abused, even in this context. The question is how we can remedy this problem most effectively, and here it is thus about remedying the factors that enable human traffickers to create this business model. Finally, we must also remember to screen the oldest of the children, because we see at least in Denmark lots of cases where adults claim to be children and among other things enter the asylum facilities for children and abuse the smaller, unaccompanied refugee children. It is also an issue that needs to be addressed in this context.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, we are going in circles. Exactly one year ago, Europol informed us of the disappearance of 10,000 migrant children, and everyone was scandalized by these disappearances, although we have been denouncing this for years. Is. Today, a year later, we are still here to debate and to re-debate. However, solutions exist to protect these children. We know them and, Commissioner, you recalled them: immediate identification, registration, immediate appointment of a guardian, shelter and free telephone number. These are rather simple measures and let us remember that we are talking, roughly speaking, of 90,000 children compared to a Europe of half a billion citizens. But you have to want these measures and want to put them in place. Commissioner, today I am not going to denounce the Commission's inaction at all, on the contrary. But basically, it is not here, in this forum, that we should debate, but rather in the heart of national parliaments, because it is the States which fish and which, as in many other areas, are sorely lacking in political will and wield hypocrisy by failing to respect European commitments and legislation. Let’s stop blaming Europe for what it cannot do. Be our spokesperson, Commissioner, to put the Member States up to the wall. It is a scandal for these children and a shame for the citizens of Europe.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it is our duty, he said, but I have to say that they are failing miserably. And those responsible have first and last names: they are the Member States and their policies that, as almost always, are absent from this debate. Unaccompanied minors are suffering physical and sexual violence and threats. And this favors the mafias and their trafficking networks, for example, in Hungary, Bulgaria or Croatia, according to Save the Children. But they also suffer violence at the hands of the police and the military, and it must also be said. In Europe there are temporary prisons for these children, who continue to be subjected to hot returns. And if many prefer the streets to the camps, it is for fear of violence or of being deported. Let's not forget that their families have sold everything they have so that they can travel and have a chance, with the psychological pressure that this entails. Ladies and gentlemen, minors are the most vulnerable, and many are being treated violently in Europe. What has been done and what has not been done so far is shameful, and they do not even have common procedures for identifying and tracking these minors yet.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Mr President! The discussion about children and especially unaccompanied children has been wrong from the beginning. I can understand that many of you have got the wrong picture. Often when talking about migration and children, the media finds a picture of a small child, often a girl, a picture that indirectly says that the child has disappeared from his parents during the flight to Europe. Of course, the picture is different. If there is any country that is aware of the phenomenon of unaccompanied children, it is us in Sweden. We received 35,000 in 2015. The reason why unaccompanied minors chose Sweden is, of course, twofold: welfare and age tests. Sweden has still not started any mandatory age tests for asylum seekers. What if there is a large group that deliberately deviates to get to the country they wanted to from the beginning instead? What if it is a group where most people claim to be seventeen years old and then magically have a wife and children when they get their asylum application granted?

name: Мария Габриел (PPE).
text: - Mr President, according to the latest figures from the UN High Commissioner, one in four asylum seekers is a child. We all quote the staggering figure of over ten thousand migrant children who have disappeared in Europe. However, the exact number of missing children remains unknown. Most of the cases are unreported due to the lack of a central register. This leads to the creation of incorrect data. There is a real need to share information at European level so that it is accessible to all Member States. Second, prevention is a key word. The prevention of cases of missing migrant children must be at the heart of the European Union's migration policy. Prolonged administrative procedures, lack of information and trust in local authorities, inappropriate reception conditions, as well as the practice of detention are just some of the factors that contribute to cases of disappearance. Concrete efforts are needed in this direction to prevent these children from falling victim to criminal networks and traffickers, to prevent cases of re-disappearances. Congratulations on your efforts, Commissioner! Issues such as reception conditions, the role of Frontex, Eurodac, all this is a significant step forward. We must all approach these files responsibly in order to ensure that a safe environment is provided for migrant children, as well as an improved monitoring system to ensure effective protection.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! Almost a year ago we discussed this issue here very emotionally, and they are still there, the missing children. That should actually make you nervous, Commissioner Avramopoulos - in the interests of children and young people, but also in the interests of security in Europe. If I were you, I would also wonder whether it might also have something to do with the fact that the resettlement process from Greece has still not got underway and that thousands of children are still stuck with nothing to lose and are becoming quite a few Victims of criminal gangs. I would not only think about how the relocation process can be accelerated, but above all how the conditions for the children can be improved in the meantime. I've seen the conditions in Greek refugee camps and I can't get these images out of my head. We should do everything we can not to leave the children alone. We need this much-cited action plan, otherwise we will be discussing exactly the same thing again next year, and we shouldn't really be.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen!I'm glad to speak.Unfortunately, my previous speech had to be canceled because I was sitting in your seat.We are talking about drama, human drama, because the disappearance of a child is a tragedy for every parent.I have three children myself, and I think most of us are well aware of the drama and the size of this drama.It seems to me that the more we should try to invest the financial resources of individual Member States, and also of the European Union, in the countries from which these people are leaving.I think that the greater the investments and improvement of people's living standards outside Europe, the less such tragedies on the old continent, our continent.I think it is worthwhile to echo this in this discussion.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, it has to be said that the main task of the Member States is to look after missing children who are in their areas. First of all, that is their main task, their competence. Officially, the European Commission does not even have the authority to do so, because the Lisbon Treaty does not provide for that. If there are problems in accommodation in Belgium, the state of Belgium and its government have the obligation, just like in Germany or France. But I have specific requests in the areas where I believe we can do something, particularly in the area of ​​hotspots, where most of the unaccompanied minors arrive. Would it be a possibility, Commissioner, for us to create separate units within Frontex and EASO to take care of unaccompanied minors on arrival, and perhaps also to set up our own contingent of staff to encourage the respective local authorities to To accommodate unaccompanied minors separately from the start, if possible, to provide them with separate support, and perhaps also partly with the support of European funds? A second request: although there are units in Europol to combat trafficking in human beings, units to combat forced prostitution, enslavement and the like, there are no specific or insufficient staff to deal with the issue of children who have disappeared or children at risk can. Would it be possible to specifically increase Europol in these areas in order to be able to take specific and quick concrete steps on our part?

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, while the European Asylum System pays special attention to unaccompanied children and juveniles, the Hungarian government would further tighten refugee laws. As part of this, legislation is being drafted that would exclude unaccompanied children and young people between the ages of 14 and 18 from the scope of the Child Protection Act. This means that these children are not placed in children's homes, they are not given a guardian, special protection. The proposal also stipulates that minors would also be automatically detained and would have to wait for the asylum procedure to end in container camps to be set up in the transit zone. This draft does not comply in any way with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, violates the constitutional obligation of the Hungarian state and the principle of protection arising from humanity. Here and now, I call the attention of the European Parliament and the Commission to another inhumane measure by the Hungarian Government. I am convinced that it is our moral obligation to do everything we can to ensure that this proposal never becomes an actual law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, children are the biggest victims of the refugee crisis. More than 89,000 unaccompanied children came to Europe in 2015 and 10,000 refugee children have disappeared, according to Europol. There are many cases of unaccompanied children being trafficked, abused and exploited in Turkey. It is estimated that in Greece, about 40% of the refugees in the country are children. I want to return, Mr Avramopoulos, to the issue of decongestion in the Aegean islands, because, according to figures, of the 16,500 people on the islands, at least 40% are children. I remind you of the answer you gave me a few days ago on this issue, when you said that vulnerable groups can now go to mainland Greece, and please see this issue immediately because it is very important. It is necessary for these people, these unaccompanied children, to be able to go to mainland Greece and not be crowded in the Aegean islands. An immediate solution can be given to the decongestion of the Aegean islands by 40%.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to give a concrete example, because I have listened to the words of the Commissioner well. When the most vulnerable people, which are children, arrive in a Member State in Europe, what are they? I am a number, that number disappears, that number cannot be found anymore. In hotspots when they are registered, before registration, we must give them immediate protection. Why not delete this number which, in my view, is a shame and immediately give them a protection card? Because they are rights holders. Then: elimination of transfers, because from one transfer to another in the Member States we must reduce them to a minimum, precisely only in the best interests of the child, because between one transfer and another they can be lost, they are children who when they arrive in the State member have already been abused, raped, we have really seen them in terrible conditions. The last, and I say it, no to transfers and an important economic commitment, because protection requires an economic commitment, if there is no money, there are not even safeguards.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, already on September 12, 2013, we voted for a resolution condemning the gaps in the protection of unaccompanied minors within the Union and denouncing the often deplorable reception conditions for these minors as well as the numerous violations of their fundamental rights in certain Member States. Four years later, 10,000 minors have disappeared according to Europol. It is a horrible record and a collective bankruptcy. Unaccompanied minors constitute one of the most vulnerable populations and, yet, their rights are violated upon their arrival in Europe, with the detention, the slowness of the procedures and the family reunifications which do not take place, all of which are reasons for them. encourage people to flee at the risk of falling into the hands of traffickers. We can prevent this, including by stopping transfers of minors under the Dublin Regulation, banning the detention of minors or relocating those who have arrived. For this, we must put the best interests of the child back at the center of the process, and I regret to say that resuming transfers to Greece is not a good way forward, because this principle will have an impact. directly on minors, whose reception conditions remain unacceptable, especially in countries of first entry.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Canada is an example and a reference in the world in the treatment of refugee minors and, particularly, accompanied minors. Why isn't the European Union? Just yesterday we held a very intense hearing in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in which we were able to hear heartbreaking testimonies, but also proposals for responses to the problem of unaccompanied minors in the European Union. What does the Commission expect to demand these responses from the Member States? We debated this matter here in April last year, we voted on it and heard from the Commission the commitment to bring here a specific plan of measures in the face of the drama, the tragedy of unaccompanied minors. We are still waiting for it. We are reforming the European asylum system; This is where we have to frame the reform of the Reception Directive and reception procedures and the procedures for the protection of unaccompanied minors so that, once and for all, the European Union lives up to what it promises and gives a response that is a measure of their height, of their moral stature in the face of that tragedy of 10,000 missing children in the European Union - according to Interpol - but, above all, of 20% of unaccompanied minors, of all minors who they demand refuge, being as they are the most vulnerable link in the chain of refuge, but also of the exploitation of people.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, we all agree that children are the most vulnerable, the most innocent victims in the wave of migrants who have come to Europe.And Europe should show that it is aware of its responsibilities and can defend the best interests of the child.So what is the solution?Many of you have already talked about this here.Children must be identified, they must receive the protection and care they need.I think that none of us will regret the means to implement these measures.There is a need to allocate proper financial resources as well as staff capacity.We have no restrictions on that.I would like to call on you, Commissioner, to be aware that you have our full support for all legislative and financial measures for fingerprinting, identifying children and providing financial security for facilities where children will be adequately cared for.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unaccompanied minors arriving in Europe along the central Mediterranean route are victims of violence of all kinds, they are the category most at risk. According to the recently published UNICEF report "A deadly journey for children", of the 181,000 migrants and refugees who arrived in Italy, about 30% are minors and nine out of ten of them arrived on the Italian coast unaccompanied. Furthermore, of the 4 579 migrants estimated to have died while crossing the Mediterranean in 2016, 700 are believed to be minors. Europol reported that at least 10,000 migrant and refugee children went missing in Europe in 2016; many of these minors are enrolled in the world of petty crime where they suffer various types of exploitation. These are the numbers of an Odyssey. It is necessary and urgent to put in place a global strategy to protect all migrant children, as announced in the European migration agenda; unaccompanied minors must be protected and protected against all threats. This must be a top priority for Europe, we also make Europe like that.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the disappearance of migrant children in Europe in the 21st century is a scandalous phenomenon that we should really be ashamed of.Guaranteeing the safety of those we choose to receive is our duty and this horrible phenomenon is another indication that we have bitten more than we can chew.Tolerating illegal migration on a huge scale has led to this shameful problem, and without a serious revision of our immigration and asylum policy, it will not be solved.Illegal migrants are brought to our territory by criminals, human smugglers.The more open we are to this kind of migration, the more people want to come that way, and smugglers ’business is booming.What is often overlooked is that criminals have their partners in Europe, so some migrants, who are unprotected and easy prey, are only passed on to them for other criminal activities.Let's put an end to illegal migration and solve this problem once and for all.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, this statement was essential if we take into account that Europol put figures to measure the problem: 10,000 unaccompanied minors disappeared in 2015. It means that at some point there was evidence of where they were and who they were, but the worst is how little we know about what happens to them and how much, sad and serious, that we can imagine. If asylum seekers are already vulnerable, minors, women and other groups with special needs remind us of the intensity of a drama that now needs urgent measures. Trafficking in human beings, which "hunts" among desperate people and uses new technologies to find its victims, is best fought with police and judicial cooperation, the definition of a specific crime, and special attention at the points of entry, with a quick assignment of tutorials and insertion in integration programs. But we need, Commissioner, to know where these children are and we need to demand that the Member States cooperate in these policies.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, I thank the Commissioner for his contribution to the debate. First of all, I am upset that we are repeating a debate that took place a year ago, which shows that, unfortunately, we have achieved very little. I will avoid saying that we must stop the causes that create the problem, namely the wars, because it will sound earlier. We are already facing the problem and this is what we have to face. I support all the proposals that have been heard because they are moving in the right direction. I would like to emphasize in particular the proposal to discuss the issue in the national parliaments as well. Member States must assume their responsibilities. Finally, I want to say something that has not been said so far: the media must open the eyes of the people. They need to have this issue on their agenda so that any useful information is given where it should be.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the number of what we call unaccompanied minors has reached a record of more than 95 000 last year. Those children are at serious risk of abuse, trafficking and exploitation, and they experience dramatic situations on a daily basis. It is not a question of money. It is a question of political will. We are dealing with human beings, and the most vulnerable of human beings, children. We should not be lecturing other countries about human rights whilst we let this happen on our own continent. Beyond the issues of relocation and procedure we must have put in place mechanisms to support and heal children who very often experience immense suffering and trauma, often resulting in serious mental health issues. This must be done by taking into account the special needs of children with disabilities, and young women and girls, and we must also give these children access to education. It is a human right.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, we have listened to your spurious concerns and priorities and the security intentions to resolve this dire reality. We note how they shake off the responsibility for violating children's rights, a violation that adds to the many human rights violations that today occur on European soil and that result from your criminal immigration policies. Let us discuss the causes of this scourge. We discussed how the Dublin Regulation and the objectives of your ongoing review of the asylum system disregards and impedes the right to reunification and family life. Let us talk about how your wall, externalization, return and repulsion policies feed the networks of human trafficking and the sexual exploitation of women and children. We reject your security hysteria, which favors identification, the collection of typing data since the age of six and even detention, imagine yourself, rather than guaranteeing the fulfillment of the child's fundamental rights to protection and integration. Be ashamed, Mr Avramopoulos.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, in January 2016 Europol revealed that at least 10 000 migrant and refugee children were missing in Europe. This is a terrible drama, a terrible strategy, and very difficult to explain. It is clear that Europe has to act to tackle the disappearance of migrant children with every possible means and as soon as possible. I believe the Commission should inform us when it is going to present a comprehensive strategy to protect all children in migration, as announced last May in the European agenda on migration, and how it will address the clear conclusions and recommendations made during the 10th European Forum on the Rights of the Child and the ‘Lost in Migration’ Conference in Malta. Moreover, I would like to know what the Commission is doing to support Member States in relocating more children from Greece and Italy.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the increase in the disappearance of migrant children within the Union shows the degree of decay of Western European culture. At the same time it reveals the culture and mentality of most of the extremist Muslim secular view, where women and children are exploitable products. Hundreds of pieces of evidence and evidence show that missing children are victims of child slavery and organ trafficking. Human life produces money and human dignity is redeemed. Traffickers, a number of NGO workers, participate in an international network that is growing in size due to the non-existence, tolerance and incompetence of civilized Europe. The only solution is full national control of the external borders, where children will receive the appropriate protection and where the various clerics and Muslim parents who abandon their children will be punished by example.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, since Europe revealed it in January 2016, that by then 10 000 migrant and refugee children had already disappeared on European soil, which the Commission and the Council did to protect these children and many more unaccompanied than arrive in Europe and prevent them from falling into the hands of human traffickers, predators of all kinds and criminal networks, including terrorists? In Sweden, a few months ago, policemen sadly told us that if a Swedish child disappeared, they would revolve the country - but if he was a migrant or refugee, there was no way. What Europe is this, in which, for everything, our leaders invoke security reasons, but fail in it, failing in the relocation and family reunification of refugees, including asylum seekers, including minors, dragging processes for the appointment of tutors, access to education, legal, specialized counseling and psychological support, returning Afghan children to their origin, on the pretext that they come from a "safe country"? In fact, in this way, the sinister business of the traffickers is fed and our collective security is jeopardized.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, children must be protected no matter what country they live in, so can refugee children. If the figure is true, 35% of incoming migrants are unaccompanied children, the number is huge. How do these unaccompanied children end up? Here I think we need to look for the cause and then the solutions. We must always go to court. It is hard to believe that the minors decided to leave without their parents. In fact, child trafficking seems to be much safer, child trafficking without parents. Commissioner, I think we need to act on two levels. The first plan is for the Member States and the Commission to find solutions to protect children arriving in Europe, but the other is to do something to stop conflicts. And I ask you directly, Commissioner, that there is currently a collaboration between the international institutions UN, UNICEF, the European Commission, the International Red Cross, the Member States, local organizations, because otherwise the case will not be resolved and we still have a flow. of children who come unsafe and are trafficked. Thanks.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks for your contribution to this debate and for your interventions that call for actions to protect children. A few of you, I believe, did not hear my introductory remarks, but most of you were here, and I believe that the common conclusion is that we share the same concerns and objectives. I can assure you that the Commission is working on concrete and comprehensive actions to protect children in migration and offer them a future.  Tomorrow the Commission will adopt a package of reports that show that all actions are interlinked. Relocation – and this was underlined by some of you earlier – is the key solidarity measures also for migrant children, and I agree with you that that this situation is unsatisfactory. All migrants eligible in Greece and in Italy should be relocated before September. It is a deadline for all Member States, and I believe that all of them will take up their responsibilities and will move swiftly to the implementation of this relocation scheme. Relocation of unaccompanied minors should increase as a matter of absolute priority for us and for all of us. I said at the beginning that detention is a tool of last resort that should not be excluded per se, but only used in cases where it is in the best interest of the child.  Let me stress that the European legislation requires Member States to place minor migrants only in specialised detention centres that are adapted for migrants so that they have access to leisure activities. Sometimes, as I said before, this is for their own protection because let us be clear: the reality out there on the ground is not ideal. We have to prevent minors falling into the hands of unscrupulous smugglers and traffickers that wait outside open detention centres, so closed centres can be appropriate in some cases.  Some of you, like me, have been visiting these places. Children are the easiest victims of smugglers and traffickers. Colleagues, our primary, common goal is to protect children and I would like also to call on NGOs with expertise to support the authorities of Member States under pressure even more. The protection of children of course needs to be regulated, but it is the responsibility of our societies, of all of us as a whole, and the Commission has taken the lead on that but, as was said very correctly before, Member States should take their share and I fully agree with the proposal to sensitise and mobilise your colleagues in the national parliaments. We have to address this issue together, united, and I do not think there is one person among you, or among the Members of the Commission or among your colleagues in the national parliaments, that does not share our determination, our commitment, to safeguard and support this vulnerable group of the migrants that have decided to cross rough seas, fire, dictatorships, difficulties and dangers in order to come to Europe. It is our duty and it remains, as I said before, our top priority to address this very, very sensitive issue.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you for that final declaration you made.Please note that we were talking about children.We have never talked about a child's smile, a child's joy or something else entirely.Therefore, we are awaiting concrete steps.I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. –  The scale of disappearance of migrant children is absolutely shocking. Research by Missing Children Europe estimates that up to 50% of unaccompanied children in certain reception centres in the EU go missing. We are told by Europol that there is a ‘tremendous amount of crossover’ between smugglers smuggling refugees across borders and gangs ensnaring people for forced sexual and labour exploitation. Yet the issue is not confined to the country of origin. If a child is abducted in Spain, they could easily travel as far as Sweden or any of a dozen countries without them or their kidnappers ever being subject to a passport check. The opportunity to catch the perpetrators is lost, and the problem is incredibly difficult to tackle when we do not even know which country a criminal or victim is in. If the European Union truly cares about security, it will rethink the Schengen Agreement, which leads to the unrestricted freedom of movement of traffickers and their victims.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – When historians look back at the migration crisis, there will be many things that they will say Europe should have done differently. Fifty per cent of all children who arrive at reception centres in Europe go missing, the majority of them lost within the first 48 hours of arrival.  These minors, who have very often been separated intentionally from their family members by traffickers, are often subjected to kidnapping, sexual exploitation, slavery, the tracking of organs, prostitution and even forced drug smuggling. This is not the life for a child. This has resulted in one of the largest atrocities of this migration crisis and it cannot continue to go ignored. But with only four Member States having legal or procedural regulations on missing migrant children, we still have a long way to go. I can think of no greater need for children, than the need for protection. And these children, like all children, deserve it too.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. - Europol figures speak for themselves and more than 10,000 refugee children have disappeared in Europe. These children, most of the time undocumented and often without adults accompanying them, risk falling prey to international criminal organizations that have the aim of enslaving them or exploiting them sexually, or even for the sale of organs. The European legal landscape is fragmented and cumbersome, lacking a unitary strategy that can allow an effective fight against the disappearance of migrant children. Instead, it would be advisable to intervene promptly to ensure that a single protocol is adopted, which allows their identification at the time of disembarkation or in any case of arrival, their registration in a shared database at EU level and the immediate entrustment to protection services. of minors. In the event of a disappearance, action should be taken with the utmost urgency, by issuing reports and notices to each competent authority in each Member State. We also need a tough and effective policy to combat all forms of exploitation and abduction of immigrant minors and the Commission should act as a priority on this issue and not limit itself to saying words, as beautiful as they are empty.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - Among migrants, children seeking access to Europe are also most at risk of harassment and exploitation and are the earliest victims of traffickers, so it is important for them to be registered for their own protection, thus preventing them from being lost. The most effective way to prevent the disappearance of migrant children is to improve the living conditions of camps close to their homeland so that they do not have to travel to Europe at the risk of their lives and in countless dangers. One of the most important elements of this is ensuring access to appropriate education, as this is essential for the healthy development of children, but also for the future of their own community - whole generations must not be left out of education. But it is equally important to provide them with adequate health care. That is why Hungary also supports the provision of education in the refugee camps in Lebanon, Jordan and Iraq, and urges the construction of a hospital.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - The report published by Unicef ​​with the emblematic title "A deadly journey for children" photographs a dramatic situation that we cannot fail to see due to moral duty, sense of justice, political honesty and institution. Of the 181 436 migrants and refugees who arrived in Italy in 2016, 28 223 are minors. Nine out of 10 are accompanied minors. 28 disappear every day. After the violence, the torture, the traumas of a journey through hell, in Europe they do not find an adequate welcome, so many flee, lose their tracks, continue to be perfect victims, because they are defenseless, of unscrupulous crime. There are no migrant minors and European minors, refugee minors and minor citizens, there are children and young people that Europe has a duty to distinguish from adults. Minors need different treatments, different attentions, dedicated spaces and a path, a project, which can lead them, if not to forget, to overcome so much pain. Today the European Commission approves its recommendations for migration policy, which cannot fail to contain a chapter dedicated to minors fleeing war and arriving in Europe. Rules that must apply to all Member States. Let no one feel acquitted, because we are all involved.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - Thousands of nominally migrant minors have appeared in a number of EU countries in the last two years. They seem to benefit from information on the special conditions of children who come to the EU as migrants. Due to the fact that they do not have any personal documents and the age cannot be determined really reliably, many of these migrants are classified as minors on the basis of their own declaration. In the famous "jungle" near the town of Calais, they were nominally adults and nominally minors. Adults were relocated to various refugee facilities throughout France, while "minors" eventually arrived in England. I'm not sure if a similar policy is right, but I understand that younger migrants are more likely to influence their attitudes through education. Nevertheless, I cannot defend the belief that the country of origin should take care of its citizens, and not the country of their choice and "probably recommended by someone". In principle, it does not matter whether they are officially missing juvenile migrants or those whose whereabouts are known. In many EU countries, these attitudes of official positions significantly intensify xenophobic sentiments and increase the preferences of the extreme right. This also increases the risk of self-destruction of the European Union project.

name: Kati PIRI
text: written.- Thousands of children traveling alone have been lost in Europe in recent years.They are at risk of exploitation, forced prostitution, and even illegal organ trafficking.The EU and national governments would do well to put this issue high on the agenda, both for the safety of these children and for our own.After all, they are easy prey for organized crime and extremist recruiters.It is bizarre that Europe cannot even take care of these most vulnerable migrants.Our governments simply need to ensure decent reception, better monitoring and fulfill previous agreements on relocating refugees from Greece and Italy.In Greece, for example, there are 500 single children who have met all the conditions for relocation for months, but have still not been taken over by other European countries.It is a shame!

name: Soraya POST
text: written. - 10,000 migrating children have disappeared in Europe. We hear these numbers over and over again. But the missing children are not gone, they live and are in the midst of us. They disappear for fear of being sent back. When the children have no safe place, they take refuge in the place that receives them. They end up with organized gangs, they sell drugs to survive, they are sexually exploited, without access to school, health care or any of the rights children have. It is adults who have taken their right to a safe place. It is adults who have taken away their hope. Some children are so betrayed that they choose to take their own lives. We need to give these children their right to an obvious place in the world: we need to give the children a residence permit and do so immediately through a general amnesty. The children need to know that they are wanted. As Olof Palme said: there are not your kids or my kids, there are only our children. And the children need to know this. Today, in this minute.

name: Emil RADEV
text: In written form. - The information about the missing 10,000 migrant children is worrying for two reasons. On the one hand, these are children for whom we have a duty to take special care, given that some of them have lost their parents. On the other hand, if so many children manage to escape the watchful eye of the services, imagine how many more and what kind of people use migrant routes to reach Europe and then disappear. More action is needed at European level to protect migrant children, such as combating trafficking in human beings, providing special care for unaccompanied children, strengthening cooperation and exchanging information between security services on missing children, even by setting up of a specialized department at Europol. We also need to ensure, through the forthcoming changes in European legislation, that unaccompanied migrant children receive qualified and trained guardians. Migrant children are not criminals, but they can become criminals if they fall into the hands of human traffickers, organized crime groups and even terrorist networks. That is why tackling the problem of missing migrant children is in the interests of both their security and well-being and European security.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The Lisbon Treaty enshrines the protection of children's rights as one of the European Union's tasks, both internally (within the EU) and vis-à-vis third countries. In recent times, unfortunately, thousands of children from third countries who migrate unaccompanied by their parents or legal guardians have flowed into Europe every year. There are many reasons why this is so, but some are refugees and flee from war, armed conflict, persecution or discrimination in their country of origin. However, there are many children fleeing poverty and looking for a better life and job in Europe. What I personally find saddest is that many of these children are frequent objects of human trafficking, forced labor or exploitation. Even if we neglect the motive of the journey of these migrant children, I regret to say that these children are extremely vulnerable and prone to victims of prostitution, pornographic abuse, child labor, drug trafficking and other forms of crime. I consider the disappearance of migrant children, who are the most vulnerable among migrants, to be an extremely alarming problem, because in the life where they find themselves, they seem to be invisible and without their own voice.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. - A year after a parliamentary question was tabled about the disappearance of an estimated 10,000 refugee children in Europe, the situation has not only not changed but seems to be worse than we know. The figures now speak of 30,000 missing children, whom we have so far been unable to locate and help reunite with their families. Many of them are likely to have been exploited, especially sexually, by organized crime networks and human trafficking. It is a fact that the European Police Office does not have a special unit to deal with missing children, and the coordination of the Member States in this area is disappointing. Recording minors by taking fingerprints, taking into account their age and in any case, not minors under the age of six, is an important measure to avoid new child disappearances. In addition, it is crucial to have more effective European rules, forcing Member States to cooperate with each other and with EUROPOL, to bridge the existing gap in cross-border cooperation. Children are the most vulnerable group of mobile people and it is the duty of civilized Europe to protect their future.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the statements by the Council and the Commission on the gender pay gap (2017/2567 (RSP)).

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner Jourová, first of all let me thank you for the opportunity to intervene here today on the topic of the gender pay gap. Equality between men and women is a fundamental principle of the European Union. It is enshrined both in our Treaties and in Article 23 of the European Union Charter of Fundamental Rights.  In 1975, the Treaty of Rome was successfully invoked to defend the rights of an air hostess who worked for the Belgian national airline, Sabena. She felt it was unfair that she was paid less just because she was a woman. She demanded equal treatment and won her case in the European Court of Justice. That groundbreaking European Court ruling more than 40 years ago opened the way for the first European directives on gender equality. Mainstreaming this principle in all our activities represents an important mission for the Union. Promoting equal economic independence for women and men, including by closing the income gap, is a crucial element necessary to ensure de facto gender equality. However, as we all know, equality on paper does not always translate into factual equality. The principle of equal pay for work of equal value has long been enshrined in European law. Nonetheless, women in Europe continue to earn, on average, around 16% less than men. In some Member States, the gender pay gap is over 20% and when it comes to pensions the situation is even bleaker, with a gap of 38.5% on average across the European Union.  The causes of the gender pay gap are many. However, an important underlying problem is that society seems to value women’s work, paid or unpaid, less than the work of men. Firstly, the sectors employing a majority of women are also those sectors where pay tends to be the lowest. These include care work, cleaning services, casual work and so on. Secondly, women tend to be employed in more junior positions compared to men, a phenomenon we call the glass ceiling. Thirdly, women often have less continuity in their careers, as compared to men. This is because they so often give up their jobs or reduce their working hours in order to work at home. Finally, there is the crucial issue of lack of transparency in pay. It is hard to fight unfairness when unfairness is hidden. These challenges are common in all Member States, however their extent, dimension and context all differ from one Member State to another. This is why the actions that need to be taken in order to address this complex issue of the gender pay gap vary accordingly. Gender equality policies are essential instruments in economic terms. They also lead to greater prosperity, competitiveness and employment. They increase inclusiveness and social cohesion.  Honourable Members, what measures should be taken to close the gender pay gap? Greater pay transparency can help the underpaid fight for their rights. Jobs should be classified mutually and fairly. Also, we must focus on the quality of jobs: while flexibility is important, it should not be forcibly imposed on workers, for example, in the form of precariousness or involve involuntary part-time work. Moreover, more women are needed in company boardrooms and in other decision-making groups. Finally, we must ensure that both sexes can benefit from the opportunities offered by the digital economy, the green revolution, robotics and by the many other transformative developments in the labour market. To achieve this, we should start with education, as gender stereotyping starts very early in our lives. We should encourage more girls to study science, engineering, technology and maths. The IT sector, of course, is another area where women are under-represented and where their talents are needed.  We also need to take a closer look at the concept of a correct work-life balance. This can be addressed through a variety of measures, which include better access to childcare and child services for dependents, as well as flexible work arrangements or leave provisions. This is true also for men. In this context, the Council looks forward to the forthcoming initiative from the Commission on improving the work-life balance.  I would like to thank the European Parliament for its continuous commitment to maintaining the issue of the gender pay gap on the European agenda. I believe this is an issue on which our two institutions have much common ground. The Council has, in particular in the last two years, worked on the gender pay and pensions and on women in poverty. On Friday, the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council will discuss measures to enhance the skills of women and men in the labour market. In this context, ministers will also consider further measures aimed at addressing the gender pay gap. Moreover, in the context of the European semester, the Council will adapt recommendations to improve women’s labour market outcomes and to reduce the gender pay gap. To summarise, we must continue to work together. Only by turning words into actions will we succeed. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, equality between women and men is a fundamental value of the European Union, enshrined in the Treaty from the very beginning. The Treaty of Rome, whose 60th anniversary we will remember in a few days, already included a provision on equal pay, opening the way for a broader gender equality policy in Europe later on. Over the last 60 years, women have reaped the benefits of education and massively entered into the labour market. Sixty per cent of new graduates today are women. Yet, after undeniable encouraging developments, the gender pay gap seems to have stabilised at 17% in the EU. Compared to men, women are also less likely to be in paid employment, to sign permanent and stable work contracts, and they tend to work fewer hours. The glass ceiling still exists: although women have made inroads into economic decision-making positions, less than 5% of company leaders in the EU are women. So it is clear that to finally erase the gender pay gap, we have to do much more. We know the gender pay gap has various root causes and my aim is to have a set of different measures to effectively tackle these roots. In other words, each of those sources of pay gap requires different solutions. In 2014 we adopted a Recommendation on strengthening the principle of equal pay between men and women through transparency. We proposed a package of measures which could be adopted by Member States to effectively fight the direct discrimination in pay for work of equal value, and we work with the Member States to assess how these measures were implemented and how it works in practice. Ladies and gentlemen, I can only share with you that our assessment is that transparency is very important but it does not do magic. Discrimination, which means different pay for the same work, is already prohibited by EU law, so we are pushing for better enforcement of the legislation in force. But discrimination is unfortunately not the only cause of the gender pay gap. We witness the horizontal segregation of the labour market. Women tend to be grouped in sectoral jobs which are under-paid and valued less, such as the social care sector, for instance. It is our intention to support both women and men to go for the less and non-traditional jobs. A good example is the digital sector, already mentioned here by the Presidency, where there are only 30% of women, and we know it is the sector of the future. We pay for projects to get more girls and women into this sector. And, yes, education is the way to solve this problem as well. There is also an issue of part-time jobs. It is clear that during some period of time people might need to use the working arrangement to better reconcile work and private duties. However, it should not be a rule that only women are going for part-time jobs, and there needs to be a guarantee for employees who choose the temporary arrangement to resume full-time work. It is one of the provisions we intend to promote in the package of measures to improve conditions for working parents and carers, the so called ‘work-life balance package’, which is a joint initiative with Commissioner Thyssen. The Commission should adopt this package of legislative and non-legislative measures on 21 April. One of the big challenges is the unequal sharing of care responsibilities between women and men. Among the working population, women spend on average 21 hours a week on caring and household activities compared to nine hours spent by men. It has a lifelong effect on women’s careers, earnings and unfortunately also pensions, where we now have a harmful 40% gap as a reward to women for their lifelong care for their families.  All this shrinks their economic independence. This is not acceptable: all talents must be properly valued and recognised; and a better work-life balance should be sought for both men and women. When providing parents with choice and opportunities, we also aim to eradicate the negative lifelong effect of ‘no-choice available’ on women’s careers, earnings and pensions. I already said in one of the plenary sessions when we discussed the pay gap and work-life balance initiative that it is our duty to remove the barriers for working parents to combine better work and family duties and it will be the free choice of people to use these opportunities. This is the philosophy which you will see in the package on work-life balance which we are preparing. This is, as you know, one of our initiatives for 2017, and this is also an initiative related directly to the European Pillar of Social Rights. The Commission is also undertaking a number of policy and awareness-raising actions to address the gender pay gap. As you know, we initiated the European Equal Pay Day; we encourage the exchange of best practices among Member States and we co-finance Member State initiatives through the Structural Funds and actions by civil society. Talking of Structural Funds, there will be a very rich chapter in the new package on work-life balance to encourage the Member States to use better and more intensively the EU Structural Funds for creating more and better and affordable social care facilities, whether it be crèches, kindergartens or facilities for caring for seniors, because this money should serve people. I cannot imagine many more and better opportunities to use this money for a really good purpose. Ladies and gentlemen, I look forward to the debate with you now.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner.We have heard two statements, the picture seems quite clear.The two statements are in a similar vein, there are no significant discrepancies, but the declarations made seem to mean that both the Council and the Commission intend to fulfill their functions.Before saying goodbye to you, thanking you for the 60 minutes you spent together, I would like to say that we do not envisage a "blue card" procedure in this debate.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Dear Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Equal pay for equal work must be a matter of course in the 21st century. Unfortunately - and you in particular, Commissioner, have already said it - these income differences still exist, and we are all really challenged to tackle the causes within Europe and thus to really contribute to closing this income gap can. I am of the opinion that this lack of women in some technical professions also makes a significant contribution to this, and we also - and it has already been mentioned - especially in the field of education, must start very strongly here in order to encourage women, especially to work in those professions that are actually very much in demand across Europe. However, women very often take a back seat in their professional lives because they are exposed to multiple burdens with family and children and, very often, also with the care sector. Here, too, I think it is very important to provide different opportunities in the social area and to relieve the women more. Or rather, I would like to point out that very many women choose this life concept for themselves and stay at home as housewives, for example. I believe that should also be an area that we should value even more. In some cases, however, women are very reluctant to negotiate salaries. Here, too, you have to start with girls very early, give them the necessary self-confidence and offer them this career perspective. It will also be very important for us to be able to close the pensiongap, which we perceive due to these very large differences in income, because old-age poverty in particular also affects women very much.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, nobody can boast of living in a modern society when data such as the ones presented here today show us that women earn a European average of 16% less than men for the same job. And we are talking about the European average ... because there are countries, like mine, like Spain, where according to reports such as those launched by the unions in recent weeks, we are in a gap of 23%. Therefore, these data have to make us see the need to promote real policies and set objectives to reduce this wage gap. Because if we continue at this rate, the data tells us that our granddaughters will have achieved the goal of equal pay, that it will take more than 70 years to achieve equal pay. Therefore, let us be aware of the need to set clear objectives. Let us propose the reduction of 2% in each country, each year, of the wage gap. Let us propose an audit - transparency is essential to put a mirror to those who are not complying with the law - and let us also be able to give the social partners the role they should play to prevent this situation. A society cannot be called fair when women are in a situation of inequality like the one we have at the moment in the European Union. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: blue-card question. – Do you know which was the place in the Polish theoretical physics Olympiad, the first place of women, of girls? I can tell you: 800th. Do you know how many women are in the first 100 chess players? I can tell you: not one. Of course women must earn less than men because they are weaker, they are smaller, they are less intelligent, and they must earn less. That is all.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: "blue card" response.- Look, Mr deputy, according to you, according to your theories, I would not have the right to be here as a deputy, and I know it hurts.I know it hurts and worries you that today we women can be representing citizens on equal terms with you.I come here to defend European women from men like you.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. - Commissioner, quite often in Slovakia I meet people who might not be interested in today's debate on gender disadvantage, but who nevertheless touch on them in practice. These are people in professions that I think are some of the most challenging. These are nurses, teachers, professional and non-professional caregivers. I don't think it's our job to evaluate how and why they decided on their profession, but if I can mention something in this short space, let me have a personal experience. I know many stories where my own experience has shown fathers of families, men, that striving for better financial conditions, affordable and quality care for children, the elderly and the disabled is the best investment in a happy society in the future. I will be glad if the issue of gender inequality in wages does not remain just a 'women's issue'. We need fathers, husbands, partners, MPs and men of politicians who also fight with us on better terms.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! We must finally stop believing in the myth of equality; it is simply not yet a reality. "Equal pay for equal work" is one of the basic principles of the European Union, which has been embedded in the contracts since 1957. And yet there is a gender pay gap, different pay for men and women in each individual Member State. Many countries celebrate the so-called equal pay day - the day of the year on which women actually begin to get as much money for their work as their male colleagues. The equal pay day in Austria is March 4th, in the EU it is generally March 2nd. Until then, women in Austria will work for 63 days, in the EU for 61 days compared to their male colleagues, actually for free. Girls often get less pocket money than boys or their brothers and the pensions for women are, as the Commissioner already mentioned, 40% less than those for men - across the EU. As you can see, for women it begins with income inequality in the cradle and ends, so to speak, on the grave.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, one week before a historic date linked to the emancipatory struggle of women, we highlight the worsening job insecurity and low wages that affect women workers, assuming particularly shocking and unacceptable expressions in new generations and in sectors such as the textile industry, commerce, accommodation and catering or services. Wage discrimination, direct and indirect, between men and women has causes, does not arise by spontaneous generation. Capital and employers use them to increase exploitation. Discriminations leveraged in the right-wing policies of the Member States and the European Union, inseparable from the attack on collective bargaining and wages and the offensive against the labor rights of workers and women, in particular. Overcoming these inequalities will only be possible by breaking with your class policies, putting an end to precariousness, limiting the use of temporary work, regulating working hours, without exceeding 8 hours a day, guaranteeing the principle of equal pay for equal work and wage appreciation, ensuring proper protection in and of maternity.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, I believe that the Commissioner has described the phenomenon very well. In the entire European Union, with a 17% wage gap, if we count the income as a whole we go to 40. And what I have to say is that things do not evolve. We are stagnant, as has been pointed out. It also has a lot to do with the type of measures, labor market reforms, that we have promoted in recent years, because, obviously, we have a problem with part-time work, which, in addition, later has a very important effect on the rate. unemployment coverage and pensions. The fact that they charge less also has an effect on pensions, because we have a pension gap of 40%. Therefore, I believe that the phenomenon is shared and that here you have to be brave. The issue of transparency on the part of companies that has been mentioned is important, but, above all, a very strong gender equality agenda must be recovered. I have to say to the representative of the Council that he has made us a bit of a notary of reality, since he has told us that, if there were more women in command positions, this situation would improve. Well, you have a Board of Directors, that of women in management positions in large companies, blocked. It would be a good idea to unlock it because that would also allow progress in this area.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President! Minister, Commissioner! Although the employment rate of women has been increasing in the EU Member States for decades, women typically contribute less than half of the average household income. My home country Austria is one of those countries in which women contribute the least percentage.
