The difference in gross hourly wages in Austria is 22.2 percent - that is a third more than in the EU. This means that women in Austria earn an average of more than a fifth less per hour than men. So much for the topic of “equal wages for equal work.” The difference in income extrapolated to annual income is even more serious. Austrian women have an average annual income that is 44.5 percent or more than two fifths lower than that of men. The reasons for this are diverse. We have already heard a few things today: there are fewer women in management and leadership roles, women perform important unpaid tasks such as housekeeping, child rearing and care for the elderly to a much greater extent than men, and therefore often have to take on part-time jobs. Women are more likely to have career breaks, and segregation in the labor market and in upbringing also contributes to this. The findings cannot reassure us, which is why we have to act on all political levels to even out these income differences.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - No one in this House or in the public is defending the pay gap between men and women doing the same work or work of equal value. It is certainly good news and it deserves to be talked about, albeit over and over again. The worse news is that, although this Parliament is still adopting further resolutions seeking to reduce the unjustified pay gap between men and women, the political will needed to amend the 2006 directive on implementing the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women has not been found for 11 years; women in matters of employment and occupation. This is frustrating not only for me as a Member of Parliament on this subject, but especially for women and mothers who are affected by pay discrimination and do not have effective tools to defend themselves against it. This will not change until we have resolved the issue of the future of the EU, which we discussed at the beginning of this sitting. Because what measures we take to combat the unjustified pay gap between men and women, and whether we take them at all, depends on which of Juncker's scenarios we choose.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: - Commissioner, I welcome the Commission's determination to tackle the gender pay gap, but despite all our efforts, the situation has not changed. Unequal pay is a multifaceted problem, so in addition to wage transparency, I first call on the Member States to introduce a clear definition of equal pay in national law. In addition, it is also very important to define what constitutes equivalent work, as there is no definition of equivalent work or clear assessment criteria at EU level against which different jobs can be compared. One way to identify work of equal value is to use gender-neutral job evaluation and classification systems. The pay gap may also reflect labor market inequalities, which are generally more common among women, especially in terms of difficulties in reconciling work and family life. And as a result, women are actually more likely to work part-time, more likely to interrupt their professional careers, which limits their access to lifelong learning, as well as their professional development. Commissioner, I wholeheartedly ask for a legislative and non-legislative package on reconciling work and family life as soon as possible.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Madam President!In the context of today's situation, I would like to draw your attention to my homeland.The campaign against Poland has been going on for many months in EU institutions.Its basic element is repeating lies about the situation of women in Poland, as well as about the allegedly broken democracy.These are obvious insinuations, as evidenced by the recently published PwC report "Women in Work Index 2017", which shows that Poland is in the forefront of countries with the lowest wage gap - only 7%.The PricewaterhouseCoopers report also indicates that if we maintain the current trend of changes, the difference in wages in Poland will be eliminated as early as 2021, which is the fastest among all OECD countries surveyed.Ladies and Gentlemen, this is how equality is measured realistically - not by lies, but by facts.Poland has achieved great success in this field.Follow our example.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, the gender pay gap is the difference between what women and men earn on average per hour before tax. In general, women are not paid less than men for the same work, because that is illegal under EU law. Nonetheless, the gender pay gap is real, even when you factor in the difference in hours worked between men and women. That gap is especially wide in low paid jobs. A recent study in Ireland showed that in 2015 we had a 14.8% difference in median pay between women and men. Crucially, that gap has widened by 80% since 2012, when it stood at 8.3%. This impacts throughout women’s lives with knock-on negative effects on their pensions. The causes of the gender pay gap are complex. We have identified them and now we need to address them. An overarching way of doing this is to strengthen the gender mainstreaming approach throughout the entire lifecycle and to ensure work-life balance.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: - Madam President, discussing the pay gap between men and women today is both essential and futile. This is essential, because it is intolerable that, for the same job, the pay gap between men and women is around 9%. Futile, because the 9% figure only reflects part of the grim reality. In fact, the net annual pay gap is 25% if part-time work and occupational segregation are taken into account. In March 2015, I already denounced the scandal of these women forced to take part-time work to earn 700 euros per month, which is less than the poverty line. Today, one in three women works part time. Occupational segregation - the fact that women and men do not work in the same sectors, do not have the same positions, the same responsibilities - also greatly influences this pay gap. Let us also denounce the exploitation of all these women in supermarkets, in cleaning companies or other offshoots of globalization who, for a pittance, do not even control their schedule.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Ladies and gentlemen! Today we are talking about the wage gap. This is the indicator that we use to monitor and that we use to evaluate both the European Commission and the Member States when it comes to the situation of women. I would like to point out that the wage gap illustrates and diagnoses only a fragment of the wage and economic differences between women and men. The gap we use in our statistics, the wage gap, only reflects the differences in the hourly wages of the wage base in a given sector of the economy. This means that this ratio does not include allowances for internships, functions, positions, overtime and additional projects. It does not take into account measures such as awards, it does not take into account non-wage benefits such as company cars, cell phones, laptops, etc., which are usually associated with high-level positions that very rarely belong to women. So if we wanted to really compare the earnings of women and men within the industry, we should actually compile their annual PITs submitted to the tax offices. Such an overall wage gap would be a better measure of the differences between women and men in the labor market. We know that such a comprehensive gap, because it is measured, amounts to about 38% in the European Union, so similarly to the pension gap, which also seems to include more salary components than the wage gap. Commissioner! I am calling for a change in the methodology of calculating the wage gap and for the use of the overall or pension gap as an indicator of the differences between women and men.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today is 1 March, and it is actually, if we think about it, the first day of paid work of 2017 for many women, but not because they have been on vacation from New Year to today, it is not this the reason, but because - if one takes into account, of course, the equality of duties compared to their male colleagues - they worked for free for the first two months. This is what all the studies that reconstruct the situation with respect to the pay gap tell us. Because, yes, in our prosperous, rich Europe these enormous differences still exist and they are differences - colleagues - absolutely unacceptable, as you said. It is also unacceptable that this difference decreases with this irrelevant speed, because at this rate we will arrive at equal wages in eighty years; probably our granddaughters will be able to achieve this and, I conclude President, we therefore expect the Commission and the Member States to put… (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker).

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, equal pay for equal work is one of the European Union’s founding principles and every Member State is bound to ensure that the principle of equal pay for male and female workers for equal work, or work of equal value, is applied. As Marian Harkin said, however, actually making sure this happens is only half of the problem. The reasons behind the gender pay gap are complex. They overlap and there is no one solution to this issue, but there is absolutely no doubt at all in my mind that the gender pay gap is caused by direct discrimination: segregation in the labour market, traditional gender stereotypes and work-life balance issues. When combined, all these serve to reinforce gender inequality on a much broader scale. The impact of the pay gap extends even beyond retirement, as we have heard. The at-risk-of-poverty rate is around 22% for women over 65 – reflecting the inequality of pay. What can we do? It is time that we took real action. We must extend the right to flexible work to all jobs. We must create a more effective policy on shared parental leave, with fathers getting at least three months’ paid leave, and we must provide a mandatory scheme that includes funded training for women over the age of 40 who have done their duty in society, as they see it, to get back to work. Society must take responsibility for that.

name: Anna HEDH
text: - Madam President! Everyone in this House knows, or should know, that the pay gap between men and women in the EU is huge, not least given that it is now 2017 and that the principle of equal pay was enshrined in the Treaty of Rome 60 years ago. It should be a matter of course that women and men receive equal pay for equal work, but finding a solution obviously takes time. Women still make up a disproportionate proportion of those who work part-time. They are also overrepresented in insecure, insecure forms of employment. According to the latest available statistics from Eurofond, the trend is for part-time work to increase. The same Eurofond statistics also show that women in families with children under the age of seven spend 32 hours a week in paid work and 39 hours in unpaid work. For men, the figures are 49 hours of paid work and 15 hours of unpaid work. In my home country Sweden, which is most often used as a model in the discussion on gender equality, we reach the equal pay principle of only 33 years at today's pace. In Sweden, the wage gap is 12.5 percent; in the EU it is even higher and therefore we need to take real action now.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, last but not least, allow a male colleague to speak about the gender pay gap. Although women have as good, or better, qualifications than men in many cases, their skills are often not valued the same as men’s and their career progression is slower. This results in an average gender pay gap of 16% in the European Union. Over the years it also results, among other factors, in a gender pension gap of around 39%. This situation is not acceptable and has to be addressed as soon as possible. Equality between men and women is one of the fundamental values of the European Union but today we are reminded that it is not one of its fundamental realities. We must cut the gender pay gap by 2% each year over the next five years. The 2006 (recast) EU Gender Equality Directive provides guidance for Member States but I believe it is fundamental to have a revision of the recast Directive to introduce mandatory transparency of pay reports and gender action plans in companies in order to reduce the gap.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, to achieve equal pay for equal work is a top priority for women’s empowerment and the lack of progress is frankly frustrating. The gender pay gap is a challenge throughout Europe in all kinds of jobs. Even in Sweden, my country, a champion of gender equality, women earn in a lifetime on average EUR 300 000 less than men. So what are we to do? There is no one-size-fits-all solution. It is a structural problem that needs to be dealt with from different angles and nationally. Member States have to ensure that women have equal career opportunities in all fields, and this includes care facilities for children and a culture of shared family responsibility between men and women, to facilitate and encourage women entrepreneurship and to fight discrimination. The private sector, where the gender pay gap is more common, should take its share of the responsibility. It is important that we join forces at all levels to raise awareness, putting pressure on Member States to take concrete actions and share best practices.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, many efforts have been made in recent years to reduce the inequality of wages between men and women in Europe.The data in this sense are encouraging, but certainly not satisfactory.Today, women between 30 and 35 years of age have on average a higher level of education and are therefore more qualified than men of the same age, but only 63% of the latter carry out a professional activity, compared to 75%some men.This situation of inequality, as we have said, also manifests itself in terms of the wage gap between men and women, a gap that tends to widen in pensions.Policies are therefore needed to change this trend, to support women in the need to reconcile work and family, but it is above all necessary to invest in education, in order to break down prejudices and discrimination that still too often determine a wage gap between men andwomen.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, a woman as a mother and wife is a pillar of every family, but her crucial role in the family home does not in any way exclude her professional achievement.It is unfortunate that many women today encounter various forms of discrimination in the labor market, which have no place in the civilized world.There are growing tendencies in European politics to completely equalize women and men and reduce them to the same thing, which I consider unnatural and counterproductive.We are different and we need to respect those differences.But where there is no difference, where we do the same job, we need to have equal working conditions.And of course, it goes without saying - and equal pay.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, we have a perfect measure of the size of the problem, and for the celebration of Working Women's Day I want to insist on a change of perspective on the wage gap and female work. The expression in euros of the wage gap is only part of the bill we pay for not making the most of the talent and skills that we despise because of inequality. The difference in salaries between men and women is the translation, in the labor market, of inequality, and eliminating it involves promoting conciliation and joint responsibility - at home, at home - and assigning responsibilities on the basis of merit and ability without gender penalizing. Until we solve these problems, which start with the personal attitudes of all of us, women will work fewer hours and in worse jobs, they will pay us less for each hour worked and we will have lower employment rates and lower retirement rates. And an example of this change in attitude is today's debate: only four men have participated, and one of them to insult us. You also have to change your attitude. It is everyone's problem. It is a social problem for men and women.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think we all agreed that equal pay is, first of all, a matter of elementary fairness, and the fact that we still have this average pay gap of 16-17% also shows, among other things, the lack of respect for women, which is so deeply rooted in traditions and stereotypes. So we need to be smart in introducing a combination of legislative and non-legislative measures in order gradually to change the situation and the conditions. Yes, we heard here from several men – and the one who offended all of us reminded me of a discussion I had last year in New York with an African minister who had very similar opinions, and I realised how happy I am to live in Europe, even though we have all the problems we have discussed here. This is a good address for women, because the vast majority of us agree that there must be full respect for women, and that there is no reason for keeping the pay gap. This is a matter of fairness, but keeping the pay gap and keeping the barriers for women who want to combine better family duties and work is also a matter of alarming economic short-sightedness, because we have very telling figures showing that not enabling women to go to work if they want to combine work with their family duties – with better help from men, of course – is a great waste of talent. I am in frequent contact with IT companies and they desperately need talent, they need innovation, they need fresh thinking, and they are seeking women in this sector. They are also seeking women because women are more in tune with consumer thinking. Women comprise up to 70% of consumers, as measured by the volume of money invested, so there is a demand to have more women better educated for this sector. Speaking also about those economic factors – and we need to speak about them because when we speak about this only as a gender problem it will not fly because the argument of unfairness, and I do not know why, is still not strong enough – in economic terms, society needs children. We heard the figures today in our new White Paper: the demographic trend in Europe is really alarming, and we need to think about it. Our societies, our economies, need to harvest what has been invested in the education of women. It is so short sighted not to help women to use their education in better jobs. I could continue this economic argument but I will give you just two figures. We can see that keeping the barriers for women going to work if they so wish costs, in some Member States, up to 5% of GDP. This is a telling figure. There is another figure which I do not use very often but which is relevant, understanding that women’s economic dependence on men leads to violence against women: that figure shows how much this horrible phenomenon in the EU costs. We have calculated that it is EUR 260 million a year in Europe. This is the cost of violence against women. I could continue. I know we do not have much time, so I will conclude by saying that I take this gender pay gap very seriously, I understand all the complexity, and I can only repeat that we need to address all the sources of the pay gap and to come up with smart, well-targeted measures to get rid of it as soon as possible. Maybe we could discuss further whether there is a need for bigger sanctions, whether there is a need to encourage victims of discrimination to complain more often, and so on. There are very concrete measures which we want to introduce.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, Commissioner, honourable Members, thank you once again for this timely and useful debate. It has shown once again the complex, but pressing nature of this problem. A cross-cutting life-course approach is needed. Each measure we take in each policy area is a part of the puzzle. The Presidency had decided to focus in particular on the issue of skills. On Friday, the Council will adopt a set of conclusions on enhancing the skills of women and men on the European Union’s labour market. Improving the skills of women will improve their situation on the job market and, later on, in retirement. It is a necessary step on the road towards equal economic independence. In its conclusions in the context of the European Semester on the Annual Growth Survey and the Joint Employment Report, the Council will note that more visibility should be given to the gender pay gap and the gender gap in coverage of pensions and that more efforts should be made to reduce them. Thank you once again for your attention.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The data relating to the wage gap between men and women in the European Union paint a complex picture, and very diversified by geographical area. In particular, it is worrying to see how wage imbalances in some regions of Europe increase rather than decrease. Inequalities are growing or persisting despite women having a higher education qualification than men on average: women represent 60% of total graduates, and on average 83% of women have at least upper secondary education in the EU , against 77.6% of men. In light of these data on the level of education, it is easy to understand how the promotion of wage equality between men and women is essential for all those companies that want to invest in talent and professionalism. Women have increasing expectations of professional life, and it is the duty of the European institutions to encourage this path of equality in a harmonious way for all Member States.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - No one can boast of living in a modern society when the reality is that women earn 16.7% less than men for the same job. And we are talking about the European average ... because there are countries like Spain, where according to recently published reports by the unions, the gap can reach 23%. These data have to make us see the need to promote real policies and set objectives to reduce this wage gap. Because if we continue at this rate, until 2086 women will not earn the same as men, it will be our granddaughters who achieve the goal of equal pay. We Socialists call for a 2% annual reduction in the wage gap in each country, mandatory transparency of reports on remuneration, a gender action plan in companies, audits to reduce wage differences and support the social partners to prevent this situation. A society cannot be called fair when women are in a situation of inequality like the one we have at the moment in the EU. Women are neither weaker nor less intelligent, we are the same as men and we have the same rights.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up. - Commissioner, gender equality is a right enshrined in the Treaty of Rome, but, as the Council representative said, in practice it is a difference between regulated and real rights. But I would like to look more optimistic about this topic today when we celebrate the arrival of spring in my country, the symbol being the "Martisor" that women receive from men. I believe, Commissioner, that the responsibility for achieving gender equality in fact lies with the Member States. I must say that great progress has been made in my country in terms of women's involvement in management positions and salaries. I would like to ask you, Commissioner, to propose measures to share positive examples from some countries, to continue with actions to promote women, such as the network of women entrepreneurs' ambassadors. The right of women to receive equal pay for men for the same job and the same responsibility must be respected, and the role is both of the institutions and of civil society and NGOs.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - On the occasion of the European Remuneration Equality Day on 3 November, Mr Timmermans said that the Commission was working hard to close the current pay gap between men and women in the Member States of the Union. However, so far the Union's attitude towards some of its Member States, such as Greece, is anything but helping to close the gender pay gap. Thus, in my country, austerity and violent fiscal adjustment have led to high unemployment for women, with the difference between the total wages between the two sexes amounting to 45.2%. The dissolution of the public sector and the imposition of flexible forms of employment have brought many women into financial despair. Inequalities between men and women have negative consequences for societies themselves and because of these inequalities they are unable to create sustainable development and social cohesion.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Since the signing of the Treaty of Rome in 1957, which prohibits discrimination based on sex in relation to pay, women have continued to fight for equality and equality in the workplace. Unfortunately, the reality is different and shows that women earn on average 17% less than men, which later affects a lower pension by 40%. I must note that stereotypes and prejudices based on gender discrimination have a big impact on the pay gap. For example, women are often grouped into sectors that average lower wages, lower social prestige, and are considered traditionally female occupations, such as care-related jobs. Also, women spend an average of 21 hours a week on unpaid jobs, such as caring for the household and children, while men only 9 hours which leaves long-term effects on women’s careers, earnings and pensions. The problem I want to focus on is the poorer continuity of work experience in women. Women are less likely to be permanently employed and to sign long-term contracts because of the responsibilities they have around family and children. Increasing social support and adopting a package of measures to reduce barriers to working parents would enable women to be mothers without fear for their jobs and for the existence of themselves and their families.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - The average difference between the pay or better the hourly pay of a European and a European woman doing the same job is an incredible 16 percent. In the case of some countries, however, the difference is even greater. In the Czech Republic, for example, this inequality reaches a record 21 percent. It seems completely unrealistic to me that in the 21st century, women still have to work up to 10 years longer to do the same job, only to achieve the same pay as male representatives at the end of their careers. This senseless social injustice must be eliminated as soon as possible. Gender-based artificial discrimination is not just a mere sign of intolerable discrimination, but results in a much higher percentage of women than men at risk of poverty, even though women are statistically attaining higher education. I believe that transparency is a necessary tool with which we can successfully combat discrimination based on sex. I therefore support more transparent remuneration systems and audits, which will enable us to close the two-month financial difference that the male gender benefits for almost a year. I firmly support the call by the Socialist and Democrat political group to call for another two years to reduce the gender pay gap by two percent. Postponing the solution to the problem of the wage disadvantage of millions of European women is unjustifiable.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: written. - Equal treatment for women and men is a fundamental right in the European Union. It is shocking that some of the previous speakers consider the unequal pay of women to be justified, even with the same qualifications and performance. Unadjusted, the gender pay gap is a staggering 41% in the EU average! This inevitably leads to another problem over the years: the gap between men's and women's pensions is 39%. Women are therefore more often affected by poverty in old age. In Europe it is more urgent than ever to close these gaps. If we carry on as before, it will be 2069 before men and women will finally be paid equally. We now need transparency about remuneration and sanctions for companies that violate equality in pay. We need affordable and good childcare services to relieve women of childcare and caring for relatives. And we need a change in our minds, what financial value we attach to typical women's professions. With these approaches we have to reduce the gender pay gap by 2% annually over the next few years - we owe that to half of the population of our member states!

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I consider the debate on the gender pay gap to be important, as the pay gap between men and women is currently around 20% at EU level. It means at least 10 extra working years for a woman to achieve the same level of pay as a man. The level of wage inequality, which has been a problem for decades, varies from one Member State to another, but is still significant. For motivational purposes, there have been awareness campaigns for years, such as the “Equal Pay Day” campaign for the thirteenth time. In many cases, however, inequalities between men and women can be traced throughout the working life cycle, from job search to retirement. Whether women or men predominate varies from sector to sector, but unfortunately it is common for fewer women to take up leadership positions, regardless of sector. Unfortunately, the Hungarian government has not done much to end the shameful situation, although it should have contributed to it. It should take immediate action, such as pushing employers to eliminate pay discrimination through appropriate regulation, or, for example, guaranteeing the recognition of care institutions and work from home. I must also emphasize that the problem of wage discrimination within the EU is the difference between the minimum wages in the Member States and the lack of a European minimum wage, the latter of which we must implement as soon as possible in accordance with a common European intention.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - While we are in 2017 and we continue to affirm all the efforts made in many areas, it is still too easy to give examples showing that women are still not put on an equal footing with men. The pay gap is one of these examples and remains too large, with an average of 16.7% in 2014. Indeed, for equal work, a woman is paid 83.6 centimes for each euro paid to a man. At this rate, equal pay would only be a reality in 2084. It is clear that many efforts still need to be made in this area. So the pay gap is still a reality, and changes are too slow. Our goal should be, more than ever, to address the causes and consequences of these gaps in order to reduce these persistent differences between men and women. Another objective is to change mentalities, especially among certain men, who are not ready enough to work on this problem. As I said before, men and women are not and never will be the same, but they should at least have the same rights.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - Mr President, thank you very much for the floor. I am saddened by the fact that women who are equally qualified and do the same work as men still receive a lower income. Despite all the EU's efforts, the average pay gap is still 16.1%, with significant differences between Member States. Here, women from Slovenia have an advantage over other European women, as the difference in salaries in our country is the lowest. However, the consequences of gender inequality in employment are not underestimated. If there were indeed equality in the labor market, we as a society could also exploit the many potentials of both sexes - and this would ultimately lead to higher GDP growth for all individual Member States as well as the EU as a whole. That is why we must continue to work for the concept of equality in employment and for wage transparency. Because only in this way will the EU be able to implement the principles to which it has also committed itself in the Treaty.

text: written. - No one can boast of living in a modern society when the reality is that women earn 16.7% less than men for the same job. name: Ángela VALLINA
text: , written. - As you know, the wage gap between women and men is, according to EUROSTAT data, around 17%. On a daily basis, millions of women throughout the European Union suffer discrimination that we can call silent, because, under the guise of similar salaries, the precariousness of contracts, temporary status and the recognition of bonuses by categories make women women receive lower wages, which unequivocally conditions their chances of a decent life now and in the future, when they receive their retirement. As you know, last year the European Parliament spoke out periodically against the wage gap and denounced the precariousness. As an example, there is the Resolution, approved on May 26, 2016, on poverty and gender perspective. What measures has the European Commission taken to meet the demands that this Parliament expressed in said Resolution, especially in paragraph 17? What have the Member States done in the framework of their meetings in the Council? I am afraid that if we continue like this, with this institutional paralysis without a real gender strategy, we will deepen even more the distrust of European institutions that citizens currently have.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The worsening job insecurity and low wages, which affect female workers, taking on particularly shocking and unacceptable expressions in new generations and in sectors such as the textile, commerce, accommodation and catering industries, or services represent a scandal that must be reported the eve of another March 8. Wage discrimination, direct and indirect, between men and women has concrete causes. They do not arise by spontaneous generation. The causes lie in the exploitation and right-wing policies of the Member States and the EU that promote this exploitation, with emphasis on the attacks on collective bargaining and wages, the offensive against the labor rights of workers that affect women more and more as shown by all social statistics. Overcoming these inequalities will only be possible by breaking with class policies, putting an end to precariousness, limiting the use of temporary work, regulating working hours without exceeding 8 hours a day, guaranteeing the principle of “equal pay for equal work” and wage appreciation, ensuring proper protection in and of maternity.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the recent partial decriminalization of domestic violence in Russia (2017/2570 (RSP)).Mrs. Mogherini is prevented.Mrs Jourová, you speak on her behalf.May I help you!

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I welcome this opportunity to discuss here, on behalf of Federica Mogherini, the recently adopted Russian law decriminalising some forms of domestic violence, in the context of other discussions we are having on issues related to gender and children. While no country is immune from domestic violence, unfortunately not even in the EU, the Russian Federation has always lacked comprehensive measures to prevent violence against women and children. Currently, according to statistics from the Russian Interior Ministry, about 40% of grave crimes in Russia are committed within the family. In 2006, the United Nations Committee on Elimination of Discrimination against Women recommended that Russia adopted specific legislation on domestic violence, stepped up its efforts to protect victims of violence and promoted gender equality. In 2010 and 2013, the Committee under the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women found that Russia failed to implement these recommendations, and urged it to give priority to this issue. Russia is one of only three members of the Council of Europe that have not signed the Istanbul Convention, that is, the Council of Europe’s Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence. Most countries in Europe are taking measures to stop domestic violence and raise awareness of this serious violation of human rights. On the contrary, Russia’s recent actions send the wrong message about the country’s commitment to tackling violence against women and children. They also go against its responsibilities as a member of international organisations. The recent law – adopted by the parliament and signed by President Putin – reduces ‘battery within the family’ from a criminal to an administrative offence for first-time offenders, and it weakens the sanctions. This is a clearly regressive step. It reverses some amendments to the criminal code adopted by the Russian Parliament itself in 2016, which treated violence against relatives as a criminal offence. The law was passed just weeks after the decision by the Russian Ministry of Justice to list the ANNA Centre as a ‘foreign agent’. The ANNA Centre is a Russian NGO renowned for its work on combatting domestic violence, including its reporting for the United Nations and the Council of Europe. The European Union expressed its concern about this bill right after it was voted by the parliament, and before it was signed into law by President Putin. We addressed this issue in the Council of Europe on 1 February and in the OSCE on 2 February. After the law was signed, on 7 February, we confirmed our criticism through a statement. We now repeat our call on Russia’s institutions to reverse this law and to respect international human rights standards, implementing in full the recommendations of the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women. The ratification of the Istanbul Convention would also be a very positive step. There can be no excuse for domestic violence. Social norms can be no excuse; family culture can be no excuse. Social norms can change, but we need to work hard for this to happen. We need to work on education and on good laws, so that violence can be eradicated from family life. Reducing sanctions is clearly a step in the wrong direction. It can only leave those who need protection more vulnerable and weaker than before. Honourable Members, thank you for your attention and I look forward to our discussion.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Why are we talking here in this House about this change in law in Russia? Because unfortunately we have to state that in the Russian Duma there is no voice or lobby for the weak in society in this case either. And NGOs that take care of it - we just heard it - are put on the list of foreign agents. Instead, of course, the brutals are consistently protected, whether they are family fathers or others. It's also an indication of how society is evolving. Why is there a committee for soldier mothers in Russia in the next phase of life? Because they have to worry about their sons, because in many cases they are treated there just as brutally, up to and including death. This is an expression of brutalizing society as a whole and also the language in this country. And I believe and fear that in general the sensitivity to violence should be weakened, the sensitivity to the fact that society is actually being militarized in many areas - in the curricula, in the exercises in schools. In my opinion, all of this is a very bad omen that in this Russian society the whole direction is not right, and it starts with the smallest and weakest in the family. That is to be condemned.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, indeed, Russia has launched a regulation on the punishment of violence against women, domestic violence, which is unacceptable to us, and I think it is very important that you hear that this Parliament and that the European Union condemn it, and that they ask review that legislation. We have a serious problem with domestic violence and, unfortunately, not only in Russia. The commissioner has asked Russia to ratify the Istanbul Convention. I fully agree, but we have to acknowledge that fourteen Member States of the European Union have not ratified the Convention: Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czechia, Estonia, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Slovakia and the UK. If we want to demand that the Russian authorities change that legislation, if we really want to protect women around the world, we have to set an example in the European Union. And, unfortunately, I have to talk about my country too, about Spain: since the beginning of the year, an average of two women a week have been murdered in our country. So we demand, but we also give an example. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam Member, I just wanted to ask you if you know that the Czech Republic has had a law on protection against domestic violence for ten years and that this law is working.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: "blue card" response.- Yes, there are many countries that have legislation on domestic violence, but, excuse me, ladies and gentlemen, you just have to look at the number of murdered women and victims of violence for all of us to recognize that what we are doing is clearly insufficient.I have used my own country as an example: it is about protecting women, more than a defense of our national identity.Any type of legislation that goes backwards with respect to the protection of women will be criticized by this deputy.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Thanks.According to Amnesty International, a new law in Russia signed by Putin on February 7 this year decriminalizes some forms of domestic violence.Amnesty International has pointed out that this is a disgusting attempt to further downplay domestic violence, an issue that Russia's leadership has long downplayed.This law kills the courage and free spirit of the family, including minors.Children are raised to have no courage, to endure violence, to endure insult and to have a fist in their mouth.We cannot have public courage if we in the family are silenced through abuse and violence.This is what awaits us in Russia or with Russia or under Russia - human rights as in the Middle Ages.

name: Renate WEBER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, an archaic justification for domestic violence in Russia says: if he beats you, it means he loves you. Recently the Russian Orthodox Church stated that corporal punishment, if reasonable and carried out with love, is an essential right given to parents by God. Unless paired with proof of broken bones, shattered jaws or damaged organs, the voices of the victims of domestic violence are silenced by this horrible law. All the progress made by Russian NGOs that fought over the last two decades to offer more protection to women and children will have been in vain. The perversity of domestic violence lies in its intimacy and its loneliness: the shame that surrounds it, the fear of sharing the house with the abuser, and the undeniable hope that maybe, just maybe, tomorrow it will not happen again, put the victims in the most vulnerable position. A bruise is not a sign of love or respect or happiness. Fourteen thousand women die every year in Russia at the hands of their husbands. They all started with just a bruise.  What can we do now? Would political dialogue be able to reverse this legislation? Can we support the work of women’s NGOs in Russia? Probably with difficulty, but I strongly believe that we cannot fail them.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the partial decriminalization of sexist violence in Russia is very bad news for all women. It is a victory for the patriarchy that Parliament lower the laws against machismo and thus pave the way to move forward with the impunity of these crimes that attack women and violate human rights. Machismo aggressions in the domestic sphere, even when they do not cause important injuries, are also crimes. They produce suffering and attack our self-esteem, our health and our rights. Decriminalizing them is a step backwards that reinforces the sexist thinking that women are only owned by men, who may even have our lives. This encourages a machismo that murders women every day. Just last week, in the Spanish state, 5 women were murdered. Enough already! Zero tolerance. No aggression without punishment. It is necessary to move from words to actions. That is why, we ask, Commissioner, interventions with all means at your disposal, including a European directive to end the sexist violence.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, colleagues, Commissioner, domestic violence is not a tradition. Beating up a spouse or child is not simply an administrative offence. Domestic violence is a criminal act, even if the recent law adopted in the Russian Parliament tells us otherwise. This law is not simply a legal change; it is a message. It is a message to all victims of domestic violence, to all Russian women, and to all women all over the world: we do not care about your concerns and we do not care about you. That is why the European answer to this message should be: we do care; we care about any form of gender-based violence. Not only will we adopt the best legislation against domestic violence, starting with the ratification of the Istanbul Convention by the European Union, as well as all Member States, but we will also provide support and funding for women’s shelters, support for victims and women’s empowerment, starting with the ‘She Decides’ Fund. What a powerful message of strength and determination – I mean real strength and real determination, not the strengths that people such as Trump or Putin believe in – this would be to all European women, to all Russian women and to all women all over the world.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, domestic violence everywhere must be combated, and victims protected and supported, we all agree. When I saw this debate on our business tonight's agenda, I wondered what crime the Russian government could still have been guilty of. But contrary to what you claim, nowhere does the text adopted by the Duma almost unanimously legitimize any violence, neither conjugal nor family. Humanity is thus made, the family is sacred to all - well almost all, because we can doubt it at the sight of the texts adopted and the speeches held in this hemicycle which seriously endanger the traditional family balance by attacking to the institution of marriage, by promoting gender theory or by adopting measures allowing the commodification of the female body. So, rather than thinking about Russian children receiving an education and, admittedly, sometimes spanking from their parents, it might be wiser of you to try to understand the reasons for the monumental election spankings than the European Union. will receive within a few months. (The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: blue card question.- Dear colleague, do you not consider that what is happening in Russia is a return to the Middle Ages sponsored by the state?Women and children are not bags to hit.Physical abuse, hitting them physically, is something unacceptable.Point.After signing this law, the president of Russia should not be called Vladimir Putin, he should be called "Vladimir the terrible" or, perhaps better, "Vladimir the beater."(The speaker did not receive an answer to the question.)

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I think it was Solzhenitsyn who said, 'I do not know of any creature under the sun who has suffered as much as a Russian woman.' but he certainly had in mind thousands of Russian women living in the gulag, on the construction of railroads, on the fields of sovkhozes. He had in mind the horrors of war, when women lost their husbands and sons. He meant brave Russian women who were dying in the war. Alexander Isaevich also lived to see the Chechen war in the 1990s. He must have known about Russian mothers who went through Caucasian villages and held in their hands photographs of their lost sons, those sons whom the Russian general had driven to the Chechen war slaughterhouse. Solzhenitsyn knew the weight of Russian everyday life well. He knew how Russian men drowned their souls in vodka, and he sympathized with their wives. Solzhenitsyn did not hide his respect for Russian women. It is a pity that he did not live to see the new law passed by the Russian Duma, according to which domestic violence against women is no longer considered a crime, but a mere offense. He would be the first to explain where the violence in the Russian soul comes from.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Madam President, we have spoken on many occasions in this Chamber about gender violence, saying that it is the greatest social scourge that the world is currently experiencing. And also that it does not understand borders, that it does not understand territories, that women are being murdered in the world for the mere fact of being a woman. And now we find ourselves in this situation, where the Russian Government passes a law that says that hitting a woman once is not a crime; with data as chilling as the one that about 14,000 women a year are murdered in that country. I think it is important - we have already mentioned it on other occasions - the need for the European Union's foreign policy to have a gender dimension, and therefore to transfer, in relations with other countries and in cooperation policy , that gender dimension to prevent these situations and so that women, inside and outside the European Union, know that they have a speaker in this Parliament.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, thank you, Madam Commissioner, for your commitment on violence against women. Today, I wish to reach out to the women and children of Russia that have lost legal protection from domestic violence, to show them solidarity. The new Russian law trivialising domestic violence is a serious setback in combating violence against women. It sounds chilling that beating up your wife, your partner or child becomes simply an administrative offence, like wrongly parking your car, unless permanent damage is caused. It is even absurd to think that this kind of abuse by a loved one would not cause permanent damage to the victim. Domestic violence is violence. It is not a private issue, it is a crime, and it has to be treated as such. Traditional sexist maxims never justify this violence. Women’s rights are human rights. These are universal values under the United Nations Charter. It is not the West versus Russia. Or is it about ideology, patriotism, nationalism, a way to disempower women? We are not interfering in domestic affairs, but standing up for humanity. Russia is a member of the United Nations and the Council of Europe, and should behave as such, first of all by signing and ratifying the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women. I call on the EU and on the Council of Europe to raise this issue in particular at the upcoming UN Conference on the Status of Women and to urge Russia to modify the law.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President!We are currently experiencing a renaissance of authoritarian behavior: the strong man is booming - not just in politics.Taking action, setting facts without talking to others, driving over them - these are behaviors that are enjoying ever greater popularity.This also includes violence in the family towards one's partner and towards children - not only in Russia, but above all in Russia.The decision of the Duma on February 1st to prosecute corporal punishment within the family only in the case of severe physical consequences is a slap in the face of the civilized world.If you love your family, you don't strike.Striking is not a sign of strength, on the contrary: He who strikes is weak.And a law that protects the ruthless is a weak law.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Dear Colleagues, theoretically, in 1718, Russia abolished gender segregation. 300 years later, in the gender inequality index, Russia is at the bottom of the list. An abyss remains as regards opportunities between men and women. In a very populous country, with more women than men, they earn 32% less than they do. In a modern Russia, which rejects the Istanbul Convention, 90% of cases of gender-based violence are not reported and used, not to educate for equality, but to excuse what should be a public crime. When religion, politics and justice get mixed up it is very dangerous. When this is added to violence as a culture, the explosion is imminent. This is not a cultural issue, it is a political problem. Vladimir Putin said the blatant interference with justice in the family is intolerable. But, Mr. President, the blatant dismissal of politics in the fulfillment of democracy is more intolerable.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, twenty-six years ago, it was in Moscow where OSCE member states agreed to work to eradicate all forms of violence against women. It is ironic that after twenty-six years, all forms of violence against women are returning and the tougher punishment is being abolished. One in three women in Russia faces domestic violence. So it is not because there is no threat of violence in Russia, but on the contrary. The petitioners argue that this is an internal matter of a traditional Russian family, and the proposal decriminalizes domestic violence against children and the husband's wife. More serious violence from the fracture upwards will be considered a criminal offense. In the previous situation, it was very difficult for women to get help. So now it will be even more complicated. I do not know if it makes sense to call on President Putin to propose an amendment to the law when he signed the law a month ago. But I believe that we must speak up and support those who have the courage to stand up to violence. I expect it to be the voice of churches and other organizations, as well as individuals, who have not yet given up the fight for human and dignified living conditions in Russia.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the recently passed law to partially decriminalize family abuse in Russia has caused considerable concern, despite the harsh criticism of human rights associations. Domestic violence is, in fact, in any country in the world, a violation of women's rights, of particular gravity, which causes indelible trauma even in children and is unfortunately a problem that, rather than being reported, often remains hidden, protected by walls and by the complicity of a social fabric closed to any State intervention in what are considered only family matters. Faced with the immediate denunciation of the High Representative of the Union and of all the Member States, who stigmatized the work of Russia, the European Union must commit itself with the utmost determination to promote, through its foreign policy, the elimination of domestic violence even outside its own borders.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the Russian decision to decriminalize domestic violence goes in the opposite direction to the effort that is being made throughout the planet to combat gender violence. It is also one more example of the regression that, since 2014, we have observed in terms of respect for fundamental rights in that country. The Foreign Action Service of the European Union, the Council of Europe or the United Nations are some of the international organizations that consider that the decriminalization of sexist violence within the home unprotects women, but also harms children and is not compatible with the European Social Charter that commits Russia. We are therefore surprised that this Federation is one of the four countries, among the forty-seven of the Council of Europe, that have not signed the Istanbul Convention, together with the fourteen members of the European Union that have already been mentioned. All our solidarity, then, with Russian women and our support to the External Action Service of the European Union in all the actions it undertakes to help reverse this situation.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - The decriminalization of domestic violence is a big step backwards. In this way, women become even more vulnerable in this way. This is also a major departure from the European Union's goals of gender equality. The European Commission's Strategic Cooperation for Gender Equality 2016-2019 identifies five key areas for action, including promoting gender equality outside the European Union and combating violence, and we are therefore obliged to strongly condemn any violence, anywhere in the world. It is surprising, however, that the proposed controversial amendment is the work of a woman. This example is a clear indication that domestic violence is closely intertwined with societal views and tradition. Therefore, we must continue to strive for greater awareness of victims and preventive measures, and to inform girls about zero tolerance for violence, as the attitude towards women depends to a large extent on family upbringing. If we bow our heads to Russia's intention, which is in conflict with international human rights commitments, then we are violating our own commitments, as concern for women's rights and their dignity is also a fundamental condition for peace and security in the world.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, I wanted to raise one additional concern. I am aware, from Georgia and Armenia, of the Russian influence in this regard. Exactly the same kinds of laws against domestic violence are being called into question by forces who consider that preventing and combating domestic violence represents something imposed by Europe and America and at odds with morality. We have to be aware that this type of attempt to stop the fight against domestic violence is a very essential part of pro-Russian propaganda, which emphasises the so-called traditional values. We know what that means: ‘traditional values’ means that women are not allowed to decide on their lives and that they are subordinated to men. We have to be aware of this risk: it is spreading.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the honourable Members for their contributions. From this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in using EU diplomatic power to its full potential in support of Russian citizens and of respect for human rights, international standards and human dignity in Russia. No country is immune from domestic violence. In that regard, and in view of 2017 being the Year of European Action on Ending all Forms of Violence against Women, we will continue our efforts to promote the eradication of domestic violence and to support its victims within the EU as well as beyond our borders. May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of the European Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the international agenda.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.Written declarations (article 162)

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - This debate on the decriminalization of domestic and family violence in Russia is symptomatic of the constant disinformation about this state in the Western media. Pursuant to the revised article 116 of the Russian Criminal Code, domestic or family violence without consequences for health will henceforth be punishable by fifteen days of administrative arrest, a fine of 30,000 rubles or 180 hours of community service. general. This reform addresses a legal inconsistency. Indeed, the perpetrators of violence without consequences on health (such as spankings, in the case of children) were previously subject to criminal law on the pretext of their status as "close" to the complainant. Violence of similar gravity, of which any other individual would have been guilty, fell under the scope of civil law. Domestic violence inflicting damage to health, however mild, remains a criminal matter and carries a sentence of up to two years in prison. The reform also introduced restrictive ordinances, hitherto unknown in Russian law. Russian society condemns domestic violence as much as Western European societies. This reform is simply aimed at preventing any state interference in the family sphere.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing.- In his speech on the anniversary of his republic, the Estonian Head of State, President Kersti Kaljulaid, has just said the following: “Violent patterns are repeated from generation to generation, they cannot be broken except with public attention, which leads to a significant shift in attitudes.It is not enough to delegate this problem to the police and social workers. ”It is extremely positive that President Kaljulaid is moving in the right direction when it comes to domestic violence, but at the same time we must acknowledge with sadness that our great eastern neighbor is moving in the exact opposite direction.This attitude proves once again that Russia is not a good partner for the European Union, both in the field of energy and in other matters.I have said this many times in Parliament, but perhaps this approach proves to some colleagues that Russia's world of thought and values do not overlap with ours.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on violations of the current freedom of movement of European Union citizens staying in the United Kingdom and the use of deportations after six months, ofSophia in 't Veld, Catherine Bearder, Gérard Deprez, Cecilia Wikström, Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz, Angelika Mlinar, Louis Michel, Nathalie Griesbeck, Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea, María Teresa Giménez Barbat, Yana Toom, Renate Weber, Javier Nart, Carolina Punset, IvoVajgl, Marian Harkin, Enrique Calvet Chambon and Marietje Schaake, on behalf of the ALDE group, Claude Moraes and Seb Dance, on behalf of the S & amp; D group, Jean Lambert, on behalf of the Verts / ALE group, and Marie-Christine Vergiat, CorneliaErnst, Barbara Spinelli, Marina Albiol Guzmán, Kostas Chrysogonos, Josu Juaristi Abaunz, Stelios Kouloglou, Merja Kyllönen and Paloma López Bermejo, on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group (O — 000008/2017 - B8-0204 / 2017) (2017/2572(RSP)).

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: author. – Madam President, firstly my thanks go to Sophia in ‘t Veld, a D66 MEP who has helped enormously with this issue. This union of sovereign states has been clear over the years that the rights of their citizens are important and are to be protected, with the mutual recognition of qualifications, agreements on health and pension rights, and so on. Like many other MEPs I receive heartfelt emails from citizens living in the UK and across Europe. There are tens of thousands of EU citizens in the UK. They have paid their taxes, they have paid into our pension pots, and they are paying down our debts. They contribute to our society and our economy. The threats from Mrs May’s government must be stopped now. No ifs, no buts. They are doctors, nurses, shopkeepers, students, teachers and others – they are not political bargaining chips. There are many examples. There’s the Romanian electrician forced to resign after threats and bullying. There’s the Italian beautician who has been resident for 20 years, married to a Brit, but now threatened with deportation as she has no private health insurance. And the lists go on and on. They are real people, with real lives, who are worried and fearful. Is that how we should be treating people we promised we would welcome? My government needs to guarantee the rights of these people immediately and stop uncertainty. We need to protect the UK that I know: open, tolerant and united. But it is for this House and its MEPs to speak for all European citizens. We are the ones who must fight for the rights that need to be protected. Brexit negotiations will be tough, and we all know it is easier to chop away rights than to protect them. So this House demands the Commission enforces EU rules and the British Government must respect those rules, respect the citizens, and respect the benefit that migrants bring.

name: Claude MORAES
text: author. – Madam President, before I say anything else I must put a clear question to Commissioner Jourová, on behalf of EU citizens. Now, and once Article 50 is triggered, will you, as the guardian of the Treaties, take action to ensure that the Free Movement Directive is properly applied in relation to both EU citizens in the UK and UK citizens in other EU countries? Why must we ask this today? Because there is compelling and growing evidence, since the Brexit vote, from our constituency casework, responsible journalism and the voices of EU citizens themselves, that some EU citizens in the UK are experiencing great uncertainty about their position. There is suspicion that, far from protecting their rights in the sensitive transition period, the UK has already begun to use them as bargaining chips. We can detect this from the approximately 28% of EU citizen applicants for UK citizenship since the referendum who have had their applications rejected or declared invalid. It is well known that the procedure for some who have been living in the UK, sometimes for decades, involves having to fill in the notorious 85-page forms, which can often trigger delays and panic. I do not have time here to recount the stories of heartbreak and stifling bureaucracy but we must ask if this amounts to a UK policy or to negligence in respect of individuals and families whom we are legally obliged to protect. The European Parliament will hold hearings to gather our own evidence and do our job, but the Commission can act right away. The UK Government has a moral, political and legal duty to protect the rights of all EU citizens, not least because they contribute to our communities and our economy. They are vital. As Article 50 is triggered, hundreds of thousands of UK citizens in other EU countries will want the same equality and dignity that is afforded to EU citizens in the UK: not a negotiation, but a guarantee. The UK Government must do what is right. The Commission must engage and we, your MEPs, will represent you.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Auteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we turn to the Commission with this question, it is because we want to give a voice to the more than 3 million European citizens living in England and the million and more British citizens living in the Union. The anxiety of both is very great and their rights of movement, residence and work will have to be guaranteed now and in more detail in the future withdrawal agreement. Contrary to what Brexit advocates claim, it will be extremely difficult to enforce their vested rights. Many lies were told during the referendum, the "remain" proponents were too silent and reticent on this point and it is crucial that the Commission speak out. The House of Lords has already said it unequivocally: in the absence of a negotiated agreement, the consequences of the loss of European citizenship rights will be severe, so it is important to know how the Commission intends to proceed to deal with the infringements of which the Kingdom United has become responsible in recent years with very restrictive laws on the residence of European citizens in England. Until the day a separation agreement is reached, the UK is subject to European law, the Free Movement Directive, and must therefore be held accountable for any unilateral violations, in the same way that all Member States are obliged to do so. Until then, England cannot limit itself to saying that it will only allow "the brightest and the best" to enter the Union, as well as of course the wealthiest as it promises to do after leaving.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Madam President, I think we are all aware that the UK is not the only Member State with issues regarding long-term residence and citizenship. We will discuss the others when the Petitions Committee brings forward their resolution. However, many EU 27 nationals do live in the UK and over a third of them live in my region of London. Some of them are my neighbours. And the lack of certainty over their future is causing huge concern, just as it is for UK nationals living in other Member States. You only have to read the testimonies on the ‘Brexpats’ website. Much of this uncertainty could certainly be removed by the British Government. I think many of us will welcome tonight’s vote in the House of Lords on the Article 50 bill, asking the government to introduce proposals within three months of the triggering of that Article, to ensure that EU citizens in the UK have the same residence rights after Brexit. In the meantime, as people have said, there are people in the UK from EU countries who have lived, worked, studied and retired there. Some have caring responsibilities and there I think we have an issue with the long-term residents directive. They do not want to be used as bargaining chips; they feel it is insulting and demeaning, and it is. Our government could at least be clear that these people are valued and it should strongly condemn the rising racism and xenophobia we are seeing in the UK. A lot of the stress and the fear that we are seeing is also being caused by the attitude of the authorities. Certainly in terms of sickness insurance we know there has been a shift in position by the British Government over the last few years on the role of the NHS. We really hope that the Commission will get on, please, and introduce the infringement proceedings that have been hanging for so long. I think many of us would say from the case work that we are seeing, and indeed from the excellent LIBE petitions survey, that when you look at this, we either have a government that is dealing with wilful incompetence or targeted administrative efforts to actually delay, restrict, diminish – all of these words crop up time after time, and we would like some certainty, please, for our citizens and yours.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, freedom of movement is one of the basic rights of EU citizens and the European Commission will continue to defend it as a top priority. The correct application of EU rules on free movement by all Member States is of fundamental importance – correct application by all Member States. And for as long as the UK remains a Member State, all rights and obligations continue to apply.  I am fully aware that EU citizens living in the United Kingdom are concerned about their future rights; EU citizens residing in the United Kingdom deserve to know what their rights will be in the UK after the UK leaves the European Union and, vice versa, the same applies to UK citizens residing in the other 27 Member States. The authors of the oral question are absolutely right: people need certainty and stability and they deserve respect and fairness. That is why I hope that this issue can be addressed as soon as possible. However, it is first for the UK to give effect to the outcome of the referendum vote. There can be no negotiation before notification, as you know. It is therefore not possible to be more precise at this stage. Let me now refer to the individual questions. On the first question, concerning the statistics on the number of residence applications, residence refusals and expulsions from the UK, the Commission does not have up-to-date statistics on this matter. EU law on free movement of EU citizens does not oblige Member States to collect such data and share them with the Commission. Some data on numbers of issued residence documents are in the public domain, but there is little data on refused applications, and there is almost no publicly available data on expulsions and appeal rates. Ever since the entry into force of the Free Movement Directive in 2006, the Commission has been working closely together with Member States to improve their ability to collect statistical data and share it. Unfortunately, progress is limited due to a lack of commitment on the part of Member States.  With regard to the infringement procedures, I would like to underline that the Commission takes appropriate action to address failures of any Member State to comply with their obligations under EU law. There are currently infringement procedures in this area against eight Member States. The two pending infringement procedures against the United Kingdom relate to access residence rights of economically non-active citizens, and rights of UK nationals returning to the United Kingdom after residing in another Member State. I would like to inform you that the Commission is assessing these cases carefully.  As regards the residence rights of economically non-active citizens, the Commission will take into account in its assessment the recent case law of the Court of Justice concerning the conditions to which Member States can subject the access to welfare benefits by economically non-active EU citizens in order to protect public finances. Please allow me to underline that the Commission is also carefully assessing the compliance with the provisions of the Free Movement Directive of the latest amendments to the UK legislation that came into force in February 2017. With regard to your last question, the Commission attaches great importance to providing guidance to Member States in order to prevent breaches of EU law. Therefore, since the Free Movement Directive entered into force, the Commission adopted five official guidance documents: in 2008, the report on the application of the Directive; in 2009, guidelines for better transposition and application of the Directive; in 2010, the Handbook for the processing of visa applications; in 2013, the report on free movement and in 2014, the Handbook on marriages of convenience.  In addition to official guidance, the Commission has met experts from Member States twenty-four times in an expert group dedicated to the application of the Free Movement Directive. These meetings are a useful tool to communicate the Commission’s interpretation on issues of practical application of EU law. Last but not least, I would like to inform you that a few weeks ago, the Commission has made available an e-tool on free movement for national administration, together with its citizenship report issued by the Commission in January 2017. The Citizenship report sets out a number of actions to raise citizens’ awareness of their rights and how to seek help if their rights are not respected.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, free movement is one of the cornerstones of our European project and we need to be vigilant in order to ensure that there are no unnecessary limitations to it by any Member State. The ‘sufficient resources’ argument is one that requires constant monitoring and, while it is fair that EU migration does not become a burden on the host state, this principle should not be abused by Member States, nor should it be used, as my colleagues have said, as a bargaining chip. The UK remains a Member State of the EU and the Commission must insist that, until the moment it is not, any and all existing EU acquis needs to be respected, implemented and properly applied. In this respect, it is crucial that the Commission provides Member States, including the United Kingdom, with proper guidance to ensure the correct application of the Free Movement Directive and protect the rights of EU citizens. This is an issue that is so personal for so many people. I have met countless Maltese citizens who live and work in the United Kingdom, and many UK nationals who live in my constituency of Malta and Gozo. They are worried. They are concerned that the life they have spent decades building is suddenly uncertain, they are anxious that after years of abiding by the law, working and paying taxes, they read reports that make them apprehensive. They should not be made to feel targeted. Their rights must be clarified sooner rather than later.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, on behalf of the Socialist Group and especially the Labour members of the Socialist Group, let me say that the way the British Government appears to be intending to use European citizens living in the UK as pawns in the negotiation is a disgrace. The good news is that an hour ago, in the House of Lords, the UK Government, the Conservative government, was defeated when the House of Lords adopted an amendment that obliges the government, if it is confirmed by the House of Commons, to settle this question as quickly as possible and in the shortest period ahead. If that is sustained, that is good news. But I fear that the Conservatives will use their majority in the House of Commons to overturn this amendment and go back to the status quo. It is a disgrace and we shall fight it all the way. But we must do one more thing in this Parliament: we must be vigilant throughout the negotiations and look very closely at the deal that comes back, the so-called divorce deal, because if it does not respect citizens’ rights we should refer it to the Court of Justice to verify its compatibility with the Treaties.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Britain has a long and celebrated history of immigration, a proud record of welcoming people from inside the EU and from across the world, and this will continue long after Brexit. Immigration has made our country stronger, richer and more tolerant. The Prime Minister was very clear about the value she places on the contribution of EU citizens to Britain, to its economy, its society and its culture. That is why securing the status of EU nationals residing in the UK, and of UK nationals residing in the EU, is a top priority for the Prime Minister. Any delay in reaching guarantees on this issue is a consequence of timing and procedure, not of political will. Why are we not now debating how we can make freedom of movement work better? Why are we not debating how we can rebuild people’s confidence in the principle? Why are we not debating how we can address the concerns regarding its implementation across the whole of Europe? For example, we could be addressing the concerns in Germany about access to public services and benefits. We could be addressing the demographic challenges that many EU countries face.
