Our debates do nothing to convince people that we have solutions to the challenges we face – and then we wonder why voters are turning to the fringes of our political system for answers. Debates like this just fuel the scaremongers and spread fear amongst our citizens, who are already unsettled by the changing political landscape. We are missing an opportunity to strengthen our goal of a better Europe, and I am afraid that political point scoring ahead of the triggering of Article 50 will only weaken this House and its credibility. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: question “carton bleu”. – Tá tú ag caint ar an luach atá Theresa May á chur ar mhuintir na hEorpa. Cén luach atá curtha aici orthusan atá ina gcónaí i dTuaisceart na hÉireann; daoine a vótáil chun fanúint laistigh don Aontas Eorpach, go bhfuil faillí uafásach déanta orthu agus ní hamháin sin, ach go bhfuil baol anois ann go bhfuil comhaontú Aoine an Chéasta curtha i mbaol dá bharr seo? Ní fheicimse agus níl aon iontaoibh agam go bhfuil Theresa May ag tabhairt aon aird nó aon aire dár muintir thuas sa Tuaisceart a bhí ag iarraidh fanúint san Aontas Eorpach.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: blue-card answer. – The Conservative Party has always been the Conservative and Unionist Party. The Conservatives believe completely in Northern Ireland and in supporting the Northern Irish citizens of Great Britain. We are committed to ensuring that all parts of the country, Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales and England, remain as a Union and together solve the problems that are inevitable in this Brexit process. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Seb DANCE
text: blue-card question. – You say that this debate sends a signal – an unhelpful one, according to you. Surely the Government sends a much stronger signal than we ever could in this House? Is the fact that the Government is refusing now to acknowledge, and to protect, the rights of the three million citizens who live in our country not damaging our economy and damaging our public services – because we are sending a signal to these people that we do not want them? That is not British.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: blue-card answer. – Were it true, it would not be British, and I would agree with you, but it is not true and you are doing our Prime Minister a great disservice if you think that she does not want to confirm the status of EU nationals residing in the UK. She has made that very clear, but she has also made clear that we want to protect the rights of UK nationals in the other European countries, and those two things go hand-in-hand. If it were down to our Prime Minister alone, it would already have been sold. It is not Britain that is holding this up. It is other Member States that will not discuss this and will not agree it at this point.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: , on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, yes, as long as the United Kingdom remains a Member State of the European Union, your Government is obliged to respect the Treaties that it signed, and the Commission must ensure that they are complied with and act against those who violate it. Given the colossal uncertainty that Brexit has generated, it is our obligation to give certainty to all European citizens who for years have lived and legally contributed to the United Kingdom and the countries of the Union. Thanks to the initiative of my liberal colleague Sophia in 't Veld, we have set up a working group in this Parliament with a single and clear common goal: to defend the rights of European citizens residing in the United Kingdom and British residents of the Union . Even before Brexit, discrimination against my compatriots in the UK was already a reality. I know him well because I closely follow the “Spaniards in the UK” Facebook group, now subtitled “Surviving Brexit”. But, Mrs. May, I'm sorry, the rights are not negotiable. And the European citizens are not a bargaining chip.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I absolutely share the concerns of Members here tonight when they outline their frustration and anger at the failure of the British Government to outline its commitment to protect EU citizens living in Britain. But why should we be surprised that the British Government will not commit to protecting the rights of EU citizens in Britain when it will not protect citizens that it claims jurisdiction over? The people of the North of Ireland voted to remain part of the EU. I am an Irish Republican. I have listened all my life to institutions like these, institutions like those in Westminster, telling me that the constitutional status of the North of Ireland could not change unless the majority of the people acceded to it. We all collectively came together in 1998 and accepted the Good Friday Agreement, which underpinned that principle. Well, we are saying tonight ‘right back at you.’ The people in the North of Ireland wanted, and want, to remain part of the EU. That decision must be respected, and we are depending on the EU to stand up for citizens in the North of Ireland because it is absolutely apparent that we cannot depend on the British Government to do so.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, at a time when the people of Europe are calling for reductions in immigration and for stricter border controls, here you are going on and on, again. While you elitists may not want to accept it, the Brexit vote made a decision: the British people decide who comes to our country and who stays there. As for residence rights, the EU is scaremongering, as are all of you, and treating British expats and EU citizens as bargaining chips. It is an absolute disgrace and it is one more reason why we are glad to be out and why we are confident that we have made the correct decision. May you all suffer for what you are doing to those people. (The speaker did not agree to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8) by Anneliese Dodd)

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Madam President, I am certainly not in favour of the EU, or the UK, using British citizens as a bargaining chip; it is quite disgraceful. Mrs Merkel and others could actually state very clearly now that they are not using people as bargaining chips, but they are choosing not to do so. What you do not recognise in this place is that the majority of British people said by vote that they are taking back control of their borders. As Lord Tebbit, my hero, said in the House of Lords this evening: we will be putting British citizens first. He is back. Yes, the Lords did make a decision this evening, but guess what? Our Home Secretary has at least grown a pair of balls recently and is going to rescind it. They are going to overturn it because the British voted for Brexit. Yes, Ms Spinelli, we are going to have the brightest and best from around the world, from China, from India, and we are going to choose who come to our borders. Not you, Labour, you are out for another 20 years, out for a generation, and thank God for that. Roll on, Mrs May.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – Madam President, over eight months have passed since 52% of British voters decided that the UK should leave the European Union. In those eight months the British Government has not triggered Article 50 and they have not opened up the opportunity to actually negotiate how best to arrange our divorce. So what have they done? They have confronted those Europeans who have applied for residence permits with a level of bureaucracy that I can only describe as ironic for a government that has spent so much time complaining about bureaucracy in the European Union. They have published new regulations on immigration and updated policy on the removal and revocation of European citizens, which has only created more fear, more chaos and more uncertainty for those Europeans living in the UK. They have sent letters to European citizens living in the UK for decades, often married to UK husbands or wives, to make sure they prepare for their departure. If this is Prime Minister May’s idea of creating the grounds for a friendly negotiation, if this is the idea of a global Britain, then I would ask her to think again because this is not global Britain; it is certainly not noble Britain: it is Little Britain at its very smallest.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Madam President, many of us have received e-mails from concerned EU citizens in the UK. One group of people have not sent these letters, but they do have a lot to worry about. There are up to 300 000 Roma migrants in the UK. Recently, a report from the Institute for Public Policy Research warned that Roma EU migrants in Britain face a triple whammy of challenges, legal limbo in terms of residency, and an increase in racist attacks of 57% since the referendum. For them, having to leave Britain would mean not knowing if they would have to send their kids to bed hungry. You will probably not receive any e-mails about this, but I would like to ask you, colleagues, to put some thought and action into the situation of the most vulnerable casualties of Brexit.

name: Emil RADEV
text: - Madam President, the free movement of people within the Union is one of the greatest benefits of membership, which is directly enjoyed daily by millions of citizens of the Member States. Removing or limiting it would negatively affect people's lives. As well as being one of the fundamental freedoms, it is also key to the development of the European economy, competitiveness and business. In this context, I would like to state directly that the British Government's attempts to restrict the rights of European citizens living or wanting to settle on the island are unacceptable. The UK is and will continue to be a Member State until its final exit from the Union, and must fully comply with existing legislation, including the principles of freedom of movement and non-discrimination. I condemn the attempts to instill fear in British society that half of Bulgaria and Romania will move to Britain. Difficulties in the forthcoming negotiations do not justify such meaningless allegations concerning one or another Member State as a pretext for breaching the treaties and trampling on the rights of European citizens. I therefore call on the European Commission to protect all European citizens and to ensure that their rights to free movement and establishment are respected throughout the Union, including in the United Kingdom, even if criminal proceedings have to be launched against the latter. We need more information about existing cases of violations and what actions will be taken to stop them.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, there are worrying signs of possible violations of the right to freedom of movement of European citizens in the UK. I made a list of examples in a petition signed by over 30 000 people that I submitted to this Parliament.  If we have this problem now, I am wondering what will happen after Brexit. We have to react from now on, to prevent any abuse, because this affects not only Europeans but also British people. Too often, populists talk in Britain about Eastern Europeans who come to take their jobs. Anyone who believes that we wanted to see 200 000 Romanian professionals – students, doctors and engineers trained in Romania – leaving for the UK is really crazy. At the same time, it is these so—called bad Europeans who buy British products and work with UK companies and will fight to protect the British people after Brexit. I trust the EU and the British people will not let freedom of movement in the UK disappear, because together we are stronger. We have to give more freedoms and rights to Europeans in order to win against populism. We do not need five scenarios: we need one good one to make Europe a better place for Europeans and British people, and freedom of movement is at the core of this project for the future.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I will build on my colleagues in the Group of the European People's Party. I am glad that we are discussing this point today, because at a time when the United Kingdom is part of the European Union, the Commission needs to do everything in its power to ensure that the British comply with European legislation. That, I think, is the basic postulate that applies, and the other debates that have taken place here between the various British Members are not so much related to that fundamental problem. In short and well, there is a clear directive on free movement, and it is clear that the United Kingdom is not fully complying with this directive, that it is partially emptying its content. It is a bit of a pity, Commissioner, that we have no further information, that we do not have more statistics on how many European Union citizens have been expelled from the UK in recent years, as this would clearly confirm that current British legislation restricts freedom of movement as regulated by a European directive. I therefore call on the Commission, like my colleagues in the Group of the European People's Party, to pay special attention to this issue, because the European Union stands on four fundamental freedoms, freedom of movement, freedom of capital, freedom of services and freedom of goods. If we were tolerant of restricting one of these freedoms, we would be undermining the principles of the European Union, regardless of how Brexit itself turns out and what rights after Brexit the citizens of the European Union will have in the British Isles. Therefore, please pay attention to this, we protect the principles of the European Union.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I wanted to draw attention to the case of homeless European migrants who found themselves destitute and sleeping rough. In my constituency in north-west Manchester the Booth Centre is committed to helping rough sleepers to move off the streets and into stable homes. It is working in close partnership with many organisations, including local authorities, and they are very concerned about the recent increase in British Home Office activity around European migrants who are sleeping rough and at risk of mental health problems. This attack on rough sleeping has coincided with the Brexit campaign where European migrants have been stigmatised and hate crime has increased in my country.  The Booth Centre is actually fully committed to the voluntary assisted reconnection of destitute European migrants and in the last 12 months has organised the return of 141 people. They work with the individual to ensure that they have got a place to stay on their return and are linked to family, medical and social services. But the Home Office is at the moment riding roughshod over this and not working properly with the voluntary organisations that put these people’s well-being at the core of their work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the issue we are discussing is very serious, in view of the fact that there are now problems with the free movement of European Union citizens on the occasion of the Brexit decision, and that is certainly very serious because we have a lot of European Union citizens working in Britain and we have a lot of Greeks who work in the country and are worried about the prospects they have and the conditions under which they will be able to continue working in the UK. We certainly expect that the process of completing Britain's exit from the European Union will take two years. It is certain that in these two years the citizens of the European Union in the United Kingdom must continue and of course the Greeks must fully exercise their rights. Beyond that, there must be a prediction of what will happen in the future.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we learn from the British Home Secretary that the principle of free movement - as we know it - is bound to change suddenly after Brexit. However, the fact remains that one of the fundamental pillars of the Union is the right to free movement and that all primary legislation, both Community and national, is standardized on this pillar. Of course, this balance is indeed called into question by the initiation of the Article 50 procedure, but it should be emphasized that the right to free movement is also enshrined in Article 45 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The circumstance raises the level of protection of the principle to a higher rank, particularly when considering the acquired rights and life expectancy of those who have decided to live and not just reside in the United Kingdom. I hope that these concerns do not become an instrument of diplomatic pressure and negotiation, leaving room for the substantial adequacy of the protection of Union citizens.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - (do not hear the speaker because he does not have a microphone on)… economic freedoms are the main advantage, because citizens trust the European cooperation project. But they will only feel like Europeans if they are, in fact and truly equal citizens. Today, however, we are witnessing the emergence of two categories of citizens. We may be talking about the end of Schengen, we are talking about different working conditions, we are talking about different food quality. Then we need to ask whether we are still talking about the European Union. In the United Kingdom today, more than 100,000 Slovaks live in uncertainty today. Eastern European workers have always been a positive asset to the countries of old Europe and have contributed more than five billion euros / pound a year to the UK public budget. Austria also wants to limit child allowances to Slovak workers, especially caregivers, of whom there are 20,000. They work honestly and pay taxes in Austria. Low wages in Slovakia have forced Slovak fathers and mothers to look for work abroad so that their children have a better perspective. The free movement of persons did not harm the Member States, but it did help. I want to call on the European Commission to defend the interests of all EU citizens and the leaders of the Member States to seek a sensible agreement and compromise.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to reassure you that the Commission is taking all necessary action to make sure that EU law is fully respected. Until the Treaties cease to apply to a Member State that has notified the European Council of its intention to withdraw from the Union, in accordance with Article 50, such a Member State remains a member of the EU, with all rights and obligations. EU law continues to apply in full to the United Kingdom and in the United Kingdom until it is no longer a member of the European Union.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – Free movement – which includes the rights of people to work and reside in other EU Member States is enshrined in the EU Treaties, including Article 21 of the TFEU and Article 45 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which reads that every EU citizen has a right to move and reside freely within the territory of the Member States. I believe this is a fundamental principle and that the UK, as a full member of the EU, must duly comply with this clause. I call on the Commission to provide us with any necessary statistics of any cases of unjustified expulsion or refusal and to ensure that the UK upholds the rights of EU citizens in the UK.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - Freedom of movement and residence is a fundamental pillar of the Union. It is the greatest expression of European citizenship. It is the biggest hit by and for Europeans. It is the greatest achievement of Citizens' Europe. For a country like Portugal, which has always turned abroad, this achievement is of particular importance. As of 2015, there are more than two hundred thousand Portuguese people living in the United Kingdom and who, as European citizens, were able to benefit - without being discriminated against by their nationality - of all the rights accessible to the English. Thus, reports that the British authorities are making it more difficult for Europeans to reside in administrative terms cannot go unpunished. For the time being, the United Kingdom remains a full member state and therefore has to respect Community rules. In the name of Europeans, but in particular the thousands of Portuguese who live there, this Parliament must ensure strict respect for the rights of European citizens.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – Let me be clear: for the time being and at least for the next two years, the UK is a member of the EU, and therefore must apply EU freedom of movement laws. In case of breaches, the Commission must launch infringement proceedings and take the necessary measures to guarantee the full and unreserved implementation of EU law and, in this particular case, the respect for one of the Union’s core principles.  Whenever the UK Conservative Government finds the courage to act on the result of the referendum that it called for and triggers Article 50 – nine months and counting! – the result of the exit negotiations will determine which rules will be applicable to EU citizens residing in the UK. Again, let me be clear: their protection is our absolute priority, as is protection of the values that should guide every decision taken by the Union. Please note: the promotion of fear, hate and xenophobia is not acceptable in this Union.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: In written form. - In 2016, the EU made progress on its key projects related to the protection of foreign citizens, the fight against terrorism, the digital single market, the energy union, the Strategic Investment Fund. In 2017, we continue to work for the security and well-being of the citizens of the Union, we are fighting for new freedoms, such as the free movement of data. In 2016, British citizens chose not to be part of all these projects and processes after leaving the EU. However, before Brexit became a reality, Britain remained a full member of the EU. One of the obligations arising from membership is the commitment of EU citizens to benefit from free movement within the Union. It is important that the rights of the three million European citizens living in the UK are guaranteed both now and after Brexit. I stand behind the decision of the House of Lords and I hope that it will be final. One of the foundations on which the EU is based is the rule of law - it must be respected and upheld without exception. It is unacceptable for EU citizens to be deprived of their right to work and reside legally in the UK. Respect for this freedom should be closely monitored by the European Commission, and violation of it should be severely punished.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Council on the gender balance among the judges of the Court of Justice, by Mady Delvaux, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs (O — 000149/2016 -B8-0203 / 2017) (2016/3025 (RSP)).

name: Mady DELVAUX
text: author. - Madam President, the Court of Justice is one of the important institutions of the European Union. In a way, it symbolizes the rule of law, the European area of ​​justice, which is one of the pillars of our democracy. The European Parliament is very attached to the proper functioning of the Court of Justice. It has demonstrated this in the past by ensuring that it has the necessary resources. As proof of this, the goodwill of the vast majority of members of parliament when it came to reforming the tribunal. Without enthusiasm, but in order to allow the proper functioning of the tribunal we accepted, in October 2015, the Council's proposal, which consisted in doubling the number of judges of the tribunal, whereas the Council had not succeeded in agree on a smaller increase in the number of judges or a system of rotation. Parliament has therefore never failed to support the Court when asked to do so, because we believe that in a democracy, citizens must be guaranteed access to justice and fair trials within reasonable timeframes. and effective justice. But our democracy is also distinguished by respect for human rights and our values, including, of course, the principle of equality. I would like to recall here that, during the reform of the Court of Justice of the Union, Parliament insisted on respect for equality between men and women. In the trilogues, the Council had promised and pledged to nominate more women for judicial posts in both court and tribunal. We even introduced by amendment a sophisticated calendar which allows Member States to appoint two judges each time, which should have made it easier to maintain parity. We obviously know that the appointment of judges is not the competence of the European Parliament, but I expected Member States to honor their commitment. Now that do we see today? Of the 28 judges of the Court of Justice, only 5 are women. Among the 44 judges of the court, there are only 10 women. That is 15 women out of a total of 72 judges. Barely 20%. Council officials will tell me that this is the legacy of the past. Is. But how can we explain that out of the 15 newly appointed judges, only three are women? It is scandalous and unacceptable. I cannot believe that in our Member States there is no way to find women judges capable of sitting in the Court of Justice or in the tribunal. Moreover, I cannot believe that the Member States do not commit to equality between men and women. It seems elementary to me. I remind you that we are living in the 21st century. Our grandmothers were ridiculed, but they fought for the right to study, to access positions of responsibility. We're still not there. We have European justice rendered mainly by men and a judicial system lacking the crossed gaze of women. Therefore, my question is for the representatives of the Member States: what do you intend to do to meet the commitments you have made to promote gender parity when appointing judges to the European Court of Justice? Do you not think that balanced representation of men and women is an asset for the Court of Justice and for quality justice? Finally, I would like to congratulate the Member States which proposed women and thus ensured a better gender balance in the Court and the tribunal, and at the same time, I mean my disappointment, even my contempt, for countries that have not done so.

name: Mady DELVAUX
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, equality between women and men is a fundamental principle of the European Union, as we said earlier today in our debate on the gender pay gap. The equal participation of women and men in decision—making is a matter of justice, respect for human rights and good governance. This was underlined by the Council in its conclusions of December 2015. On that occasion the Council also noted that there is still a need to achieve de facto gender equality in the European Union, which requires a multifaceted approach, including legislation, awareness—raising and positive action programmes.  The Council thus called inter alia on Member States’ governments to promote a balanced representation of women and men in the political sphere, including nominations to high—level positions in the EU institutions. Against this background, it is not surprising that the importance of ensuring gender balance in high judicial functions was also reaffirmed in the context of the reform of the General Court, which was adopted in December 2015 and is currently being implemented.  As you know, this reform foresees an increase in the number of judges at the General Court in three stages. The first stage, the appointment of 12 additional judges, is currently being completed and the second stage is also in the process of being implemented with a view to reaching the number of 47 judges. Two appointments are still outstanding.  The final stage, in which the Court will comprise two judges per Member State, will be completed by 2019 and only then will it be possible to assess whether we have come closer to the objective of gender balance in the composition of the General Court. At present, out of a total of 44 judges at the General Court, ten are women and, among the 22 judges who were newly appointed in 2016, six are women. This is of course not yet satisfactory, even if there is a slight upward trend, which hopefully we will further consolidated.  What can we do in order to reinforce an equal gender representation among judges at the Court? Of course under the Treaty the appointment of judges and, by implication, the nomination of candidates, is the exclusive prerogative of the governments of the Member States. Neither the Council nor Parliament have any role in this respect. What the legislator can do – and has done in the context of the reform – is to create a legal framework which facilitates the nomination of one woman and one man by the Member States. The phasing in of new judges has been conceived in a way which ensures that over time the regular terms of office of the two judges of each Member State end at the same time. The idea is that this should make it easier for Member States to propose one woman and one man. Regarding the selection procedure, the decisive criterion for the appointment of judges is not gender but merit. The Treaty provides that judges are to be chosen from persons whose independence is beyond doubt and who possess the ability required for appointment to high judicial office. Candidates are screened and interviewed by an independent panel of eminent persons, which has set very high standards in terms of qualification and independence and whose opinions on the candidates’ suitability have so far always been followed by Member States’ governments.  This has led many Member States to introduce internal procedures with an open call for candidates and an objective selection to identify the best candidate. This is a welcome development to ensure the highest quality of judges, but of course there is no guarantee that there will be a sufficient number of women among the candidates nor that the best candidate for a given position will be a woman. This brings me back to my initial point, the Council conclusions of December 2015 on equality between women and men in the field of decision—making. In order to achieve de facto a more balanced representation of women and men in the General Court, we now need to concentrate on different aspects, such as awareness—raising and regular monitoring of progress made. These are no doubt the very legitimate objectives behind Ms Delvaux’s question and I am confident that the views expressed in today’s debate will be carefully examined and taken into account as much as possible in the capitals of the Member States.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! This is not the first time that we are talking about gender equality in various areas of life. Today we are talking about this very specific area - about the administration of justice, and in a European version - in the European Court of Justice. Indeed, in December 2015, we concluded such a gentleman's agreement with representatives of the Council in order to complete the legislative basis for the next reform of the European Court of Justice - a reform we deemed necessary. We are fully aware that this is not a clause that obliges anyone to do anything, but it is nevertheless a gentleman's agreement, an agreement that we will demand to be kept. And here thank you very much Mady Delvaux for preparing this question. My conclusion is that, when we look at employment in the field of justice in the Member States, we can see that the majority of judges are women. It is difficult for me today to imagine that in this great number of female judges we will not find such ladies who meet the highest standards required to become a judge of the European Court of Justice. So we call on the Member States to be willing to take this agreement of ours into account, and I say this with a good conscience, because my country has designated two ladies to the European Court of Justice.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: for the S&D group. - Madam President! When the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers adopted the new regulation before the European Court of Justice, it was a success for gender equality that we got through our demand for an equal gender distribution between men and women in the expansion of the tribunal. Therefore, it is very unfortunate that we now, at the time of appointment, see that only five out of fifteen new appointed judges are women. This means that Member States do not respect this agreement with Parliament. If we are serious about achieving equality between women and men, which is also advocated in our EU cooperation under Article 3 of the Treaty, it presupposes that the European Court of Justice is equal. It is also important that we reflect the peoples of the EU. The 500 million people who live and work in the EU have the right to legal certainty, and thus to be reflected by the judiciary. I would like to know how the Council intends to fulfill its commitment to promoting the EU's gender equality goals and a balanced gender balance in the European Court of Justice?

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, the Supreme Court of Justice of the European Union has 28 judges, 11 advocates-general and a secretary. Out of a total of 40 members, only 7 are women, 5 of whom are judges and 2 are advocates-general. These figures embarrass me as a European and make me feel that the time when women were legally barred from accessing the judiciary is not so far away. With these data, the European Union loses legitimacy to implement policies that require the Member States and private companies to respect the principle of gender equality. This inequality at the Court of Justice of the European Union is not only the responsibility of men, but also of some women. When, about a year and a half ago, in October 2015, I submitted a report on the reform of the General Court, I proposed an amendment to the respective regulation that would guarantee an equal number of judges. Unfortunately, it was not just men who were against it: some women opposed this proposal, as they were more interested in a hasty and unnecessary doubling of the number of judges in that court than in the historical realization of this fundamental right of European women.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I see today's debate on the need for balanced representation between women and men in the judicial profession before the European Court of Justice as a warning of the persisting inequality between women and men, which we want to combat. But I think that we should focus primarily on the issue of women's employment in the labor market and their salary evaluation. The difference in the hourly wage of employed men and women in the Czech Republic, for example, is twenty-two percent. Of course, lower wages are also reflected in the amount of pensions. For example, after a divorce from a partner, women find themselves on the brink of poverty. Another huge problem is the lack of available services for mothers with children, which leads to a reduction in the employment of women in the labor market. This fact increases the social costs of the state. Gender issues are very broad, and I hope that we do not limit ourselves to the case of the Court of Justice of the European Union. We must do our utmost to enable women to reconcile family life with the necessary professional growth.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (FI) Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, when the Council was unable to resolve this reform of the General Court in the best possible way, the European Parliament came to the rescue. We did indeed be a little reluctant then, but we nevertheless agreed to double the number of judges, and we reached a political agreement. Mr Zwiefka said that it was a gentlemen's agreement, but it was a political agreement by which we decided that in future we would work as effectively as possible to have as many female and male judges in court. Unfortunately, you use very traditional arguments, such as that gender is by no means decisive, but merit, and there is no guarantee that there will be women in the candidates, and of course the best will be chosen. It is strange, however, that in this society and in the European Union, these conditions continue to be met mainly by men. I hope that the Council will really remember the agreement reached between the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, equality between men and women is a fundamental legal principle in France and in Europe. It is also a founding principle of contemporary European civilization. On this subject, as on so many others, the European Union is, unfortunately, incapable of setting an example. Only three of the fifteen recently appointed judges to the Court of Justice of the European Union are women, which shows some contempt for other women who had the necessary competence to be selected. It is urgent to react. The equality of men and women must be reaffirmed with force at a time when Daesh and certain communitarianisms advocate the enslavement of women to men. If the Union does not do this, the peoples of Europe will draw the consequences. But for her, it is probably already too late. In France, it will soon be a woman who will take charge of ensuring respect for equality between men and women in place of the Union.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: - Madam President!50% of the population are men, 50% are women.In this respect, it is absolutely logical that this equality should also be respected before courts and of course also before the European Court of Justice.The European Parliament did not make it easy for itself to wrestle a decision when it came to increasing the number of judges.One condition was clearly that the number of women should be referred to and the number of female judges increased.In this respect one can only say that the Council did not take this principle into account.And in future we in the European Parliament will have to think very carefully about the extent to which we are also relying on the Council, which assures us something and does not stick to it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I would just like to point out that the proportion of men and women is really almost equal, fifty-one to forty-nine percent of the European population, and that I really see no reasonable reason why such a ratio should not be represented.at the European Court of Justice.On the other hand, I don't think it should be an absolute dogma.I am in favor of gender discrimination, simply the best lawyers should sit in this institution as respected as the European Court of Justice.I am, of course, in favor of women's representation, the transitional quota, which means that there should be some transitional provision that will allow for greater representation of women in the European Court of Justice.But let's not really stigmatize people by gender.I am convinced that we are able to reach a reasonable agreement.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as a woman, former magistrate in Italy - a country in which, today, 50.6% of magistrates are women - I regret to note that, within the Court of Justice and the Court, a marked gender disparity. Despite the measures adopted by this Parliament in 2015 at the time of the reform of the Court of Justice and the entry into force of a regulation that invites States to present 2 judges of different sexes to the Court of Justice, the trend does not seem to have reversed. From 2016 onwards, the only new judge of the Court of Justice has been a man, while as regards the Court, 15 male and only 3 female judges have been appointed. It is therefore evident - and I turn to the Council - that we must continue to urge the States to propose a greater presence of women in the Court of Justice, where they are certainly able to bring capacity, competence and commitment. This is to give substance to the principle of gender balance in the States, but also in the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Court of Justice of the European Communities, in 1976, delivered the crucial Defrenne judgment, which established gender equality in remuneration at European Community level. Today, however, within the Court of Justice of the European Union, the percentage of women is less than 20%. Of course, the fact that there are few women in many of the highest courts in the Member States of the European Union cannot be an excuse for Member States not to appoint female judges, as they have the right to appoint university professors and therefore university professors or even lawyers. Therefore, things are simple: the Member States must clearly take into account the principle of gender equality in the appointment process and also appoint women judges to the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, outside the famous British Old Bailey courtroom stands the statue of Lady Justice, a stark reminder that justice is for all. That principle goes back at least to Roman times, to the Roman goddess Justitia. Since the 16th century, Lady Justice has often been depicted wearing a blindfold, that shows that justice, true justice, is blind to wealth, power or other status, and in today’s society we might well add gender, amongst other characteristics. I do not think it is in any way a stretch to suggest that the same principles should apply to the appointment of judges. Equality of opportunity should exist for all. I do not care whether a judge is a woman or a man, black or white, rich or poor, straight or gay, religious or atheist. I only care for the job that they do. Appointments of judges must depend solely on their ability to apply the law diligently, without fear or favour. Equality of outcome is not, for these reasons, a valid target.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, as I stated initially, the promotion of gender equality in high—level positions in the EU institutions, including in the Union courts, is an important political objective shared by our institutions. While in the most recent appointments at the General Court we have seen a slightly higher percentage of women than before, there is clearly still scope for improvement.  We could ask what else could be done to promote gender equality in the composition of the General Court. It is difficult to understand that, while in many Member States women are well represented in national judicial functions, this is still not the case in the European Union’s Court. Perhaps it is due to the fact that, for judges at the General Court, relevant experience of at least 12 to 15 years is requested, and that women are less represented in this category of experienced lawyers and judges. Some paths towards improving the situation have been outlined, as I have already mentioned, in the Council conclusions of 7 December 2015 on equality between women and men in the field of decision—making, in which the Council called on governments and the social partners to establish far—reaching equal opportunities policies and to set targets and timelines to further develop and implement effective measures aimed at ensuring the balanced representation of women and men in decision-making and leadership, including training, mentoring and sponsoring schemes. This could be food for thought, inter alia, as regards the preparation of suitable female candidates for judges’ posts at the General Court, and might contribute, over time, to improving the overall gender balance among judges. Finally, I think that we could again take stock of the situation once the last stage of the reform has been completed, which should be sometime in 2020. In the meantime, I am confident that discussions like this one contribute to the public debate on the issue and to awareness raising in the capitals. Thank you very much for this debate and for your attention.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - The debate is closed.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - The next item is the debate on the report by Zdzisław Krasnodębski, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the establishment of an information exchange mechanism inas regards intergovernmental agreements and non-binding instruments in the field of energy (COM (2016) 0053 - C8-0034 / 2016 - 2016/0031 (COD)) (A8-0305 / 2016).

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: rapporteur. - Madam President! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! The overriding goal of the Energy Union is to ensure energy security for its members, which largely depends on the diversification of supplies. Compliance of intergovernmental agreements in the field of energy with EU law is one of the conditions for the proper functioning of the internal energy market, increasing security of supply and diversification. However, as we all know, so far the Commission has not had an effective tool to prevent the conclusion of agreements that are incompatible with EU law, incompatible with the objectives of the Energy Union. More than a year ago, in December 2015, in the parliamentary resolution on the energy union, we highlighted the low transparency of intergovernmental agreements, the supply and transit of energy resources from third countries, or the construction and use of the necessary infrastructure, and highlighted the ineffectiveness of existing control mechanisms. In February last year, the Commission presented a proposal to modify the decision on this matter. Since then, we have worked intensively within the Committee on Industry, Energy and Research to establish verification mechanisms for these agreements. I must emphasize here that without very good cooperation with the shadow rapporteurs of the individual political groups and their advisers, such a fast legislative path would not have been possible. I would like to thank everyone very much. This period of intense negotiations coincided with the final period of the Slovak Presidency. We have also worked very well with the Slovak Presidency on this document. I would also like to thank the President of ITRE, Professor Buzek, for his commitment, cooperation, not always obvious among politicians of different political orientations, but I think it was indeed a very good cooperation. I am convinced that the draft decision we are about to adopt tomorrow can provide citizens and states with greater energy security. This it will also be the first legislative act implementing the assumptions of the joint energy strategy of 28 member states. Obviously, this project is the result of a compromise reached in negotiations between the political groups in the committee and in negotiations with the Council, and, like any compromise, it implies some concessions. The most important provisions of this document are the fact that draft contracts relating to the supply or transmission of natural gas and crude oil will be verified by the European Commission before they are ratified, i.e. ex ante. So far, we have only dealt with ex ante verification and only in terms of existing EU regulations; now, broadly defined energy security is becoming an additional verification criterion. However, it was not possible to include the ex ante verification of electricity contracts in the current form of this decision. It is worth emphasizing, however, that in accordance with the provisions of the review clause, they could be included in the scope of verification in the next update of the regulations. The ex ante verification clause also excludes so-called non-binding instruments and hybrid contracts. As for non-binding instruments, the notification criteria are much less restrictive in this case, but the important thing is that they have been defined in this decision, which opens the possibility of introducing more detailed verification of these instruments in the future. The draft also omits hybrid agreements, but in the framework of trilogue negotiations, the Commission has undertaken to issue a declaration that the review clause in Article 10 of the Decision allows the Commission to propose in the future to include such contracts in the scope of the review. These are agreements concluded by states, governments with formally non-governmental entities, but in which third countries play a dominant role. Thank you very much, I will say something more, of course, at the end of our debate.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome the excellent agreement reached at the last trilogue in December on the intergovernmental agreements (IGA) decision review between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. With this, we have reached a major political success that we have built together over the last months. I want to congratulate the rapporteur, Professor Krasnodębski, and the Members of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy for their excellent work. I also want to congratulate the Dutch and the Slovak Presidencies for their support. The review of the IGA decision takes place in the context of the Energy Union Strategy, the objective of which is to give European Union consumers – households and business – secure, sustainable, competitive and affordable energy supplies. In the current geopolitical climate, the Energy Union is essential to stimulate the production of renewables, improve energy efficiency and deliver a more integrated energy sector, which can ensure the security of supply and a successful energy transition, while promoting investment, growth and jobs. With the agreement on the IGA decision, the first act to be agreed from the security of supply package we presented one year ago, we are giving a very powerful signal. We are showing that jointly, Parliament, the Commission and the Council attach great importance to bringing more coherence to our external energy policy, and that this external energy policy should be guided by respect for our internal rules and principles. The current rules on intergovernmental agreements were agreed in 2012, and they require Member States to notify the Commission of their energy agreements with non-European Union countries only after they have been concluded (ex-post). The Commission has been notified of some 124 intergovernmental agreements under the 2012 rules. One third of the agreements related to energy infrastructure or energy supply contained provisions that were not compliant with European Union law. Moreover, it has proven very difficult to renegotiate or terminate intergovernmental agreements once they have been signed by the parties. In fact, no intergovernmental agreement has been successfully renegotiated as yet. The review therefore has two main objectives: to ensure full compliance of IGAs with European Union law, thereby ensuring the proper functioning of the internal energy market, enhancing competition, and ensuring energy security. And to increase the transparency of IGAs in order to increase the cost-effectiveness of European Union energy supply and increase solidarity between Member States. The deal is very relevant: for the first time, the principle of a mandatory ex-ante assessment by the Commission of gas and oil IGAs has been accepted, while electricity IGAs are still subject to a mandatory ex-post check. For the first time the role of non-legally binding instruments has been recognised, in full respect of the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. This will allow for more transparent and fully compliant IGAs in the future. This will increase our energy security and the functioning of our internal market. Of course, there should be no complacency, and the Commission will continue monitoring the development of the information exchange in the future. By 1 January 2020 we will issue a report on its implementation, to monitor the situation, notably regarding agreements between Member States and undertakings but also regarding electricity IGAs.  At the last trilogue in December, the Commission made a statement in that sense that will be attached to the Minutes of today’s debate. On this basis, I am confident that the vote in plenary tomorrow will give a strong backing to the important agreement that we have achieved together. WRITTEN STATEMENT BY THE COMMISSION 1. The review clause of this Decision (Article10) covers the possibility for the Commission to assess whether it is appropriate to address agreements between Member States and undertakings from third countries, in the future, and to assess whether all instruments in this Decision are sufficiently addressed. 2. The Commission commits itself to make this assessment no later than 1 January 2020.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade.- Sir.Chairman!An information exchange mechanism is the first small step on the road to the EU Energy Union.It is good for the further work with the Energy Union that we now have the opportunity to get an early check of the oil and gas contracts that are concluded with countries outside the EU.We are now increasing transparency and have the opportunity to intervene before the contracts are concluded.One would not think that the early check was a necessity, but unfortunately it is.It turns out that up to a third of previously concluded contracts were not in line with the decisions we want in connection with the Energy Union and the EU's internal market.I hope and believe that this will change for the benefit of all Europeans.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as the Commissioner stated, a number of existing intergovernmental agreements were not compliant with EU law. The high-profile example was the South Stream project. Moreover, it has proved very difficult, even impossible, to renegotiate or terminate such agreements. According to the new rules, Member States should inform the Commission in advance about their future gas and oil contracts with third countries through a formally established exchange mechanism. This mechanism will allow Member States to be aware early enough about non-conformity with EU law and to have the Commission’s expertise on their side. I would highlight the fact that this is the first dossier from the Energy Union strategy on which an agreement with the Council has been reached, and securing this agreement in a record time is a significant political achievement towards establishing the Energy Union. The key objectives of the decision are to increase transparency of the energy market, to guarantee that intergovernmental agreements in the field of gas and oil are in line with EU law, and to strengthen the EU’s resilience to gas and oil supply disruptions. It will equally increase Member States’ negotiating power with third countries, as they benefit from the political and economic weight of the European Union. Subsequently, a high degree of transparency will also contribute to closer cooperation between Member States in the field of external energy relations and the achievement of long-term objectives relating to the functioning of the internal energy market. More transparency and coordinated purchasing will eliminate market fragmentation in the EU. That is why I think this decision deserves our approval.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: for the group S & amp; D. - Mr President, the European Union has been importing more than half of its energy from abroad in the long term. Very often from countries that consider energy raw materials as an instrument of their foreign policy, which is completely unacceptable. Europe must respond to this with a clear and strong position in the energy supply negotiations. Therefore, a greater degree of transparency in the negotiation of international agreements, in particular on oil and gas supplies, is more than necessary. The intensified exchange of information and the possibility for the Commission to participate in these negotiations as an observer is the way that must lead to an improvement in our position. By notifying these contracts, the Commission must also ensure that they fully comply with the rules of the European Union's internal energy market. I consider it a positive change that this will not happen until after the agreements have been concluded, but during their negotiation. So far, suppliers still apply double standards for each country, and this is a major problem. I see behind them their efforts to weaken Europe's strong position, the "divide and rule" tactic, one might say. It is this decision that we must prevent. Contracts must mitigate the adverse impact on other states. The new set-up of the information exchange mechanism will, as a result, strengthen cooperation, mutual trust, transparency and deepen solidarity within the entire Energy Union, which I consider to be a basic precondition for ensuring our energy security.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! First of all, I would like to thank you, Mr Krasnodębski, as rapporteur. You really did an excellent job and the result speaks for itself. The negotiated decision aims to overcome the weaknesses of the current mechanism. As of today, agreements do not have to be submitted to the Commission for investigation until they have been ratified. However, it turned out that agreements that are not compatible with EU law can only be renegotiated with great difficulty. That will change with the decision to be put to the vote tomorrow. Now, before signing the agreements in the oil and gas field, the Commission will examine whether they are in line with Union law. In addition, if Member States should deviate from the Commission's opinion, they must explain their reasons for doing so in writing. A clearer definition of the term “intergovernmental agreement” is also introduced, which also includes international organizations. I am convinced that this decision will significantly improve the transparency and coherence of the EU's external relations in the energy sector and strengthen the EU's negotiating position with third countries, particularly in the gas sector. My group, the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, will support that.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the final proposal, as formulated after the trialogue, has indeed been improved in some respects. We welcome, for example, the deletion of the proposal for a mandatory participation of the Commission in the negotiations. Unfortunately, however, the main objective of increasing the Commission's powers to the detriment of the sovereign rights of the Member States remains. The various proposals that remain, for greater involvement of the Commission in the process, even before the conclusion of intergovernmental agreements, with the obligatory ex ante evaluation, are problematic and involve risks. It is not possible for Member States not to be able to sign, ratify or conclude draft intergovernmental agreements without the approval of the Commission, as required in the proposal tabled. Especially since the European Union has not yet been able to deal with the serious problems that exist in energy supply, as many Member States (and regions) of the Union are isolated from the major energy networks. It is very dangerous to pursue policies that limit the ability of states to form multidimensional energy agreements based on the interests of the people. Instead, we must ensure that there is enhanced state control and national flexibility to ensure energy security for the people. The Commission's attempt to manipulate states is unacceptable. That is why the GUE / NGL will vote against this proposal.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- If you allow me, I will speak in Estonian.Mr President,I am very sorry that the GUE Group is voting against this resolution, because it is a very good resolution.It is the GUE Group that could be in favor of this, because Mr Krasnodębski has done a very thorough job of taking us one step closer to a real European Energy Union, and the EU as an Energy Union may one day be much more important than the EU as a European Union.I had the great honor of working with Mr Krasnodębski, and this experience tells me that the background of a researcher in the European Parliament on energy issues is very important.Not every politician will become a researcher, but a good researcher will become a good rapporteur, and I will end with that sentence.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much, Mr Tarand, you can of course speak Estonian.We have the best interpreters in the world here, and they are still fit late at night and interpret everything excellent.

name: Roger HELMER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the explanatory statement for this proposal says its objectives are secure, affordable and sustainable energy. Yet for many years the EU has followed policies which have exactly the opposite effect. Germany, with the largest renewables investment, now uses increasing volumes of lignite. In the UK we are planning to use diesel generation as back-up.  The highly respected Economist magazine currently runs a front—page story entitled ‘Clean energy’s dirty secret’. I recommend it to colleagues. It says we have created regulatory and subsidy structures that militate against energy infrastructure investment and threaten security of supply. I quote: ‘Green energy is eating its own tail’. Yet this proposal today amounts to little more than bureaucratic paper pushing. The explanatory statement concludes by saying the EU is torn apart by migratory and eurozone crises and desperately needs a success. Indeed it does, but this report will not deliver that success.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: - Mr Chairman! I do not agree with the previous speaker on the assessment of this agreement, but allow me to start with what most of the speakers in this House started with, namely congratulations to the rapporteur. It was the first report by Professor Krasnodębski in the European Parliament and if you hear such words of praise, it means that it was really good. I am saying it, knowing, of course, the kind words he said to me. I am convinced that we are speaking very honestly. It shows that in the European Parliament it is possible to work effectively across political divisions in the most important matters for the European Union and for our citizens. Congratulations once again, therefore, also to the European Commission, which is very important, and to last year's two presidencies. We are really satisfied with this result. This is the beginning of the legal regulation of the Energy Union, the first legal regulation, but please remember: the biggest difficulties are usually in implementing what we have passed before. And all of this is still ahead of us. Not only are further Energy Union solutions that are already on the table and on which we are working and will be working hard in the ITRE Committee that count, but perhaps even more important to talk today about how we will implement it how we will enforce. Recent experiences with tensions around the Nord Stream 2 investment show precisely that implementation and enforcement in the European Union and within the Energy Union will be paramount.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, in my speech, I would first like to apologize to my fellow Member, Mr Kukan, who, for sudden personal reasons, cannot speak in the Chamber.However, I would like to talk about an energy union from a security perspective.I am in favor of energy security and the internal market being closely linked.What Commissioner Cañete said in his introductory speech is very important.Europe is a huge market and we do not make enough use of this space.I believe that it is important at what time the Energy Union becomes a real priority for the European Union and its institutions.We need to monitor transparency, that is beyond doubt.In negotiating the various agreements, Europe is a huge internal market, and we should actually be planning our future on this.Our position as a large internal market allows us to negotiate the best conditions.I would like us to be aware of that.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a malfunctioning internal energy market places the Union in a vulnerable and disadvantageous position as regards the security of energy supply and undermines the potential benefits for consumers and industry. Indeed, the strategic objective of the Energy Union is to allow access to secure, sustainable energy at competitive prices. I am of the opinion that the construction of a mechanism for the exchange of information, relating to intergovernmental agreements between Member States and third countries in the energy sector, while going in the right direction, limiting the individualisms of the Member States, does not fully satisfy the need for prior information. Like intergovernmental agreements, joint declarations between EU member states and third countries must be examined before they are signed in order to create the necessary legal certainty for investments. Only a system of equivalent control of intergovernmental contracts and non-binding instruments can prevent the parties from finding subterfuges.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the exchange of information on intergovernmental energy agreements is important. We must not forget, however, that this is an area in which the Member States retain their national sovereignty. What you are trying to do now, with ex ante approval, is to substantially limit the sovereign powers of the Member States. Member States must comply with Community law. They have the right to sign international agreements. Only if they violate Community law do you, as the Commission, have the right to apply to the Court of Justice of the European Union to impose sanctions. Otherwise, there would be no point in referring a Member State to a breach of Community law. You would have ex ante control over everything and so this process would not exist. Therefore, the Member States must retain their sovereign powers and if they infringe Community law, then refer them. However, you can not, by the side road, take responsibilities, as a Commission, which you do not have.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Mr President, I support these new rules, which give the Commission stronger power, so that it can actually help Member States in negotiations with third countries on energy imports.What I personally think is that ex ante conditions should be extended to imports, ie contracts related to electricity imports, especially if we look at the environment of the European Union, neighboring countries that, although members of the energy community, invest in new coal-fired power plants.As they are not carbon dioxide emissions bonds, they also do not serve to improve the pollution of Member States across borders.I believe that the Commission should also be involved in negotiations with the Member States in such cases, as this would jeopardize competition in the European Union's internal electricity market.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Members, thank you for your contributions to this debate. The Energy Union is one of the ten priorities of the Juncker Commission. Let me stress in this respect that reaching an agreement on one of the proposals of the Security of Gas Supply package adopted in February last year is an important step towards the realisation of the Energy Union. It is also important to show that we can do this in just 12 months. Many of you have stressed this issue, too. It shows that when there is the political commitment and we share the same clear objectives, we are able to offer concrete responses to the needs of business and of European citizens. Let us keep this positive spirit for the forthcoming negotiations on the Clean Energy for All Europeans package that is now on the table of the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: rapporteur. - Thank you for the positive evaluation of my work. This is indeed my first legislative report in the ITRE Committee; before that, I was the author of two own-initiative reports which, of course, do not have the same legal weight as this report, which is indeed an important step towards the realization of the Energy Union. I agree with Prime Minister Buzek that the most important thing is implementation, what we will do with this legislation. Here, I would also call on the Commission to be bold and consistent, because certain decisions that are made, such as the decision on the OPAL gas pipeline or the lack of a decision on Nord Stream 2, mean that in many countries whose citizens were very convinced about the European Union and its merits, there is growing skepticism. Courage and consistency are extremely welcome. And I appeal to you for this. However, I would like to refer to this issue of criticism, which appeared not by accident on the left and on the right. It often happens in this room that the colleagues on the left agree with those on the right side of the room, right versus left. So both sides expressed concern that we are not encroaching too much on the powers of the Member States, their sovereignty, with this legislation. I must say that I come from a political group and I personally support the view that here the sovereignty of the Member States within the Union and the powers of the Member States are extremely important to us. But we should build this sovereignty of the Member States and national states in the Union together. It should not be like that, Professor Marias, a colleague from the group also made critical remarks, it cannot be that the sovereignty of one state is at the expense of violating the security of states, members of the same Union in which we all are and whose sovereignty we are building together. This is a value that we should keep.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 2 March 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - The existing mechanism for exchanging information on intergovernmental agreements with third countries in the field of energy has so far proved ineffective. Its aim is to monitor the compliance of such agreements with the legislation and energy priorities of the European Union. The result is to strengthen the internal market and energy security of the EU and its Member States. On paper, this looks good, practically in line with the Energy Union's strategy. However, the real effect is currently negligible. The problem is that the control is carried out ex post, that is, only after the conclusion of any agreements. For example, countries primarily dependent on a single fossil fuel supplier may be pushed into various disadvantages. However, once the agreement is reached, it is too late to make amends. Up to 17 intergovernmental agreements have been identified as problematic. However, entering them after signing was useless. In addition, in many cases, specific related investment projects have begun to be implemented. Given the EU's high dependence on fossil fuel imports from third countries, instead of a bureaucratically complex assessment, it would suffice to say to what extent those intergovernmental agreements contribute to the diversification of sources and transport routes. From a practical point of view, this should be done before concluding such agreements. However, this does not depend on the EU, but only on the will of the representatives of the individual Member States.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - The winters of 2006 and 2009 fundamentally shook the European natural gas system, which had hitherto been considered stable. In the past, it seemed inconceivable that political battles outside the Union could have such a serious impact on our everyday lives. Although the Member States were unprepared for the supply of natural gas, thanks to joint efforts and solidarity, they managed to endure this dangerous period. However, these crises have entered European history not only as threats, but as the beginning of a new era. The hitherto isolated energy policies of the Member States have begun to converge and the issues of security of supply and solidarity have become more important. The real integration of the Energy Union has begun, the interconnection of the networks of the neighboring Member States has begun and we have taken significant steps to develop the market. Naturally, the often largest volume of interstate contracts cannot be left out of such an integration process. A degree of information and norm control can improve the bargaining power of Member States, thus contributing to a country's prosperity and competitiveness. However, we must not completely overthrow one of the most fundamental laws of the market economy, the right to trade secrets. In this case, too, the Union must find the right balance: focus on a better Europe instead of more Europe.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. - The establishment of an information exchange mechanism in relation to intergovernmental agreements and non-binding instruments in the field of energy is an extremely important step towards a stronger and more united European Union in the field of energy. I am glad that the intergovernmental agreements will be analyzed by the European Commission before signing them, as this will not only ensure that they will comply with European law, but also help to ensure that they are not the result of using power over the state Member States by third countries. However, I believe that the ex-ante analysis should cover not only intergovernmental agreements, but also non-binding instruments which, despite their non-binding nature, are also used for such important purposes as establishing a framework for energy infrastructure or energy supply, thus influencing the energy market in a way similar to intergovernmental agreements.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: , written. - The reforms introduced by the European Parliament only reinforce the powers of the Commission vis-à-vis the Member States in negotiating intergovernmental agreements, in order to bring them into line with European regulations. Despite the fact that arguments such as the need to ensure that Member State policies are compatible with the general objectives of EU energy policies (such as energy efficiency and security) have been put forward in the debate, the Commission itself It acknowledges that it wants intergovernmental agreements to be reviewed —essentially— to deepen the liberalization of the electricity and gas market, as set out in the guidelines of the third energy package and of competition policy. In this sense, the aim is to provide the Commission with new formal and informal powers to deregulate international energy markets: powers that, by the way, it does not claim in the field of international agreements between private multinationals in the energy sector. I think we should be more cautious, especially at a time when the Commission's foreign energy policy is more aggressive than ever, as we see with the attacks on Russia and the dangerous alliances with countries like Qatar.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: - The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Soledad Cabezón Ruiz, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the EU's options for improving access to medicines (2016/2057 (INI) (A8-0040/ 2017).

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: , speaker. - Mr President, dear colleagues, health systems are part of a social Europe in which European citizens recognize each other and which they particularly value; they are crucial to guarantee social cohesion and also productivity, which create a healthy society. But they face challenges, such as sustainability, due to the aging of the population, the increase in chronic diseases, the emergence of new technologies. But today, fundamentally, the increase in pharmaceutical spending brings us here: 17% of all health spending - 1.4% of the European Union's GDP. The fact is that the high prices of medicines have put us, developed countries, in a scenario that we did not consider could reach us one day: hepatitis C - a disease with serious consequences, but today with curative treatment. It has not yet been able to aspire to its eradication, but we are prioritizing, based on guidance, its treatment, which is difficult to justify from an ethical point of view. But cancer also threatens 24 million new cases by 2030, an increase of 68% compared to 2012. But this is not a question of ethics, it is also a question of rights. Article 35 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights protects the right to health. The drug, as such, cannot be considered another consumer good, but must be specially regulated so that the patient is at the center of access to it. But, in addition to prices and sustainability, we have the problems of shortages, the lack of adaptation to needs due to lack of commercial interest - in aspects such as antimicrobial resistance - or the need to put incentives - as is the case with medicines orphans—, problems with competition for generics to enter, or lack of innovation with minor modifications in many cases. The price of Medicines are established by the industry on the basis of value, lacking other balances that guarantee access to citizenship. Orphan drugs are increasing in a number that suggests that the criteria are being applied incorrectly, because they generate a fast business, a fast return on investment. As I say, the disputes in the competition that make it difficult for generics to enter are concerned. All of this seems that it may end up leading or is leading to a business model that hinders access to medicines by European citizens. The Member States, with confidential agreements, with co-payment, in short, with different measures, try to find a solution, but, finally, what we have is a more fragmented and unequal market. The Commission implements public incentives, but they do not guarantee that return to society through a fair price or access. This balance of powers is crucial to us and, for this, the added therapeutic value is crucial and has to be established by the Commission and the Member States in a coordinated way. We need, Commissioner, a legislative framework in this regard; also analyze other criteria, of course, economic and social to guarantee it. We need to assess the true impact of intellectual property in promoting innovation and in its quality and, ultimately, in access to medicines, the social purpose that really justifies this fundamental right as well. We have to evaluate the public incentives put in place and also guarantee a fair return on investment with an adequate price and guaranteed access. We need a better framework that guarantees competition and entry of generics and a rational use of the drug. But, very especially, today I want to vindicate —and it cannot be delayed any longer— a plan that will eradicate hepatitis C.
