It is immoral, it is unsustainable that, today, When we have drugs that save people's lives, we are not able to coordinate enough to eradicate this disease.In short, this report proposes measures and actions - these and others - and I ask the Commissioner to take this initiative and, before the end of the year, show us a legislative proposal.Parliament joins the Council, the UN and the OECD.It is a popular cry that we have to respond to this just demand.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the House, and in particular the rapporteur, Ms Cabezón Ruiz, and the shadow rapporteurs, for your enormous efforts in preparing the report on access to medicines in Europe. I fully share your concern about the need to improve patients’ access to medicines and to help ensure that all patients have timely access to innovative and affordable medicines everywhere in the EU. There should be affordable and innovative medicines for each and every European citizen. The key question here is, of course, how do we balance the objectives of innovation, quality and affordability? On the one hand, we need to ensure that the industry develops truly innovative products that respect the strict rules of safety, quality and efficacy while, on the other hand, we need to make sure that this innovation remains affordable, and thus accessible, to patients throughout Europe. I support Member States’ initiatives to help reduce the price of medicines and increase transparency, and the Commission has published a study on enhanced coordination across countries in this area. Together we can all do more for European patients. Your report addresses the entire life cycle of an innovative pharmaceutical’s initial research, regulatory approvals, market launch and, ultimately, entry into the market of generic competitors. Let me concentrate on two aspects which figure prominently in the report: first, health technology assessment and, second, the incentive schemes aimed at encouraging pharmaceutical companies to develop innovative products for unmet medical needs.  I would like to start with health technology assessments. As you rightly state, health technology assessments help Member States to ensure the sustainability of their health care systems, encouraging pharmaceutical companies to develop products with clear therapeutic value-added benefits for patients. In 2016 the Commission announced its intention to propose an initiative on strengthening European Union cooperation for health technology assessment in 2017. We are working intensively on this initiative, analysing the results of the public consultation and preparing the impact assessment. In that context, I welcome the input provided by Parliament on health technology assessment. Concretely, your report recommends the harmonisation of health technology assessment tools and methodologies and that consideration be given to compulsory relative-effectiveness assessments at EU level, with a focus on medical and therapeutic aspects. I cannot, of course, yet indicate what the Commission will propose, as we need to finalise our analysis first. Your input will contribute to shaping the initiative. My aim is to come up with a proposal that has clear benefits for all – for patients firstly, for all European citizens and for Member States. Secondly, let me turn to the incentive system for pharmaceutical companies. A key component of this system is patents. The aim of patents is to allow companies to recover long—term investment in the research and development of new products through exclusive rights. In the pharmaceutical sector these patent rights can be extended by so—called supplementary protection certificates. This extension can be used when research and development has taken a very long time. In addition to patent rights and the supplementary protection certificates, companies can also benefit from regulatory data protection and sometimes market exclusivity periods, for example to develop orphan drugs. You will also remember that we announced our intention to improve the patent system in Europe in the Single Market Strategy. Let me reassure you that this work includes a reference to supplementary patent certificates for pharmaceuticals. It is currently ongoing. Let me add that we will soon launch a comprehensive study to look into the complex incentive system for pharmaceuticals, in line with the recent Council conclusions. This study will investigate the impact of the current regime on innovation, availability and accessibility. We expect to have the final results of the study at the end of this year. In the meantime we published, earlier this month, an inception impact assessment announcing an evolution of the supplementary protection certificates legislation. This assessment also identifies legislative and non—legislative options for the way forward, and we intend to launch a public consultation before the summer. Let me stress that your own-initiative report will provide a very important contribution to this work. I would like to emphasise that, when it comes to incentive schemes, we already have, as you know, dedicated European rules which apply for specific types of products such as advanced therapies, paediatric medicines and orphan medicines. First, in the field of paediatric medicines, as I explained last December in Strasbourg, we are currently preparing a second implementation report showing how the sector functions. We are currently analysing the results from the consultation so I am not yet in a position to draw conclusions at this stage.  Second, in the area of advanced therapies and orphan medicines, our current focus is on the effective implementation of the legislation. In particular, for orphan medicines, let me recall that the legal framework has, for the past 17 years, enabled a strong increase in research and development activities for rare disorders. Investment in this field was previously too scarce due to the very small numbers of patients concerned. I recognise that, besides health technology assessments and the incentive schemes, there are many other very important aspects covered by your report. For example, you touch upon research pricing competition and international matters. You also comment on the new forms of regional cooperation between smaller groups of Member States, such as the one involving Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Austria. Your report additionally calls on the Commission to submit a number of reports and to organise follow—up actions such as the creation of a new pharmaceutical forum. Be assured that we will carefully analyse these suggestions. I believe we need to capitalise on the work already carried out in other forums. This is the case, for example, on the collection of pharmaceutical prices in the European database or on the guidance documents produced by international organisations. Very often this work is conducted in close cooperation with the Commission and Member States.  Let me conclude by expressing once again my sincere appreciation and gratitude for the strenuous efforts put into this important report. Let me remind you that the Commission is also working with Member States, in the Expert Group on Safe and Timely Access to Medicines for Patients, to optimise the use of the existing regulatory tools. I am encouraged by the fact that we all share a common vision, namely maintaining a favourable environment for real innovation in the EU, while ensuring that all European patients have timely access to truly innovative and affordable medicines of good quality and safety. In the light of that, I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteur Cabezón for the work she has done here, also on behalf of Mr Corrao, of the Development Committee, since the work they have done in that committee and in the environment committee has been well received, especially for the issues that have been identified and highlighted with regard to developing countries. However, I want to bring the subject back to what is happening here in Europe and above all with regard to the abuse of fundamental rights, such as that of health. I quote Sofosbuvir, the rapporteur mentioned earlier, which can lead to complete recovery from hepatitis C and which is sold in the European Union at 277 times the production price; the pertussis vaccine is produced for less than a dollar, but in the European Union it is sold for 120 dollars; Erlotinib, for pancreatic cancer, costs 15,000 euros per treatment and produces an average survival increase of only 15 days; Cetuximab, for lung cancer, costs € 80,000 per patient and produces an average survival increase of only one and a half months. We believe - from our point of view - that in Mr Cabezón's own-initiative report these issues are not addressed with the necessary incisiveness. But the worst comes from those shameful amendments by the EPP and ALDE which even want to promote "incremental innovation". We are absurd. Any doctor knows very well that the industry uses the strategy of the "evergreen patent", to preserve the monopoly of a product as much as possible, making only small changes such as, for example, the addition of an excipient. On this amendment we asked for a nominal vote because everyone must know who are those political groups who are on the side of the industry that wants to make a profit at all costs on the skin of patients, making them chronically ill who are not they must never be healed, because then, really, they can squeeze them to the bone.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the damage caused by austerity measures, with horizontal cuts to public health budgets and the unavailability of medicines or lack of access to them due to their onerousness make the right to treatment impossible today. to an exponential number of European citizens, especially the poorest. Inequalities are becoming harshly accentuated but, at European level, a political will remains aimed at maintaining the status quo, aggravated by that obscure relationship between pharmaceutical companies and parts of the institutions on which it is evident that we do not want to ensure full transparency. The decision of the Juncker Commission to withdraw the proposal to amend Directive 89/105 / EEC on the transparency of measures regulating the pricing of medicines - a directive that dates back 28 years ago - and despite the fact that the Commission itself had given that the current regulatory framework no longer reflects the ways in which the prices of medicines are defined. It is an unacceptable state of affairs which once again undermines the credibility of the community executive.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union is charged by the Treaties with guaranteeing equal access for all to health and, of course, quality and safe health. But it is an oh so complex mission, if we take into account the fragmentation of national healthcare systems, the structural differences between the Member States and the evolution of science which makes possible innovations whose cost will not , no doubt, that to increase. A mission that we have however been able to accomplish as well as possible so far thanks to the establishment of a solid regulatory framework, with legislation on human medicinal products, the directive on cross-border healthcare, the regulation on medicinal products. orphans and many other texts. This regulatory framework has made it possible to encourage research and innovation, through carefully targeted incentives, while improving access to treatment. Proof of this is in France, for example, where innovative treatments are often quickly available and drug costs were stabilized between 2009 and 2014. The tremendous breakthrough innovations, which are finally arriving on the market, will bring medicine into the market. a new era and will have a strong impact on prices. Of course, this does not sharply raise the question of the sustainability of our care systems, but that is not why we should give up. But I have the impression that this is what some here wanted to do with this report, the final version of which is fortunately much more measured. I seriously caution, however: do not slow down tomorrow's innovation with short-term calculations. Medical research is long-term and needs visibility and stability. The challenge of access to treatments will involve new business models for laboratories, enhanced cooperation between Member States, harmonization of the assessment of medical technologies at European level, the evolution of e-health and digital technology and the development of prevention.More complex solutions, of course, but more sustainable.Think about it!The cost of innovation is also the price of progress.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, at the moment when the vision for the future of the European project is being debated, we need more and more action so that European citizens feel this project as their own. I salute the rapporteur for the excellent report she has prepared, but now we need to put it into practice, and now! Member States must work together to combat market fragmentation. The European Medicines Agency should be called upon, by extending its powers, to support this collaborative process. A new directive is needed to ensure greater transparency in pricing procedures and refund guarantees. The public effort to support and encourage research in areas such as rare diseases that affect specific niches must be reinforced, and this effort is then reflected in price formation or lost intellectual property. To ensure fair and affordable prices for users and health services, we must encourage the use of generic drugs to increase accessibility and support research into innovative medicines for pediatric diseases. The European Union and the European project must mean more and better health for its citizens. This is possible and absolutely necessary.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Thank you for this report. Ensuring the stability of health care systems in times of increased spending and an aging population requires many activities, including activities related to access to drugs, their prices and availability. It is mainly a question of using Health Technology Assessment (HTA). This use should mainly concern generics and biosimilars, because nowadays these prices are sometimes inadequate to the production costs. Mainly, it is necessary to take advantage of the competition in the off-patent drugs sector, because they generate specific savings. In the field of drug technology, I support the improvement of information exchange. After all, there are national HTA reports and the information exchange should be precisely specified, mainly in terms of clinical trial principles, standards, processes. On the other hand, I would be very careful with the economic appraisal as national systems differ, and I would let this part of the appraisal be the preserve of the Member States. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I have this question: do you not think that the best way to increase the availability of drugs would be if the EU abolished all legislation in this species, and also prohibits states from meddling in drug production?

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- I cannot very much agree with posing the problem in this way.A drug is not an ordinary substance, it is not a piece of clothing, a jacket, pants or a slice of bread.Here, very detailed research is required, mainly on safety, effectiveness, and thus - mainly on effectiveness.You cannot go back to the times from a hundred years ago, where every traveling salesman could advertise something that was supposed to be a medicine, but was not a medicine.This is too much money, too much sophistication of the financial systems of the Member States to let it run through free competition, the free market.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. -  Mister President! This is an important topic that we are talking about today. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the extensive work. We discussed very long and very intensively. It's about placing the patient at the center and then, in the case of an aging population, in some cases with more chronic diseases, which we unfortunately have, to create the same access to drugs for as many people as possible and to innovate in research too and ultimately to affordable medicines. I would like to say one thing here now, because that was a bit of an open question: I think it is wrong to deny researchers any ethics. That sounded a bit. There are many researchers in the pharmaceutical field who are determined to help people. It is an important thing. Of course, it is then about making arrangements to see across borders how you can support each other, for example if there is a shortage of medical care somewhere, if a particular epidemic or something else has broken out where you can actually see which other Member State may have something in stock where one can help oneself out. It is also a matter of coordinating with research and also seeing that the prices do not go wild. But I would like to address one thing that I also consider to be very important: the OECD has determined that at least 20% of health costs would not be necessary because unnecessary treatments and unnecessary medication must be taken into account. Digitization can bring a lot, that has already been mentioned. In Greece it has been noticed that e-prescribing has reduced drug costs by 40%. We have to take all of this into account in order to actually ensure that we have what we need for the people who need the drugs Have money.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, first of all let me thank the rapporteur for her work. I believe that the document mentions all the fundamental problems that make it difficult for citizens in the European Union to access medicines today. The most fundamental from my point of view is the problem of the so-called parallel re-export, which afflicts especially states like mine. Both the European Union institutions and the Member States need to make every effort to prevent parallel trade in pharmaceutical products in the most lucrative markets, as this leads to a shortage of medicines, leading to extremely high health risks for citizens who are often even forced to discontinue treatment. . I believe that the report makes this clear. I also believe that we have succeeded in calling for a solution to fully control the invaded intellectual property right, which today allows for the new patenting of a product that has been only slightly modified, in order to extend the term of drug protection at the expense of finding new ones. That is why I am shocked by the amendments tabled by the right, which seeks to further protect these heinous practices of the pharmaceutical industry. I hope that colleagues will take reason into their own hands and not participate in something like that. What should be emphasized again in connection with yesterday's Rare Diseases Day is that the development of new innovative medicines cannot be governed solely by market rules and the mantra of the cost of profit, as the Commissioner has already said here today. I hope that this document has succeeded in untying the Commission and the Member States, and we will see a solution later in this legislative term.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group.- Mr President, Commissioner, how many patients in Europe are experiencing increasing difficulties in accessing essential medicines?Whether it is cancer treatments for hepatitis C or for rare diseases, some astronomical prices are a scandal.Should we penalize the pharmaceutical industry that still creates 800,000 jobs?In addition, I remain measured on the use of legal tools such as compulsory licenses promoting research and the design of generic drugs, but in Europe.Another point is that the European Union cannot go beyond its powers.Reimbursement is in particular a sovereign decision of states and the Union cannot impose its definition of universal access to healthcare.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, thank you for the floor.It is clear from the report we are now debating that the EU pharmaceutical market is suffering from a serious imbalance.The balance between public and private interests has been upset.Governments would be obliged to provide access to medicines at apparently affordable prices to protect the health of the population.Private interest, in contrast, is the profit of pharmaceutical manufacturers.Of course, it is necessary to ensure profitability in terms of innovation and research.However, profitability is much higher.The pharmaceutical industry has become one of the most lucrative businesses in the world, and unfortunately in no small part by the unjustified, artificial extension of intellectual property protection.In order to protect the health of the European population, we have a duty to restore balance in this area.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, I would like to contribute to the debate with some specifics. I believe that the European Commission must continue to evaluate the functioning of the pharmaceutical system. The data collected can help ensure sustainable health systems and develop innovative medicines. I believe that there is a clear need to step up European cooperation, for example, on the issue of prices or the fight against falsified medicines, as well as the exchange of information. I do not agree with referring to the economic crisis or the negative effects of austerity policies on the state of health systems. This is a one-sided approach. Regardless of the economic crisis, the health situation in Central European Member States is still worse than in the West. Catching up takes time, but we must seize every means to avoid that patients ’recovery and health depend on which country we live in. At this point, I mention the parallel trade in medicines, which is also a problem in our countries and leads to a shortage of medicines. To prevent this, the EU institutions and the Member States must also take action, because quality and affordable medicine is not a luxury. It is also very important that Member States share information, expertise and best practices in order to prevent overpricing of medicines and to ensure that generic products reach the market. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, you said that the health situation in Central Europe is worse than in other Member States of the European Union.I ask you very specifically: What Central European countries are you talking about?Because I believe that it is in the Czech Republic, even though it has its problems, that healthcare provided to patients is at a very high level, and I do not want to talk about this country in such a way that the situation is worse there or that patients do not have access to treatment there.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- (Do not hear the speaker well at the beginning because he does not have the microphone on)… I will answer… in Slovak so that you can hear it better.I agree with you to some extent.But I think we are "late" in Eastern Europe, we cannot solve this with just some statements.I think that the cooperation of the Member States and the European institutions is needed, and I am convinced that the role or role of the European Commission in this area is also irreplaceable.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the time has come to update the European legislation on medicines, a market which generates more than EUR 200 billion in turnover and which employs over one million people. A growing sector which, however, needs advanced rules, not only to guarantee the safety of medicines, but also the quality of innovation and the sustainability of health systems for an aging population. Medicines are different from other consumer goods, the rules on intellectual property risk conflict with the protection of health, which requires governments to guarantee access for all to medicines. I will therefore be voting in favor of this report, which also calls for greater public investment in research and aims to overcome the fragmentation of the European market and the inequality of access to medicines among European citizens. I would also like to underline that there is also an issue linked to the waste of medicines, which we should also address, on which just today I submitted a written question to the Commission, asking the Member States to take action to promote the recovery of valid and expired medicines. We are talking about tons of drugs that end up in waste every year, causing significant environmental damage, as well as economic damage, to the systems ... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker).

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Colleagues, if you get one minute from your Group please try to stick to one minute. We are way over time already. I will not have a catch-the-eye in this debate, I am afraid we cannot do it because we are way over time already. Please stick to your time slots.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman! Although the draft report on the EU's potential to increase access to medicines appears to be beneficial, it nevertheless operates with ambiguities that may cause companies to overstate the cost of research and the price of drugs introduced to the market, similar to the described principle of a fair price of a drug, which may leave the freedom to manipulate to maximize profits. The new Commission directive is to regulate drug pricing procedures and reimbursement systems, and the only criterion considered relevant is the criterion of market challenges. The pricing and reimbursement systems are within the competence of the Member States, while the European institutions are competent in the field of competition protection and research support, which means that through this document the EU bodies try to influence the Member States to introduce regulations in line with their expectations, although the EU bodies themselves have not been empowered by the Treaties to deal with this type of problem.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, someone having to walk hundreds of kilometres to access medicine: you would probably think of sub-Saharan Africa and some unfortunate mother looking to help her child. In the Republic of Ireland, at the moment, we have such a situation: we have a mother called Vera Twomey who is trying to help her daughter Ava Twomey get access to medicine, and to do this she is walking hundreds of kilometres from her home to our parliament in Dublin. The purpose of it is so she can get access to medicine based on tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). She currently can, in Ireland, get access to CBD, which is also a cannabidiol-based treatment, for her daughter. Her daughter suffers from a severe form of epilepsy called Dravet’s syndrome. She suffers multiple seizures. If she could access THC, which she could in Germany, Poland, Great Britain and other countries, her seizures would stop. What I suggest here is that the European Union concentrate on harmonising this, rather than concentrating on jumping through hoops about harmonising what we eat for our breakfast.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: - Mr President, many patients in Europe have little or no limited access to vital diagnosis and treatment. Inequalities in access to quality healthcare are widespread throughout the European Union and, unfortunately, innovation is not reaching all Member States at the same pace. Although the powers in the field of drug policy are at the national level, I think there are also European solutions to improve the current situation. Medicinal products are one of the main pillars of the healthcare system, not just a commercial commodity. Public health and patient interest considerations must take precedence over economic considerations. Therefore, the European Commission must closely monitor the situation with parallel trade in order to prevent it from leading to a shortage of medicines in some countries, such as Bulgaria. I think it is counterproductive to talk about harmonizing drug prices in the European Union. The economic situation is different in each country and prices should adequately reflect this. However, what we can do is harmonize the assessment of the therapeutic added value of each medicinal product in order to speed up the marketing process and avoid duplication. Twenty-eight different national agencies are currently evaluating, but some countries are experiencing serious difficulties due to a lack of administrative capacity. Ultimately, this affects patients who are at a disadvantage because they do not have timely access to the necessary treatment. Finally, I would like to draw attention to an important issue, which concerns cooperation at regional level.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: -  Mister President! This report makes it clear that it is an important task for the European Union to ensure that patients in all Member States have the same access to medicines. Article 17 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights refers to the protection of intellectual property. When companies invest in innovation and research, this ensures a return on the investment. The pharmaceutical market is a specialty because pharmaceuticals cannot be viewed like other goods. Article 35 of the Charter obliges states to ensure access to medicinal products. There is thus a conflict of objectives between two fundamental rights that must be resolved in favor of the health of Europeans. The EU must work to ensure that the well-being of the patients and not profit is paramount. The market launch of generics is an important means of stimulating competition, reducing prices and ensuring a sustainable and high-performance health system.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Ensuring effective, safe and economically affordable medicines is primarily the responsibility and task of the Member States. However, legislative information, economic and financial mechanisms need to be promoted at EU level to help achieve this goal. In particular, the creation and implementation of effective policies and support for the development of research and production of new medicines in EU countries must be ensured. Policies to prevent and hamper harmful outsourcing of these capacities from outside the EU, with all its negative consequences, should be considered. The market must better meet the real and defined health needs of the population and not follow, for example, medically dubious, fashionable or even harmful lifestyle requirements. Attention must also be paid to medicines for rare diseases and medicines for diseases ... medicines for diseases that can be considered neglected in the EU. Ensuring the protection of the population against low-quality or fraudulent medicines entering the EU also remains a challenge. Equally important is the protection of the population against medically unjustifiable or directly irrational medical procedures and preparations from the so-called alternative medicine. Adequate involvement of the patient himself is important, who must become the subject and co-creator of the necessary changes.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened to Members’ comments and opinions with great interest and I am grateful for this rich exchange of views. This debate shows we share the aim of helping patients gain access to truly innovative medicines at affordable prices across the European Union. I would like to pick up a couple of points raised in your report and in the debate.  I support Member States’ initiatives to help reduce medicine prices and increase transparency in the setting of such prices. Small countries have lower negotiating power and face particular difficulties. I welcome the ongoing cooperation amongst European Union countries in this regard. In addition, our European Union Joint Procurement Agreement enables Member States to buy medicines together under the same conditions. In fact, most Member States will buy pandemic vaccines together this year. Thinking about vaccines, vaccine shortages are indeed a major challenge. This is why we are setting up a joint action on vaccines with the Member States to help them forecast and manage vaccine needs.  Last and most important, the report provides a contribution to our ongoing work on health technology assessment. Once again, my aim is to come up with a proposal that has clear benefits for all, including, above all, European patients. Finally, I fully agree with the need for a strategic breakthrough on disease prevention to reduce the need for medicines, as expressed in your report.  Let me conclude by expressing again my gratitude to Ms Cabezón Ruiz and the shadow rapporteurs. Our discussions today demonstrate very well the value of effective and continuous dialogue, which I trust will continue as matters progress. I look forward to our future cooperation.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: , Speaker. - Mr President, Commissioner, I can only begin and end by celebrating the announcements you make to us. Picking up the glove, it shows his commitment, announces that he is going to start up or make a proposal on the evaluation of technologies, specifically medicines. I think that will come to answer, that it will be very important for what some group has claimed here: the need to have an objective criterion so that we can set a fair price and avoid excess in some cases, as has been shown here . I am pleased that you are going to review the incentives to meet the effective purpose for which they are mandated or that you review the impact of intellectual property. Indeed, the report also calls for the revision of the Directive; calls for a necessary strategy to combat antimicrobial resistance; a strategy against cancer; also for pediatric medications; of course, addressing the shortage of the countries, especially the Eastern countries; greater coordination and transparency between Member States. In short, it is a complex panorama, but I believe that in the report, with the help of everyone, we have been able to collect, and we have known how to aim for it to be explored, to achieve what we all here - we have seen - share. We share, and I think there is a general consensus, the need to guarantee the sustainability of health systems and to guarantee access to medicines by European citizens. I can only end by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs enormously - also the rapporteurs of the opinions of DEVE, JURI and PETI, with their invaluable contribution, and, of course, their capacity for dialogue - so that we could achieve this report, which had a broad consensus in the committee and which I hope will have the same support tomorrow, so that we can thus support the initiatives that the commissioner is going to implement and, ultimately, improve the quality of life of European citizens.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 2 March 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The financial crisis and austerity policies are forcing many states to make massive cuts in essential services such as healthcare.There are millions of sick people who cannot access treatments and medicines because of the price.There are medicines on the market that allow the treatment of numerous diseases but with unreasonably prohibitive prices.For example, Sofosbuvir is a drug used to treat hepatitis C, which is sold within the EU at a price that is 277 times the production price.The mechanisms of intellectual property, instead of meeting the needs of patients, are used by pharmaceutical companies to maximize profits.All of this is in clear contrast to the fundamental right to health.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – Health expenditure remains constant even if the prices per patient of some new medicines are higher than in the past. It is true that during the debates on this report, the discussion on affordability of medicines was automatically related to ‘fair price’. But what does fair pricing mean? From my point of view it means one that can reasonably be covered by patients and health budgets and that simultaneously continues to sustain research and development.  Currently, the high prices of many new medicines are challenging public healthcare systems or patients who have to pay for them out of their own pocket (as is the situation in most low- and middle-income countries). Therefore, we have to find solutions to overcome this situation by taking into account the economic circumstances and needs of the health system of each country, not by creating idealistic references for high-income countries in price setting, and highlighting the advantages of incremental innovation.  We also need to address the additional barriers which hamper patients’ access to medicines, and which are not related to budgets: red tape and bureaucracy, lack of vision for the medium and long term, instability of legislation in many Member States, unpredictability, and a lack of dialogue and partnership.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - In recent decades, the prices of new medicines in the EU have risen to the point of becoming unaffordable for many citizens. To ensure a better balance between the public health interests of EU countries and those of the pharmaceutical industry, this proposal for a legislative initiative is welcome, which calls for measures to improve the traceability of research and development costs, public and marketing expenses. However, it saddens me to note that, while 11 million Italians are forced to give up medical care, some politicians are working to multiply the business of pharmaceutical companies. We know well that the pharmaceutical industry uses the strategy of the "evergreen patent" in order to preserve the monopoly of a product as much as possible, making only small changes such as, for example, the addition of an excipient. We asked for a vote on the amendment in question because everyone must know who those political groups are that support it. It is good to reiterate that we of the 5 Star Movement are opposed, today as always, to those political groups that are on the side of industry and pharmaceutical multinationals whose only interest is to make a profit at the highest cost of all: that of leather and patient health.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the report, because it really supports citizens in matters of access to medicines and expanding options. The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights recognizes citizens' fundamental right to health and medical care. Public health systems must ensure universal access to health care for all European citizens. We believe that medicines are the key factor in healthcare, where all citizens have access. The high prices of innovative drugs do not provide accessibility to all citizens. Competition is an important factor in reducing drug prices and thus improving access to medicines. We note that expenditure on the EU pharmaceutical industry accounted for 17.1% of total health expenditure and 1.41% of Gross Domestic Product.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - Access to medicines is one of the most important topics dealt with by the government of each Member State of the European Union. On the one hand, in the face of increasing resistance to antibacterial agents, we must foster innovation, which of course costs money. It costs both pharmaceutical companies and citizens. On the other hand, we must bear in mind that health budgets are generally very tight and the differences in wealth among European societies are huge. Therefore, we are pleased with the provisions of the report, which draw attention to these problems, calling, inter alia, to adjust the price of drugs to the wealth of the population, promote generic drugs or look at the problem of the so-called parallel trade, through which richer member states buy drugs from their poorer neighbors. At the same time, I would like to point out that the provisions regarding the quality assessment of medicines and proposing common criteria may weaken the autonomy of the Member States in deciding on prices and the level of reimbursement for medicines. I hope that the Commission will not interpret these imprecise provisions in this way and decide not to enter an area where it does not have the power to act under the Treaties.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up. - It is unfortunate that many citizens in the Member States do not have access to healthcare or medicines and, moreover, it is extremely worrying that thousands of victims are registered due to the lack of effective treatments for rare diseases, as well as the lack of access to certain treatments or their astronomical cost. Member States must support research and development based on the medical needs of citizens, with a view to creating innovative medicines and producing generic medicines at affordable prices for all patients. Greater transparency is also needed in terms of the costs of investing in pharmaceutical research, development and innovation, so that the consumer does not end up paying twice for the same product. I believe that the Member States must cooperate on their own initiative, in particular with regard to prices, reimbursements and the exchange of information. I urge public decision-makers to take proactive steps to make generic and biosimilar medicines available in a timely manner to truly reduce total costs and costs for medicines, always taking into account the need to ensure the same beneficial effects and continuity of patient care.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, I invite you to vote in favor of this report. In recent years, pharmaceutical companies have been asking exorbitant prices for their new products. In my country, in Belgium, we are talking about more than 43,000 euros for the treatment of hepatitis C, but also more than 100,000 euros for one year of treatment for breast cancer. Ultimately, these prices put the social security budget into play. Moreover, the innovative reputation of the most expensive drugs is often overrated. Are these indeed real innovations? To justify the high prices, pharmaceutical companies highlight the high costs of drug research and development. But how much does it really cost to develop a new drug? The information is not public. In addition, a significant part of research takes place in universities financed by public funds. It is therefore fortunate that we are dealing with the matter today. Thank you for your attention.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - It is well known that access to healthcare is a fundamental right of all citizens. As such, one of the basic objectives of the EU and the WHO, namely Sustainable Development Goal 3, is precisely to ensure that individuals (patients) have access to medicines. Obviously, access to medicines is dependent on the timely existence of medicines and their degree of accessibility for all citizens, without discrimination. But there are still major discrepancies between public health systems, as well as between pharmaceutical systems in the Member States, to which are added the challenges posed by the aging EU population. Moreover, access to medicines is restricted either due to pharmaceutical business strategies (profit maximization strategies), or for political reasons, related to the production or distribution process or even due to parallel trade, or due to higher revenues. reduced rates of some Member States. However, improving access to medicines can also be achieved by reducing administrative procedures and budgetary constraints, by developing biosimilar and innovative medicines. Also, the involvement of all those interested in the medical field (manufacturers, researchers, patient organizations, institutions, etc.), in order to improve access to medicines for Europe's citizens is essential.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - Due to the dynamically developing pharmaceutical industry, the World Trade Organization (WTO) suggested including drugs in the patent system and introduction of intellectual property rights protection for enterprises related to the development of new drugs. The right to protection of intellectual property rights is a fundamental right enshrined in Art. 17 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. It aims to provide investors / researchers with a return on investment, ensuring, promoting and stimulating innovation and research for the benefit of society. Such a solution could bring many benefits and the pharmacological market could become one of the most attractive and profitable markets. Another important aspect presented in the report is the standardization of the availability and prices of medicines for the citizens of the Member States. It is important to ensure that every EU citizen has full access to medicines that are innovative, safe in quality and sold on the market at affordable prices. Therefore, I believe that proposals should be supported to protect the rights of our citizens both in terms of equal access to medicines and the intellectual property rights of researchers.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: - The next item on the agenda is the one-minute remarks on important political issues (Rule 163).

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: - Mr President, Parliament must know that the Nissan factory plant, located in Ávila, is a fundamental company for the development of our land: hundreds of families depend on it directly or indirectly. The decision to immediately cancel the production of the NT500 vehicle, as well as to reduce the production of the NT400 model, starting next April, would mean the loss of 500 direct and 300 indirect jobs and, above all, contravenes the industrial plan in force until 2023, co-financed with Community funds and aimed precisely at supporting the manufacture of these vehicles. I want to expressly acknowledge the importance of Nissan in Ávila and all that it has contributed over the years, but the important thing in times of uncertainty is to guarantee the jobs linked to maintaining production. No one can lose their job. Any solution must go through the maintenance of job stability; Any solution must go through the agreement accepted by the workers and must not entail a loss of salary, labor or geographic. The Commission has to commit. From the European Parliament we will fight for it and we will be vigilant.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, we can see that the epidemic of military spending is spreading across western countries. According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, the world’s military spending may reach USD 1.7 trillion. More than half of this money is in NATO countries’ military budgets: USD 980 billion. But for some politicians this is not enough. US President Donald Trump made an announcement about increasing the military budget by USD 54 billion. Chancellor Merkel said recently that Germany will raise defence spending to 2% of GDP; some other European countries are going to do the same. I would ask my colleagues whether they really believe that spending 20 times more than a potential adversary is not enough for defence. I doubt it. This is a neat trick whereby some lobbyists want to redistribute budget money from social and development objectives to the military.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Dear Colleagues, we are witnessing a dangerous farce about the supposed friendly agreement between Portugal and Spain on the construction of a temporary nuclear waste warehouse at the Almaraz power station, which pledged to start a constructive dialogue. Qualifying the ATI as temporary is a real scam. ATI is the very key to the survival of nuclear energy in Spain, which, since 2010, should have been built alongside Madrid, but which the opposition of the Government of Castilla-La Mancha has embargoed. The answer to the drama of the 5 Spanish nuclear power plants being already at 90% of their capacity was Almaraz - the obsolete power plant next to Portugal, whose soil the Spanish National Security Council classified as a risk. In 2008 and 2015, Portugal and Spain signed protocols for consultation on cross-border projects, so this supposed agreement does not add anything new. Ironic is that the Spanish Minister of Environment now promises all transparency to Portuguese neighbors and friends, in a rhetoric that convinces no one, claiming that ATI is a pool that has no major environmental impact and that even improves the current situation. More ironic and dangerous is the Government of Portugal having abdicated national interests, withdrawing the complaint against Spain. The Portuguese do not give in to manipulation and only accept the closure of the Almaraz plant.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: - Mr Chairman!While the world was enjoying the end of World War II, an anti-Soviet armed uprising was taking place in Poland, involving over 200,000 people.citizens, brought thousands of victims murdered with a Katyn shot in the back of the head.To commemorate their memory, we have been celebrating the National Day of Remembrance of the Cursed Soldiers for 7 years.On this day, I am in Poland and with Poles with my heart and mind.Hello and glory to the heroes!

name: Daniel BUDA
text: - Mr President, thank you. Are we asking ourselves today where Europe is heading? Do I think that before answering this question, we must answer where the European Union started? We all know that the lack of freedom, death, hunger, poverty and war paradoxically generated this great project. And today we can see that the Union has ensured us peace and prosperity for 60 years, which shows us that there has not been, is not and will not be an alternative to the European Union. A Europe with concentric or two-speed circles will not be a place where opponents and allies unite as the founding fathers of the European Union wanted, on the contrary, this reconfiguration would certainly lead to the disintegration of the European project and that is why Romania decides for a strong, consolidated and united Europe. Whatever solutions we pursue, they must be the result of consensus, and a strong Europe is a life assurance for all Member States.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: - Mr. President, this Friday marks a year since the assassination of Berta Cáceres, a human rights defender, feminist and Copinh leader. Despite the unanimous condemnation of this Parliament and other international organizations, her murder to this day remains unpunished. According to Amnesty International, there are judicial loopholes and a disgraceful lack of effective investigation. This situation is intolerable and sends a message of impunity, not only in this case, but also towards the 123 activists killed in Honduras since the 2009 coup d'état. Enough, ladies and gentlemen, with good words. If we want to stop the murders, we must send a strong message. The European Union-Central America association agreement should now be paralyzed, as well as cutting off bilateral aid to the Honduran State, especially in the Eurojusticia program. Facts and not words: this is what ensures that human rights violations by states and companies do not remain unpunished.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Commissioner, I would like to thank all those who have helped Peter Jašek to be free at this point. The Czech humanitarian worker was imprisoned for fourteen months in Sudanese prisons and eventually unjustly sentenced to twenty-four years in prison. His name was part of a resolution adopted by this Parliament last October. Thanks to pressure from Czech and European diplomacy, Sudanese President Umar Bašír pardoned him on Sunday, February 26, and ordered his immediate release. We could all see his great joy when he stood with the Czech Minister of Foreign Affairs Zaorálek and the Ambassador to Egypt Šmigolová before leaving for his homeland. I think that together with the diplomatic pressure of the European Union, it was the great diplomatic commitment of Minister Zaorálek and the Czech Ambassador that led to the release of Petr Jašek. Thanks to them and thanks to God, Petr Jašek is alive and well in freedom. It is an encouragement to us all, love and truth have once again won.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Mr President, in recent days the trials against Catalan independence leaders by the highest courts of justice have been accelerating in Spain. Weeks ago I asked the Commission what it thought about judicial independence in Spain, as provided for in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The Commission responded by making a vague, generic praise for judicial independence and indicating that the Commission forms an opinion based on surveys and bilateral dialogue with the national authorities, which are precisely those denounced. I see that I cannot expect much from the European Commission in this regard. Therefore, I renew my complaint here. In Spain, it is increasingly difficult to find judges and prosecutors of the highest magistracies who do not depend on the will of the Government and the first opposition party: they are elected by them and follow the orders of the State Attorney General, also appointed by the Government. In Spain, the separation of powers is a democratic desire not yet realized.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union imports Canadian wheat which according to North American laws should be disposed of as waste, but here in Europe it becomes pasta, bread, pizzas, flour and sweets. We assist in a sort of dumping on the contrary, damaging the agriculture of the South and is attentive to the health of consumers. The practice of mixing contaminated grains with contamination-free grains in order to obtain moderately contaminated batches, albeit within the limits of the law, is prohibited, but some processing industries justify this practice as unavoidable for their know-how. The Commission must absolutely harmonize at the international level the European thresholds of mycotoxins, first of all the DON. This should be accompanied by a ban on the use of glyphosate in imported grains, recognition of the subsidiary role of associations in toxicological analyzes on cereal-based products and support for consumer information campaigns. We owe respect to the trust of those who consume and the structures of those who work.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Mr President, said the President of this Parliament, at the beginning of the session, that he was very concerned about freedom of expression in the world.I would like to invite Mr. Tajani to come to Spain, where this week seven trials are being held for comments on social networks.And it is that in Spain there is repression, persecution and criminalization: for questioning the Royal House, like the rapper Valtonyc;for a tweet, like Cassandra, Strawberry or Zapata;for a political satire sketch, like Facu Díaz;or simply by an ironic play, as happened to the puppeteers a year ago.These are just a few cases, but there are more.And it seems that in Spain for a tweet or a song you can end up behind bars.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - (The first part of the speech was not recorded due to a technical problem.) Mr President, as the Romanian state, wants to abolish the Roman Catholic Grammar School in Târgu Mureş. To this end, it uses the National Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office, which on the pretext of suspected corruption has not only suspended the school principal, but is currently illegally harassing hundreds of students' parents and ordering them for questioning. At the same time, the county education inspectorate illegally banned children from enrolling in elementary school. The fall of about four hundred students at the school is in jeopardy, and the existence of the school itself is at stake. I protest against the anti-minority discrimination and abuse of power and intimidation of parents that afflict our Hungarian church school. I call on President Antonio Tajani to intervene to protect the school, parents and children.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, since May 2010, the catastrophic memorandum has been implemented in Greece, which has turned the country into a vast social cemetery, with millions of poor people and armies of unemployed. As if that were not enough, the Troika continues "business as usual". Already yesterday, the representatives of the Troika invaded Athens and demanded reductions in pensions of up to 35% but also reductions in income through the reduction of the tax-free limit. So instead of recapitalizing the insurance funds, which were destroyed by the Troika with the PSI, it finally sends the already impoverished retirees to the memorandum Kaiadas. Instead of creating a public fund for the red loans, the Troika is hammering the houses of the Greeks. Instead of investing, the Troika is launching the sale of public property instead of a lentil plate. The Greek people no longer tolerate the memoranda and will soon throw the Troika out of our homeland.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I would like to inform Parliament and the Commission that the Minister of Industry and Trade, Jan Mládek, has been dismissed in the Czech Republic, because he did not sufficiently defend the interests of consumers and preferred the interests of mobile operators. For example, it did not push hard enough to break down roaming prices and enforced the law on electronic communications, which harmed consumers instead of protecting consumers sufficiently against mobile service providers. The Minister is gone, but the original law, which in my opinion is in conflict with European law, with a European directive, continues to apply. I have repeatedly called on the Commission in writing to address and resolve the situation in the Czech Republic and to press the Parliament of the Czech Republic, the Czech Government, to change legislation that will protect the interests of Czech consumers as well as consumers across Europe. So I call on the Commission's representatives to further address this issue and resolve the inconsistency of Czech law.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Mr. President, I understand the public's concern in the Republic of Croatia about natural gas prices, especially after the liberalization that came with the new changes in the law on the gas market.However, the latest decision of the Government of the Republic of Croatia on regulating the wholesale gas price is not in the long-term interest of the Republic of Croatia, ie in the long-term public interest.The reason is that in this way investments in renewable energy sources are postponed, those that need to use local potentials, investments in energy efficiency are postponed and in both cases local jobs are not created, which are so necessary to increase employment in Croatia.Also, such a policy endangers the security of supply of the Republic of Croatia in the long run, because the insecurity will eventually be paid for by either the citizens or HEP.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Mr President, the common agricultural policy is a terrible failure. In France 700 farmers committed suicide last year and one in three farmers lives on less than 350 euros per month. Agriculture Commissioner Phil Hogan at first denied the gravity of the situation. He admits to being completely outdated today. In an interview he gave to the newspaper Liberation on February 28, he believes that more aid should be given to small farms and less to large ones. But nothing is done. The problem is deeper anyway. The CAP is responsible for the agricultural disaster because it recklessly abolished customs duties and deliberately encouraged the concentration of farms. The 1000 cow farm and its production model: a model adapted to ultra-liberalism. If we want to preserve family farming, we must therefore completely change the model. As a French person, I recommend replacing the CAP with a PAF, a French agricultural policy.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Ladies and gentlemen!Comrades and companions!Today in Poland we celebrated the Day of Remembrance of the Cursed Soldiers, soldiers who fought underground with the communist occupier of Poland after the Second World War;they fought after the amnesty, they fought until Stalin's death, and the last of them died only in 1963.Today, the young generation of Poles is restoring the memory of the heroes fighting against communism.These young people asked me to tell you about the steadfast soldiers and to honor their memory with this speech.We tell them, "Hello and glory."We say, "Hello and glory to the heroes," but whenever I enter this building through the gate marked Altiero Spinelli, I repeat their call: "Down with communism.Death to the Communists.Thank you for your attention.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Commission, namely Vice-President Timmermans and Commissioner Jour, for their proactive cooperation.Based on our dialogue, the European Commission launched a pilot project last year on the Justice Program: Europe of Diversities pilot project for multilingual and multicultural societies in the EU.This week I received a report that this call also inspired civil society organizations in my country, the Slovak Republic, and submitted a project called Better United in Europe.It is a nice example of the positive response of the idea of European Commission experts in the society of a Member State.I hope that other good projects from other countries will be presented, and I also hope that, after a successful evaluation of the pilot project, we will continue to work together on the basis of the same principles.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: - Mr President, the Spanish Government has approved a legislative decree to gradually abolish the current port stowage system and liberalize this sector. This decree has been approved without social dialogue. It goes far beyond what the European Court of Justice itself asked for; it puts the continuity of the stevedores' jobs at risk and makes their working conditions precarious. It does not take into account the negotiations that the union and the employer have held for two years, nor the fact that both parties had already concluded agreements that were perfectly compatible with the Court's ruling. We support an open stowage model without monopolies, but that preserves, at the same time, the rights of employees and guarantees dignity in working conditions, safety and training. We don't want more precarious work or cheap layoffs; we want quality employment and policies that promote and protect it. We fear that, in this case, the Spanish Government is also going in the opposite direction.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, is é inniu an chéad lá de cheiliúradh Sheachtain na Gaeilge 2017. Is fiú a rá gur ceiliúradh idirnáisiúnta é seo, agus dá bhrí sin, táim thar a bheith sásta fáilte mhór a chur roimh thoscaireacht daltaí ó ghaelscoileanna éagsúla, Gaelscoil na Bruiséile ina measc, agus beidh siad ag teacht anseo an tseachtain seo chugainn chun na Parlaiminte. Glacfaidh na daltaí páirt i gcluichí rólghlactha trí mheán na Gaeilge.  Is díospóireacht bheo leanúnach í cearta teanga. In Éirinn, mar shampla, tá ár rialtas féin ag déanamh faillí ar ár bpobal Gaeilge le heaspa seirbhísí agus easpa aitheantais. Tá dearcadh rialtas na Breataine scannalach i dtaobh ár dteanga dhúchasach agus níl sé toilteanach Comhaontú Chill Rìmhinn a chomhlíonadh maidir le hAcht na Gaeilge. Tá sé chomh tábhachtach dár bhféiniúlacht, dár gcultúr agus do chearta daonna go seasfaidh an tigh seo lenár gcearta teanga. Is páirt dár bhféinmhuinín, dár n-éiceolaíocht agus dár gcultúr í an Ghaeilge. Bímis bródúil agus mórtasach aisti agus tugaimis teachtaireacht láidir do na glúine atá amach romhainn gur sheasamar an fód agus, gan dabht, tá an focal deireanach ag an mbean ón nGaeltacht sa tigh seo anocht, mar sin bainigí taithneamh as an gcuid eile den oíche.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!In one of the Dutch so-called Levenseindekliniek, or end-of-life clinics, a woman suffering from depression was killed against her will, but aware of what was happening to her, and a defending woman.Her fate was decided on the basis of euthanasia procedures.This macabre act will not be justified by any law, no public support, no political parties, no authority.I call for the Vice-President of the European Commission, Mr Frans Timmermans, in whose country this tragedy took place, to take a position without delay on this matter.We must all be aware that the permissive silence of official human rights ombudsmen will be an invitation to escalate similar inhuman practices.I am waiting for the reaction of the European Union authorities.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: This item on the agenda is thus closed.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: On behalf of all my colleagues, I thank the Commission for its presence.I would like to thank the interpreters for their excellent work late into the night and wish you all a good night.(The sitting was closed at 11.40 p. M.)
